summary: Paul Merson reignited his spat with Andros Townsend by mocking the Tottenham winger’s seven-minute cameo in a 0-0 draw at Burnley, tweeting “did you miss the coach? #RubberDub #7minutes.” Their row began when Merson wrote that Townsend’s England inclusion lowered the bar, only for Townsend to score a spectacular equaliser against Italy, after which Merson acknowledged he was wrong. Townsend had fired back on Twitter, and although the tension seemed to ease, Merson’s latest tweet revived the dispute following Tottenham’s draw at Turf Moor.

Chelsea have made a formal summer offer for FC Tokyo’s 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane, with plans to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem if the move happens; Ogane says the bid is unrelated to Chelsea’s £200m Yokohama Rubber sponsorship. Muto, an economics graduate from Keio University, has 37 club appearances with 16 goals (13 in his debut season, earning J-League Best XI) and has started this season with three goals in four games, while internationally he has 11 caps and one goal for Japan. A fee around £4m has been suggested, Muto calls the offer an honor but says he has not decided, and he would be Chelsea’s first Japanese player if he joins. Yokohama Rubber becomes Chelsea’s shirt sponsor from 2015-16, with a possible pre-season tour of Japan under consideration.

A large Finnish study of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months—and those with repeated prescriptions before age two—were more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers, especially boys, who were also slightly taller. While the study, published in Pediatrics, did not prove causation, researchers suggested antibiotics may alter gut bacteria, increasing appetite or nutrient availability, potentially contributing to the obesity epidemic. With one in five boys and one in ten girls overweight or obese by age two, the authors urged judicious antibiotic use in infancy, noting broader concerns about over-prescription, rising antibiotic resistance, and prior links to eczema and digestive issues.

During a Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a young Queen’s Guard slipped on a manhole cover as he took position in his sentry box, sliding sideways, knocking his bearskin, and dropping his rifle in front of hundreds of tourists. He quickly scrambled up while colleagues continued as normal, blushing as he realized the crowd had seen the mishap, which was filmed by tourist David Meadwell. The slip was believed to be caused by metal protectors on his boot soles. The Guard, part of fully operational soldiers serving Buckingham and St James’s Palaces, performs daily in summer and every other day in winter. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E Networks will remake and simulcast the landmark 1977 miniseries Roots across A&E, Lifetime, and History in 2016, reimagining the saga of Kunta Kinte and his descendants for a new generation. The adaptation, co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, will be described as original and contemporary, draw more directly from Alex Haley’s novel, and consult African and African-American history scholars for authenticity. Executives and producers emphasize honoring the legacy while making the story resonate amid modern context, noting many young viewers are unfamiliar with Roots despite its cultural importance and the backdrop of recent racial issues and milestones.

Police are investigating former royal footman Christopher Lawler’s claims that, on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978, several male aides—including a senior staff member—tried to force him into an orgy, pinning and groping him before he escaped, after which he was threatened and quit the same day. Lawler says his initial complaint drew an angry response and was ignored, and that when he contacted the Palace again amid renewed probes into historical abuse, he was twice rebuffed before the matter was finally referred to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide in his 80s has reportedly denied involvement, citing being at Balmoral, and the Palace has pledged full cooperation with police, who declined detailed comment during the ongoing investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a parody rap video set to The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme, filmed largely in their car and viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The lyrics describe their life in Happy Valley, Oregon, fielding family pressure about parenthood, conceiving faster than expected, and discovering the pregnancy with a positive test; the video ends with them sharing a sonogram. They said it took five takes, was intended to inform faraway loved ones, and its viral success was unexpected; they may make another video after learning the baby’s gender. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and Melissa had previously filmed Jesse’s reaction to the news via a tag on their dog. A similar Fresh Prince-themed pregnancy announcement was made by a Pennsylvania couple the previous year.

A gray jacket-and-skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, which featured over 150 items from the 1939 film. Originally slate blue-gray but faded to light gray, the outfit appeared in several key scenes, including Scarlett’s encounters with Rhett Butler and the shanty town attack. The items came from the vast private collection of James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios hair and makeup department head who began collecting GWTW memorabilia in the 1960s, famously rescuing the dress for $20 from the Western Costume Company. Other notable sales included Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit pieces ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, marked its 75th anniversary recently and featured Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American to be nominated for and win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy suffered minor injuries after falling 10–12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo when his mother allegedly dangled him over the railing while holding another child. The parents rescued him before responders arrived, and he was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center in stable condition with bumps, bruises, and a leg injury; the cheetahs did not approach. Witnesses expressed shock, and zoo officials said multiple accounts suggest the child was dangled. The exhibit was closed, and the zoo plans to pursue child endangerment charges against the mother.

A nonfunctional speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham was mysteriously turned to face a house’s front door after all fixed cameras in the West Midlands were decommissioned in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. Since then, speed enforcement has relied on mobile units, motorway cameras, and patrols. Birmingham City Council, aware of the misaligned camera on Wellington Road, plans to inspect the site and may remove it; it will not be included in a forthcoming pilot of new digital cameras. The homeowners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic champion, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2–3, confirming he is fit and ready to run. Expressing excitement about the event’s atmosphere and Jamaica’s strong relay tradition, Bolt said he aims to make his country proud. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed his selection, anticipating “sprint magic,” and noted the full Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Neymar and Barcelona teammate Dani Alves showed support for the club by attending a EuroLeague basketball El Clasico with Neymar’s sister Rafaella, where Barcelona beat Real Madrid 85-80, though Madrid remain top of their division on points difference. The outing followed Neymar captaining Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates, a feisty match featuring heavy challenges including an apparent stamp by Gary Medel. Before the international break, Barcelona won the football El Clasico to go four points clear in La Liga, and they next face Celta Vigo as they pursue a treble.

Italy is facing a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East transiting through Libya, with 8,480 people rescued between Friday and Monday and 20 SOS calls on Monday alone. Save the Children fears up to 400 may be missing after survivors reported a capsizing of a boat carrying 550 about 80 miles off Libya, but the Italian coast guard says it cannot confirm this and has found no evidence, survivors, or bodies despite air and sea searches. The International Organization for Migration reports over 10,000 arrivals in Italy in the first quarter of 2015, about 2,000 rescues in early April in the Channel of Sicily, and at least 480 deaths this year, often due to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler boats, and crews abandoning vessels.

Arsene Wenger says he doesn’t know exactly why Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool after leaving Barcelona, but is delighted the £32m Chilean, who has 19 goals this season, joined and has quickly proven his top-level quality in work rate, efficiency, and impact. He acknowledges Liverpool’s interest in Sanchez may have been linked to Barcelona’s move for Luis Suarez and could have served as leverage in negotiations. Ahead of Arsenal’s match against Liverpool, Wenger downplays links to Raheem Sterling and praises Brendan Rodgers for adapting well after Suarez’s departure and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries, noting Liverpool’s impressive goal record last season.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt cycling’s Hour Record on June 7 at London’s Lee Valley VeloPark, aiming to surpass the current 52.491 km mark set by Australia’s Rohan Dennis in February after UCI rule changes revived the event. Wiggins, 35 on April 28, recently ended his Team Sky road career at Paris-Roubaix and will race the Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on the track, with ambitions for a British record eighth Olympic medal in the Rio 2016 team pursuit. He hopes to perform before a 6,000 sell-out crowd with live coverage on Sky Sports; tickets go on sale April 19 via Sky Tickets priced £49, £39, and £29. The Hour Record has seen recent attempts by Jens Voigt (51.115 km), Matthias Brändle (51.852 km), and Jack Bobridge (unsuccessful), and will also be targeted by Briton Alex Dowsett on May 2 in Manchester.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, narrowly defeated Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in a Fed Cup singles match but admitted the struggle was an “eye-opener” for her clay-court readiness, noting she had been playing as if on hard courts and must prepare for longer rallies. Despite improving her head-to-head with Errani to 8-0, Williams and Alison Riske lost the decisive doubles 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in the U.S. being relegated to World Group II. Williams’ doubles loss blemished her previously flawless Fed Cup record, and U.S. captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need to work harder to return to the elite, citing the depth of American players in the top 100. Williams, who won her 19th major at the Australian Open, acknowledged clay has been her least successful surface despite French Open titles in 2002 and 2013.

River Plate are interested in re-signing Radamel Falcao, with vice president Matias Patanian saying the club “dream” of his return and that “the doors are open,” but acknowledge the deal is complicated. Falcao, 29, previously spent eight years at River Plate, debuting in 2005 and scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances before moving to Porto in 2009. Currently on a season-long loan at Manchester United with just four Premier League goals, his future there is uncertain, and he could return to parent club Monaco. Despite club struggles, he has recently hit form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games to equal the nation’s all-time scoring record with 24.

Ella Henderson, the 19-year-old X Factor finalist and platinum-selling pop star, has been announced as the face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” campaign—her first brand collaboration—featuring international TV ads set to her single “Mirror Man.” The campaign, brought together by the MILES agency for the UK’s number one dry shampoo brand, showcases Henderson in various hairstyles and outfits against a vibrant, blurred city backdrop, and highlights her personal use of the product. Mark Hargreaves of Crown Talent & Media Group called it a natural synergy between a globally popular artist and a widely loved brand, signaling an exciting year ahead.

A month after 26-year-old Aaron Siler was fatally shot by Kenosha officer Pablo Torres following a vehicle and foot chase—during which police say Siler armed himself—Siler’s family and friends condemned as “disrespectful” a police union-funded billboard in Kenosha featuring Torres and thanking the community for its support. The Kenosha Professional Police Association said no offense was intended and the message was to acknowledge community support amid recent incidents affecting the officer, his family, and the department. Torres is on leave pending the ongoing investigation into Siler’s death. Separately, a prior shooting by Torres of 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives, was investigated and deemed justified by the district attorney.

Iranian state media reported that eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near Negur, close to the Pakistan border, with three militants killed by Iranian forces. Officials said the attackers crossed from Pakistan, and Iran has asked Pakistan to capture the surviving assailants. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility; it opposes Iranian influence, has targeted Shiites, operates in Pakistan’s Balochistan, and has previously carried out deadly attacks in Iran, including killing 14 guards in 2013 near Saravan. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not curbing such militants, while Pakistan condemned the attack, launched an investigation, requested evidence from Iran, and pledged to apprehend any perpetrators who entered its territory.

Japan’s Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told parliament that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered UFOs from outer space, explaining that while jets are scrambled for unidentified objects, they typically turn out to be birds or non-aircraft items. The statement came in response to questions from flamboyant lawmaker and former pro wrestler Antonio Inoki, who claimed to have seen a UFO but said he doesn’t know if aliens exist. Inoki’s colorful background includes wrestling Muhammad Ali, founding New Japan Pro Wrestling, media appearances, product promotions, diplomatic forays to Iraq and North Korea, and practicing both Islam and Buddhism. The discussion follows earlier political musings in 2007 on how Japan’s pacifist constitution would handle a hypothetical alien invasion.

At Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Anhui, China, 35-year-old passenger Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts to his left leg and buttocks after the porcelain toilet he was squatting on collapsed and shattered; he had stood on the rim to avoid touching the seat, then called friends instead of shouting for help, but required immediate hospital treatment and dozens of stitches. He reportedly admitted to friends he had been squatting but later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation, while authorities deemed it an accident and reminded the public that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested and charged with aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden bathroom camera that led police to him. Prosecutors say he secretly filmed the girl and others over three to four years, producing 41 videos—34 showing victims showering—and uploaded some, including close-ups of children’s genitalia, to his computer. The girl reported that Rebbie watched her undress and, from ages nine to 13, entered her bedroom and molested her while she slept. Rebbie admitted filming several victims and said he bought the camera to record the now-15-year-old. The relationship between Rebbie and the family is unclear. He is held on $500,000 bail, with a preliminary hearing set for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s latest series, from a book roughly titled “Daughter and Salaryman,” features teenagers standing calmly or smiling while their suited fathers leap into the air striking dramatic poses. The concept lets typically serious “salaryman” fathers show a playful, heroic side, with some older dads displaying slightly pained expressions mid-jump. Shot in front of various Japanese landmarks, the images pair casually dressed daughters with sharply dressed fathers, vary in jump intensity, and have attracted significant online attention despite limited available background information.

Following the sacking of England managing director Paul Downton, speculation over Kevin Pietersen’s potential return to the national team intensified as he took part in Surrey’s preseason photocall at the Kia Oval. Pietersen, last capped during England’s disastrous Ashes whitewash in Australia in 2013-14, showed mixed emotions—pensive during the team photo yet jovial with teammates and photographers—as he rejoined Surrey to push for a Test recall ahead of the summer Ashes. Surrey open with Oxford MCCU on Sunday and begin their County Championship campaign at Glamorgan on April 19.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, battling relegation, sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani left them 16th and six points from safety. Ze Maria, a 41-year-old former Inter and Parma right back capped 25 times by Brazil, had been fired on Wednesday, reinstated Thursday by owner Angelo Massone, and initially hired in January as the club’s third coach of the season, replacing Florin Marin. He will now be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar says Radamel Falcao likely regrets leaving Monaco for his season-long loan at Manchester United, where he has struggled after a serious knee injury and scored only four goals, making a £46m permanent move unlikely. Dirar notes Falcao was unhappy in Monaco but believes he would have played more and featured in the Champions League there, suggesting the Colombian may have needed a different atmosphere despite not feeling well in France.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a very tall man who robbed the Union St dairy in east Christchurch around 12:30 pm Saturday, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. Security footage shows the offender throwing the cash register to the ground and fleeing with the till drawer and about $1,500, after demanding money from the owner’s 30-year-old daughter, who ran out screaming “robber.” No weapons were reported, and the suspect remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers at 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 after admitting she kissed a 15-year-old student and let him touch her breasts in April the previous year; she was placed on administrative leave. Following rumors of another victim, police questioned a second 15-year-old who alleged he had sex with Granado in her car on January 18 and 19 across from a Dallas school. Granado was arrested again and released on $50,000 bail, with the district stating it took immediate action, though her plea to the new charges is unknown.

A widely viewed video shows a large crocodile swimming through Puerto Vallarta’s marina in Mexico with a dead black dog wearing a red collar in its jaws, identified as the pet of a local bike shop owner. Tourist Tim Weston, who filmed the incident, said the crocodile held the dog for hours and that the marina is near a crocodile sanctuary connected to the sea; the dog reportedly approached the water out of curiosity. Crowds gathered to watch, and social media reactions were horrified, though crocodiles are common in the area due to surrounding mangroves and urban encroachment. American crocodiles in Mexico can reach up to six meters and are frequently seen near human developments, including local golf courses.

After a 2-0 loss to Southampton left Hull City two points above the relegation zone with six games remaining—including tough matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United—manager Steve Bruce remained confident they can stay in the Premier League, suggesting eight or nine wins might suffice despite having only six so far. He cited long-term injuries to key players (Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and the season-long absence of Robert Snodgrass) as central to their struggles but stressed positivity and belief. Southampton’s win, with goals from a James Ward-Prowse penalty and Graziano Pelle, moved them up to fifth, while Ronald Koeman planned to address a penalty-taking dispute after Sadio Mane tried to take the spot-kick ahead of designated taker Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he asked pupils to alter SATs exam answers—and also changed some himself—outside test conditions, leading the Department for Education to annul the entire school’s 2014 results. A local authority probe confirmed the breaches; Guffick admitted unacceptable professional conduct, claiming he only sought to improve legibility, but a conduct panel ruled no changes are allowed after exams. While noting his remorse and that the conduct fell short of fraud, the panel and the Education Secretary’s representative deemed a prohibition order appropriate; Guffick has 28 days to appeal to the High Court.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard, who has struggled for playing time since joining from Aalesunds in 2010 and has made just 19 league appearances in five seasons, is now third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes and has been told he can leave, though a January move to FC Midtjylland fell through. Off the pitch, he married Swedish model Misse Beqiri—who has Albanian roots—in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius after dating since 2012; the couple have a son. Lindegaard shared Instagram posts celebrating time with Beqiri, who regularly shares her modeling work with over 17,000 followers.

Thirteen glowing blue letters that topped Yankee Stadium since 1976 failed to sell at a Sotheby’s auction, despite an estimate of $300,000–$600,000; the only “bid” was a $260,000 paddle raise by a Sotheby’s employee to spur bidding. The letters, owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson—who bought them after the stadium’s final 2008 game and joked he’d underestimated their massive size—were intended to be passed to a new generation. Jackson attended the auction and had promised to visit any U.S. buyer’s home. In contrast, a New York Mets late-1960s bullpen car estimated at $20,000–$30,000 sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed incidents involving Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe being seen with nitrous oxide and shisha pipes, reminding them of their professional responsibilities but opting against disciplinary action after speaking with them, and urging focus on learning from the episode. With Daniel Sturridge injured, Sterling is set to lead the line at Wembley, while Steven Gerrard returns from a three-match suspension and may feature against Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final, though Rodgers did not confirm a recall. Emphasizing progression after near-misses in recent competitions, Rodgers stressed that setbacks are part of the journey toward eventual success and is focused on guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his tenure.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after the international break and shared a “Home Sweet Home” photo relaxing with his dog. Fresh from impressing in Germany’s 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifying win over Georgia, the Arsenal playmaker—signed for £42.5m in 2013—aims to feature against Liverpool after missing the Newcastle match through illness, with Arsene Wenger dismissing nightclub rumors. Since returning from injury, Ozil has produced four assists and three goals, says he’s adjusted well to English football’s demanding schedule, and feels he “fits perfectly” with frequent matches and no winter break.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu reaffirmed that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, expressing they are very happy with his performance. Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer and has the team six games from the La Liga title, is focused on current competitions, with his contract running until 2016. Bartomeu praised Enrique’s work ethic, noting Barcelona’s pursuit of a treble late in the season. The endorsement followed a 2-0 win over Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson, 24, has agreed a new long-term contract at Anfield worth about £100,000 per week through summer 2020, providing a boost after the FA Cup semi-final loss. He becomes the third key player under Brendan Rodgers to extend, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Signed from Sunderland for £16m in 2011, Henderson has been a standout this season with 13 assists and seven goals, and is a leading candidate to replace Steven Gerrard as captain when Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy. While Raheem Sterling has rejected a new deal, Liverpool expect contract talks with him to resume at season’s end.

Filipe Luis, despite interest from Atletico Madrid in re-signing him, says he is happy at Chelsea and intends to stay until his three-year contract ends. After featuring for Brazil in friendly wins over France and Chile, he shifts focus to Chelsea’s Premier League run-in. He notes Jose Mourinho’s constant demands for focus and winning every match, acknowledging the difficulty of the remaining nine games but believing the team is prepared to handle the challenge.

Nathan Hughes’s three-match ban and red card for a knee-to-head collision that knocked out George North on March 27 were overturned on appeal, with the panel ruling no foul play occurred and the incident was accidental. Initially deemed reckless and resulting in Hughes missing Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon, the sanction drew widespread criticism from players and pundits. The appeal, heard afresh with new evidence, rescinded the dismissal and ban, freeing Hughes to play, though he’s not selected for Wasps’ upcoming Premiership game. North, who was knocked unconscious for the third time in two months, has been advised to rest for at least a month due to concussion symptoms.

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia, ignited by farmers’ grass burning and intensified by strong winds around April 14, destroyed dozens of villages before being extinguished; their lingering smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific to the Pacific Northwest, producing striking red sunrises and sunsets in Washington, Oregon, and British Columbia. The smoke’s particles filter out shorter wavelengths (blue, green, yellow, purple), allowing reds and oranges to dominate—an effect most vivid at sunrise and sunset due to the longer atmospheric path. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets’ reddish hue will fade.

After her brand-new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her St. Louis driveway, Becky Schoenig learned on April 1 that police had found it thanks to a tip from Mick Sexton. The returned car had been altered with red spray-painted rims, red side detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of getting upset, Schoenig joked on Facebook thanking the thieves for “pimping” her ride, though she’s having it professionally cleaned due to the strong cigarette and marijuana smell. To honor Sexton, she’s creating a smoothie called the Sexton on Wheels at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, featuring banana, pineapple, peach, and coconut cream. A friend described Schoenig as vibrant, happy, and someone who loves making people laugh.

Manchester City’s players, including stars like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, are on incentivized contracts tied to financial fair play and stand to lose £500,000 each—around £12 million squad-wide—if the club fails to qualify for the Champions League. After a derby defeat to Manchester United, City sit fourth, potentially just four points ahead of Liverpool if they beat Newcastle, with only the top three securing automatic Champions League spots and fourth requiring a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the season has unraveled since being level with Chelsea in early 2015, citing seven losses and early FA Cup and Champions League exits. The club’s uncertain finish could hinder signing elite targets like Paul Pogba, while United, now four points clear, expect to attract top talent.

Manchester United’s Under-18s beat Manchester City 1-0 in a “mini-derby” at Altrincham’s Moss Lane, where around 1,000 watched a free-entry match featuring a notably local, English-heavy lineup (13 English players, 10 Mancunians). United mirrored a first-team three-at-the-back system, and after an even first half—with City’s Marcus Wood going close and United’s Marcus Rashford missing chances—England U17 midfielder Callum Gribbin won it just before the hour, drawing a foul with nimble footwork and curling in the resulting free-kick past keeper Charlie Albinson. Cameron Borthwick-Jackson later hit the woodwork, City pressed late (including a Dilrosun free-kick onto the roof of the net), but United held on. The result leaves United two points behind Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury-hit City have lost both play-off matches; the match showcased promising homegrown talent on both sides.

After England’s 1-1 draw with Italy, Joe Hart praised 37-year-old Gianluigi Buffon as a “legend of the game” and an inspiration upon Buffon earning his 147th cap. Hart, who reached his own milestone with a 50th England cap at the Juventus Stadium, said he is still learning by watching Buffon, aims to continue improving for club and country, and is determined to add many more international appearances.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with Postmates to deliver online and mobile orders in 67 cities, adding a 9% service charge on top of Postmates’ distance- and demand-based fees starting at $5. After previously declining third-party delivery collaborations, Chipotle approved Postmates, whose model uses independent contractors similar to Uber. The brand has high visibility—recently visited by presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio—and joins other major chains expanding delivery, including Starbucks (also with Postmates), Taco Bell, McDonald’s, and Burger King.

Bill and Denise Richard, parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard—the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings—wrote a Boston Globe op-ed urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev in exchange for life without parole and a waiver of appeals. They describe their family’s profound losses, including severe injuries to their daughter Jane, and argue that years of appeals would prolong their anguish and harm their two surviving children. While acknowledging the crimes’ brutality and speaking only for themselves, they call for closing the case to allow healing for their family, Boston, and the country. Tsarnaev was convicted on all 30 charges; the sentencing phase was set to begin, and his brother Tamerlan was previously killed in a police shootout.

A mystery billionaire spent about £400 million converting a Boeing 747-8—normally able to carry up to 600 passengers—into a private luxury jet designed for himself and several dozen guests. Customised over three years by Greenpoint Technologies, the aircraft features multiple lounges, a hotel-like “state room,” a master suite, guest bedrooms including an “aeroloft” with eight full beds, an office/guest room, a conference room, and a central dining room connected to a full kitchen for a private chef, creating an opulent, hotel-style environment in the sky.

SpaceX launched an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft atop a Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station, successfully placing Dragon en route but failing in a challenging attempt to land the first-stage booster on an ocean droneship—the rocket touched down but tipped over, following a similar failed try in January. Elon Musk emphasizes reusable rockets to drastically cut launch costs. Dragon is delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research gear and an espresso maker, will spend about five weeks at the ISS, then return over 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash to a Pacific splashdown off California. This was SpaceX’s sixth ISS mission, the first by a private firm to dock there, and followed a weather-scrubbed attempt the previous day.

Priscilla Presley, 69, will serve as witness at the first wedding in the new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel at Las Vegas’s Westgate Hotel (formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows). In collaboration with NBC’s Today show, a contest will select one Elvis-obsessed couple—announced next Monday—to receive an “ultimate wedding” on Thursday, April 23, including a free reception, two-night hotel suite, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who helped shape the chapel’s look as part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, emphasized it will be first-class with no impersonators. Couples must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve to be first to wed there.

Liverpool’s Jordan Henderson believes Liverpool can catch Manchester City for a Champions League spot after a 2-0 win over Newcastle, which marked 47 appearances this season for both him and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet. With City four points ahead and faltering after a 4-2 loss to Manchester United, Henderson emphasized regaining form following recent poor results. Raheem Sterling scored early with a skilful finish and Joe Allen added his first Anfield goal, acknowledging it wasn’t his best game but the goal was vital. Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal when Dejan Lovren challenged Ayoze Perez, which Allen thought looked a penalty, but it wasn’t given.

Roma ended a four-month home winless run with a 1-0 Serie A victory over Napoli, crucial for Champions League qualification hopes. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute after a swift counter, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis preserved the lead with multiple second-half saves, notably against Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini. The win moved second-place Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio; they had not won at home since November 30. Napoli’s winless streak stretched to five games, keeping them fifth. Tight security measures were implemented due to past violence, including a ticket ban for Campania residents; no incidents were reported. Roma were missing Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli saw Lorenzo Insigne make a late return from a long-term knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers’ uninspired season continued with a drab 0-0 home draw against Fleetwood Town, a game so uneventful that the club’s media team produced a 27-second “highlights” video—only 14 seconds of actual action—showing the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle, reflecting fans’ frustration and the team’s mid-table League One mediocrity.

The passage describes Roland Giroux’s unusually tactile bond with his blood parrot cichlid, captured on video as he gently cups and massages the fish, which repeatedly returns to his hand, stays still as if enjoying the touch, swims up his arm, and follows his hand when withdrawn. Giroux removed two bullying tankmates, began hand-feeding frozen blood worms, and found the fish became more sociable and even frustrated if not played with daily; he now massages and plays with it for at least 15 minutes each day. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

The passage discusses Ben Stokes’s fiery temperament and its management within the England cricket team, recalling his past locker-punch incident at Kensington Oval and a recent clash with Marlon Samuels. It praises his natural aggression and character, noting his fearlessness (e.g., against Mitchell Johnson), while stressing the need for controlled aggression and careful man-management, which coach Peter Moores has begun effectively. A minor back niggle could affect his selection in Barbados, and while there’s a case for playing a second spinner like Adil Rashid, England prefer to keep Stokes and Chris Jordan involved to maximize their development, accepting inevitable highs and lows as they grow and contribute with runs and wickets.

Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out its 33,000 capacity amid soaring interest following Wales’ 3-0 win in Israel, highlighted by a Gareth Bale free-kick. Both teams lead Group B with 11 points from five games, Belgium top on goal difference, and expectations are high that Chris Coleman’s side can secure an automatic qualifying spot. Despite speculation about moving the match to the larger Millennium Stadium, UEFA rules requiring 120 days’ notice prevent a venue change, and the Wales squad prefers the more intimate Cardiff City Stadium, where they have chosen to play.

England U17 coach John Peacock named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the defending champions, perfect in qualifying, are drawn in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. England open against Italy in Burgas on May 7, then face Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13. The squad features goalkeepers Paul Woolston and Will Huffer; defenders Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay DaSilva, and Tayo Edun; midfielders Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland, and Chris Willock; and forwards Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi, and Ike Ugbo. Notable inclusions are Chelsea’s Jay DaSilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal’s Chris Willock and first-time call-up Stephy Mavididi, with Liverpool’s Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold recalled after missing the Elite Round in which England beat Romania, Norway, and Slovenia.

Manchester City are pursuing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, considered a top talent from Anderlecht’s academy and also monitored by Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously turned down Barcelona’s La Masia at age 12 to prioritize his studies. City have held talks with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock over a compensation package, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure the promising youngster for the future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, was found strangled and beaten to death on March 28 in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, southwest London; she was pronounced dead at the scene with head and neck injuries. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death, bailed, and told to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death. Santillan, who worked in London, Paris, and Miami and described herself online as visiting London from Miami, had recently expressed her love for London and Paris. Police have not confirmed whether her profession is central to the investigation but pledged to do everything to solve the case.

Dawn, a bereaved mother who suffered seven miscarriages and buried one son, Daniel James, discovered that £207 saved toward his £500 gravestone was stolen. On The Jeremy Kyle show, she accused her long-term friend and housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, and his girlfriend Carol. After lie detector tests, Jamie was found to have taken the money; he had also messaged Dawn en route to London professing love and blaming Carol. Devastated and feeling betrayed, Dawn broke down in tears and left the stage, later explaining the money was meant to honor her son with a headstone.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis in northern Iraq, mostly women, children, and the ill or elderly, with counts reported as 217 or 228; the release was coordinated with help from Arab tribal leaders, and the freed were received by Peshmerga and sent to Irbil. The motive was unclear. ISIS had previously released some Yazidis following its 2014 takeover of northern towns, notably Sinjar, which triggered a humanitarian crisis as Yazidis fled, many becoming trapped without supplies. The group killed hundreds and reportedly raped and enslaved women. An international response included airdrops, rescues, and from August, U.S.-led airstrikes in Iraq and Syria. Yazidis, a Kurdish-descended, pre-Islamic religious minority of about 500,000 in Iraq, have long faced persecution.

Tottenham and England striker Harry Kane, enjoying a breakout season with 20 Premier League goals, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards, competing with stars like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez. Ahead of the awards, Copa90 released a clever animation titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?” that uses layered still photographs to recreate some of his best moments, including a long-range goal against Chelsea, a header versus Arsenal, and his goal-scoring England debut, highlighting his animated on-pitch celebrations.

Jamie Carragher backed Brendan Rodgers to remain Liverpool manager despite a trophyless season and likely failure to make the top four, arguing one game shouldn’t decide his future and noting many new signings haven’t settled. He said Rodgers must identify improvements and get recruitment right to push for a trophy and Champions League return next season. Liverpool are seven points behind fourth-place Manchester City with a game in hand and were knocked out of the FA Cup by Aston Villa. Carragher, who won a Beacon Award for his community work through his 23 Foundation providing coaching in deprived Merseyside schools, emphasized giving local youngsters support, reflecting his commitment to his Bootle roots and broader philanthropy.

At East Midlands Airport, four-year-old James Hayward had his brightly colored Nerf-style toy gun confiscated after it appeared on X-ray, and he was frisked by security, which his father called over‑zealous and ludicrous. The family, en route to Lanzarote, did not argue to avoid missing their flight; they later bought James a replacement toy online. The airport apologized for the inconvenience and said they had offered to mail the toy home, defending the action by citing government-set security rules that prohibit items resembling weapons, including replica or model guns, under Department for Transport regulations.

A man identified as “Rich,” a 31-year-old from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife, listing extensive requirements: a non-drinking, non-smoking, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal woman who loves pets, the outdoors, can be “a princess” when needed, is good around the house, handy, a good cook, and “great in bed.” He offered accommodation and potential perks like a company car, phone, laptop, free gym membership, and other “benefits,” saying he’s generous and will consider all reasonable offers, but excludes former partners. He describes himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, 175 cm tall, “well endowed,” sober, drug-free, outdoorsy, successful, property-owning, and independent, and Daily Mail Australia could not reach him for comment.

Five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—publicly back FA chairman Greg Dyke’s proposals to boost English talent by raising the required number of home-grown players in Premier League squads from eight to 12 and redefining “home-grown” as training in England for three years before age 18 rather than 21. Despite Premier League opposition, their letter warns that blocking the reforms will further harm England’s competitiveness, noting only 36.8% of recent Premier League starters were England-eligible and arguing the shrinking talent pool disadvantages national team managers. Citing emerging players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, they say England can produce top talent but lacks opportunities for young players.

The passage discusses a rapid pregnancy timeline in the TV show Poldark, where Demelza, barely showing one week, is eight months pregnant at the start of the next episode and gives birth minutes later, leading to viewers’ remarks about the show’s compressed timelines. It notes Ross Poldark’s affectionate response to his new daughter and his deepening feelings for Demelza despite marrying her out of duty, while highlighting fans’ reactions on social media and comparing this accelerated timeline to Elizabeth’s earlier swiftly concluded pregnancy.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson, whose team sits bottom of the Premier League but just three points from safety after back-to-back wins including Jamie Vardy’s injury-time winner at West Brom, urges his players to stay calm, focus solely on their own performances, and not be distracted by relegation rivals or shifting predictions; he stresses that their fate remains in their hands, results elsewhere only matter if Leicester do their job, and warns against becoming overly optimistic during their mini-revival.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest recorded mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding grounds off Russia’s Sakhalin Island across the Pacific and down the U.S. West Coast to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous humpback whale record of 10,190 miles. Tracked by Oregon State University scientists, Varvara visited three major eastern gray whale breeding areas, suggesting she may be an eastern gray rather than a western gray as previously thought. This finding raises questions about genetic differentiation between eastern and western gray whales and implies the already small estimated population of 150 western grays might be overcounted.

Overnight, a 1,000–1,640-foot-long and about 100-foot-wide section of seabed rose 30–50 feet above sea level along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido, Japan, creating new coastline. Geologists, including researcher Yoshinori Yajima, attribute the uplift to a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow that caused land to drop and pivot the underwater area upward. Locals reported no sounds or tremors, and authorities believe the event is unrelated to earthquakes, including the recent 7.8-magnitude Nepal quake. Officials do not expect further expansion, and marine life such as seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the newly exposed surface.

Gregory van der Wiel denies plans to leave Paris Saint-Germain, expressing love for the club, city, and teammates, and stating he wants a new contract despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Chelsea Champions League match. He accepts the coach’s decisions and remains ready to play, though PSG’s links to Dani Alves could influence his future.

Carlos Tevez, Juventus’s top Serie A scorer this season with 17 goals, has informed the club he wants to leave this summer to return to Boca Juniors, where he began his career. Boca president Daniel Angelici says the move is close but depends on Tevez first terminating his Juventus contract, which runs until 2016. Juventus, while reluctant to lose him, are identifying replacements. Argentina coach Tata Martino says a move to Boca would not affect Tevez’s national team prospects and would not be a step down.

Bayern Munich demolished Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena, overturning a 3-1 first-leg deficit to reach the Champions League semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace by Robert Lewandowski. The team led 5-0 by halftime and overwhelmed a shell-shocked Porto. Amid the excitement, manager Pep Guardiola ripped the left leg of his trousers, exposing his underwear, joked he’d need new ones for the next match, and removed his blazer during the latter stages.

A three-car crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2 km south of Fernvale, injured ten people including four children. A 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain were first airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain. Six others—including an infant and two young girls—were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment; one man had hand lacerations and two females were uninjured. One person was initially trapped and freed by firefighters using hydraulic cutting gear. Rescue 500 helicopter assisted with airlifts. The highway was closed for several hours with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Ahead of Arsenal’s crucial Premier League clash with leaders Chelsea, Mesut Ozil showed off a new Apple Watch on Instagram, likening it to Knight Rider’s Michael Knight gadget, as he anticipates Sunday’s 4pm kickoff; Ozil, with four goals in 25 games this season, is expected to start for Arsene Wenger’s side, who trail Chelsea by 10 points with six matches left, while Jack Wilshere has returned to the squad after five months out and, despite his talent, is backed by club legend Ray Parlour to fulfill his potential only if he can stay fit.

Referee Mark Clattenburg, regarded as one of the Premier League’s top officials, will oversee Sunday’s Manchester derby at Old Trafford, assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official. Despite past controversy and accusations of favoring Louis van Gaal’s United, Clattenburg has shown only two Premier League red cards this season—both to United players (Tyler Blackett vs Leicester and Luke Shaw vs West Ham). He also recently sent off City captain Vincent Kompany for Belgium, ruling him out of a June international. The derby gains added significance after City’s 2-1 loss to Crystal Palace left United a point ahead, with United on a five-game league winning streak and City struggling since the turn of the year in the race for second behind Chelsea.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of assuming embattled MP Billy Gordon would resign, characterizing this as treating Gordon as “a little black puppet on a string,” which sparked social media criticism over his terminology. Katter, of Lebanese descent, said his wording reflected his own experiences with racism and was intended to call out perceived racial overtones, arguing that resignations weren’t expected in similar federal cases. Gordon, accused of domestic violence and of withholding his criminal history, quit the Labor Party but chose to remain in parliament as an independent, jeopardizing the government’s slim majority. Katter contrasted Gordon’s stance with past independents he claimed became government “puppets,” asserting Gordon would maintain his independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy and uses dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite bullying and stares, she emphasizes that she’s like other people, doing some things differently but not deserving different treatment. Her videos, including one set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off,” aim to entertain and encourage viewers to think before judging. Defying early medical predictions that she might never walk, Dayna dances, drives, attends college, and has started motivational speaking at schools in the Chicago area, seeking to change how disabilities are portrayed in TV, film, and fashion.

Orlando City have shown interest in signing Manchester United’s Javier Hernandez, seeing the Mexico international as a major commercial draw for their Latin-American fanbase alongside captain Kaka; however, competition is strong, with Premier League clubs Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, and European sides Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan also keen, as United are willing to sell for around £8 million with one year left on his contract after a frustrating Real Madrid loan. Separately, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United’s initial proposal, and he was on the bench against Aston Villa.

At 12:15 a.m. Saturday at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles, at least three suspects argued with a driver, attempted to carjack him at gunpoint, then doused his white Dodge Charger with gasoline and set it on fire while two passengers were inside; no injuries were reported, but the car’s front end was destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, the suspects remain at large, and surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his state license after admitting to the Iowa Board of Chiropractic that he bartered sex for services, performed exorcisms on patients, and advised some to stop taking prescribed medication. He agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove the problematic circumstances no longer exist to resume practice. Despite the misconduct, his HealthGrades.com profile shows three highly positive patient satisfaction reviews, and his listed practice address appears to be a residential home; associates declined to comment and noted he had not worked at his former practice for some time.

The U.S. lodged a diplomatic complaint to Russia after a Russian SU-27 intercepted a U.S. RC-135U over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, which the Pentagon called unsafe and unprofessional due to aggressive, high-speed maneuvers near the U.S. plane. Russia claimed the U.S. aircraft approached its border with its transponder off, a claim U.S. European Command denied. This incident echoes a similar episode a year earlier when a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk, prompting a prior U.S. complaint. Such encounters between U.S. and Russian aircraft are not uncommon in Northern Europe and near the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle was stolen from a Salt Lake City Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot overnight on March 27, days before President Obama’s Utah visit. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains to a truck safe, was taken after a thief broke the car’s rear passenger window, likely used a rope attached to another vehicle to rip the case free, and pulled the window frame from the door. Police found skid marks, rope pieces, and the case’s broken handle; the agent’s bags and some clothing were later recovered at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains missing. The hotel had no surveillance cameras. The rifle’s serial number was entered into the national database, the Secret Service was notified, and it’s unclear if the agent’s car was specifically targeted. The hotel is near the airport and down the street from the state’s FBI office.

A jury heard that Luigi Costa, 71, accused of brutally killing his neighbor Terrence Freebody in Red Hill, Canberra in July 2012, was likely suffering from dementia compounded by alcohol abuse at the time. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa’s mental state was declining before and during the incident, citing fluctuating mood evident in triple-0 calls and a trail of faeces indicating confusion. Mullen opined Costa’s brain was compromised, impairing his understanding of his actions and their consequences, and he rejected prosecution suggestions that Costa feigned memory loss. Costa’s mental state is pivotal, as proving instability at the time could allow a not guilty verdict.

In Everton’s 1-0 win over Burnley at Goodison Park, Ross Barkley took and missed a 10th-minute penalty—despite usual taker Leighton Baines being on the pitch—reviving memories of a January incident when Kevin Mirallas took and missed a spot-kick ahead of Baines. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley’s decision, saying penalties depend on how players feel in the moment and noting Romelu Lukaku would have taken it if he were playing. Martinez praised Barkley’s responsibility and said Baines accepted it. Tom Heaton saved Barkley’s well-struck but insufficiently placed effort, but Kevin Mirallas later scored in the 29th minute to secure the win.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam at 11:30 a.m. Thursday while the ship was in San Juan, Puerto Rico, during a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise that departed Tampa on March 29. The cruise line said the deaths appear to be a murder-suicide, secured the cabin, and notified authorities, including the FBI, which is investigating. The bodies were discovered by cleaning staff after knocking on the cabin door, according to a Puerto Rico Port Authority spokesman.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, began his tenure as Curacao coach with success, leading the team past Montserrat into the second round of CONCACAF qualifying for the 2018 World Cup. Curacao advanced 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw away, following a 2-1 win in Willemstad, with Charlton Vicento scoring an 87th-minute goal to avoid extra time. Curacao will face Cuba on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup semi-finalist as a player in 1998 and assisted Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, a highly decorated midfielder with major titles at River Plate, Real Madrid, and especially Inter Milan (including the Champions League, five Serie A titles, multiple domestic cups, and the FIFA Club World Cup), says that helping bottom-placed Leicester City avoid relegation—seven points adrift with eight games left—would feel like winning a trophy. Despite a winless run since January and an upcoming match against West Ham, he remains confident Leicester can survive, calling it their season’s main objective. Having joined on a one-year deal in the summer and become a key player, he is happy in the East Midlands and open to staying, noting Leicester’s consistent interest and his family’s contentment.

A 23-year-old mother, Gemma, risks being barred by her own mother, Debbie, from seeing her two young children due to persistent drinking, partying, and drug use (including legal high MKat), plus suspected theft. Debbie has raised both children since they were four months old after social services intervened, says Gemma is unfit and uninterested in motherhood, and alleges Gemma sold a child’s iPad to fund her lifestyle; a lie detector indicated she did steal. Debbie, who the children call “mum,” plans to ban Gemma from the home and visits because she can’t trust her, saying Gemma must grow up and stop drinking, drugs, and partying.

Eden Hazard scored to give Chelsea a 1-0 lead over Manchester United after a move that began when John Terry challenged Radamel Falcao from behind near halfway, leading to a loose ball collected by Cesc Fabregas, then Oscar’s back-heel to Hazard. During halftime, Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness all argued the goal should have been preceded by a foul on Falcao, with Souness calling it a forearm smash and saying the elbow caused Falcao’s fall, Henry affirming he would want that foul “all day long,” and Redknapp adding that even if Falcao could have been stronger, Terry’s challenge from behind was still a foul.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas after a rear tire blew out, but Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were safely evacuated before the bus burst into flames; bystander Michael Barnett filmed the incident without initially knowing it was the band’s bus. Scott shared photos on Instagram, thanking responders and noting everything in the back lounge was destroyed except her Bible. Bandmates Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on board, and Lady Antebellum was scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas, on Sunday.

Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University proposes using satellites equipped with mirrors and semiconductors to convert sunlight into laser light and beam energy down to Earth, potentially boosting solar panels, making solar viable in places like Scotland, and rapidly restoring power after disasters. Early trials in Scotland succeeded, with further tests planned in Portugal. He notes the beams would be far weaker than sci‑fi portrayals—“not powerful enough to blind a pigeon”—though control of the satellites raises some concern. A separate Tokyo Riken proposal would use ISS-mounted lasers to nudge tiny space debris into Earth’s atmosphere, also not weaponizable.

Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile with learning difficulties and a “fanatical obsession” with young girls, is on the run after leaving a psychiatric hospital in Winchfield near Hook, Hampshire, at about 6:15 pm on Tuesday. Detained under a hospital order following an August conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl and admitting 10 unrelated child indecent image offences, he is described as 5ft 8ins, heavy build, with dark hair, and may have recently shaved his beard; police released images with and without facial hair. Previously from Marchwood near Southampton, he was assessed as autistic with difficulty controlling sexual interests. Police have launched a manhunt and urge anyone with information to come forward urgently.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling after finding that Donald Sterling used community funds to lavish Stiviano with items including luxury cars and help with a $1.8 million duplex; Shelly’s attorney called it a victory that sets a precedent for injured spouses to recover such gifts. Stiviano had argued the gifts were legitimate and not exploitative. The case follows Donald Sterling’s downfall after leaked audio of him making racist remarks to Stiviano, which led NBA Commissioner Adam Silver to ban him for life, fine him $2.5 million, and force the termination of his ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal’s recent transfer dealings and said they must sign four top players—a goalkeeper, center back, holding midfielder, and elite striker—to win the Premier League. Speaking on Sky Sports after Arsenal’s 0-0 draw with Chelsea, he questioned whether Olivier Giroud, despite 14 league goals, can lead a title-winning side, urging stronger internal competition. Henry contrasted Arsenal with Chelsea’s successful spine-building signings of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa, noting Arsenal are third, level on points with Manchester City with a game in hand, but still lacking the necessary quality to claim the title.

A young woman testified in Sydney’s District Court about years of sexual abuse by Bega Cheese executive Maurice Van Ryn, describing profound, ongoing trauma including fear for future relationships, depression since age 14, self-harm, and a suicide attempt. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim said she did not initially realize the abuse was wrong and kept it secret until learning he had been caught, which prompted her to come forward despite fears of public exposure. Van Ryn, now in custody, sat calmly and did not look at her during the hearing; she worries about his eventual return to the community and the lasting impact on how she relates to men. The hearing continues, with Lifeline support information provided.

Arsenal’s 19-year-old midfielder Serge Gnabry, sidelined since March 2014 with a serious knee injury, is nearing a first-team return after completing 90 minutes for the Under-21s in a 1-0 loss to Reading—his second full match in a week. Having impressed before his injury, the Germany Under-21 international says he feels “better and better,” is over his injury, and is looking forward to the next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant and University of Birmingham graduate who worked for Liam Gallagher’s Pretty Green, died after falling 70 feet from a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while fleeing a taxi to avoid paying the fare following a night out. After he and two friends exited the cab under the pretense of using an ATM, they ran; in the dark, Phillips leapt over a fence and fell from the disused Northern Promenade (The Dardanelles). His body was found the next morning by a dog walker. At the inquest, the taxi driver said he hadn’t realized the danger, and the coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the cliff in the pitch black. Phillips, originally from Barry, had returned to Wales for Christmas and was staying with his mother.

Last summer, HM Passport Office faced a severe backlog as 3.6 million Britons applied for passports, leaving over half a million applications stuck by mid-June; despite offering free fast-track upgrades for urgent cases, many had already paid £30 extra and some missed trips. Ministers refused blanket compensation, citing precedent, and only 2,191 claims were approved between April and January (similar to the previous year), paying a total of £203,066—an average of £92.68—with payouts ranging from £1 to £5,463, while the agency said it could not report rejected claims due to a database failure. Critics, including Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz, were “astonished” at the low compensation levels given the agency’s £42.3 million surplus (April–October) and £1.8 million in management bonuses in 2013–14 (average £499, highest £3,500). Examples include a couple who lost nearly £1,500 on a missed trip to Morocco despite timely applications and paid upgrades, and among a dozen affected holidaymakers contacted, only one received money back.

A largely untouched 1930s three-bedroom semi-detached house in Horfield, Bristol is up for auction on April 30 with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000, notable for its original features including stained-glass windows (ships and coats of arms), a mint green and black bathroom with original tiles and fixtures, wood-paneled hallway, vintage kitchen cupboards and glass-panelled door, brick open-face fire, oil-fired central heating, and hallway shelf stocked with period tins (Cadbury’s Marvel, Tate and Lyle, Colman’s Mustard); despite some upgrades like double glazing, auctioneers note renovation costs may deter developers, positioning it as ideal for antique enthusiasts or a family home with a passion for period details.

Colin Kaepernick began as Alex Smith’s backup on the San Francisco 49ers, became the starter mid-2012 after Smith’s concussion, kept the role through the season, and led the team to its first Super Bowl since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film, produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, where she spent much of her early life before moving to Texas and later San Francisco. Separately, Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 within the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast via NBCUniversal’s division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, met Graham Coxon at Stanway School and formed Blur, whose 1991 debut Leisure received mixed reviews. Influenced by alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop, he later released a self-titled debut album in 2001 that achieved worldwide success. His solo debut, Everyday Robots, co-produced by Richard Russell, came out on 28 April 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, including samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu, locally known as Hamar and also called Muqdisho or مقديشو, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, serving as the location of many key national institutions.
“Happiness in Slavery” is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, released on their debut EP, Broken, in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

Shooter is a franchise centered on Bob Lee Swagger, a highly skilled marksman and Force Recon veteran. In the 2007 film starring Mark Wahlberg, Swagger is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit. The TV series adaptation stars Ryan Phillippe as Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action after discovering a plot to assassinate the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American medical drama television series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

In 1971, Charles Manson was convicted of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for orchestrating the killings of seven people—including actress Sharon Tate—by his followers, as well as for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea; after he was charged, recordings of his songs were commercially released.

Sean Justin Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began on television with a 1974 Little House on the Prairie episode directed by his father, Leo Penn. After his film debut in Taps (1981) and varied 1980s roles including Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), he earned critical notice with At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990), and Carlito’s Way (1993). He became a leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), receiving his first Oscar nomination and the Berlin Best Actor award. Further Oscar nominations followed for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), and he won Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (27 August 1908–25 February 2001) was an Australian cricketer regarded as the greatest batsman of all time, and after retiring he remained a leading figure in cricket for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.

Volcanic outgassing formed Earth’s early, oxygen-poor atmosphere and the oceans; as Earth cooled, a solid crust developed and liquid water became stable at the surface. Martin Van Buren (1782–1862) was the eighth U.S. President (1837–1841), a leading Democrat, and a close ally of Andrew Jackson. He previously served as the tenth Secretary of State (1829–1831) and the eighth Vice President (1833–1837) under Jackson. A key organizer for Jackson’s 1828 campaign, Van Buren briefly became Governor of New York to bolster Jackson’s prospects but resigned after two months to join Jackson’s cabinet. His 1831 resignation as Secretary of State helped Jackson manage the Petticoat affair, after which Jackson granted him a recess appointment as minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey hosts Rutgers University–Camden, originally founded as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is a U.S. state in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions, notable for being the tenth most populous and having the 11th largest total area, making it the largest state by total area east of the Mississippi River. It is the only state composed of two peninsulas, which contributes to its status as a leading state for recreational boating. A U.S. state is a constituent political entity of the United States.

Penguin Books transformed publishing in the 1930s by introducing affordable sixpence paperbacks, distributed through Woolworths and other high street retailers, which made high-quality fiction and non-fiction widely accessible to the mass market.

“Bad Romance” is a song by American singer Lady Gaga from her 2009 EP The Fame Monster. DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including major franchises such as Shrek (and its prequel-spinoff Puss in Boots), Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, along with notable titles like Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013), and Home (2015). Chris Eubank (born 8 August 1966) is a British former professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and previously held full control as Chairman and CEO of News Corporation, which later split into News Corp and 21st Century Fox on June 28, 2013. After King George V’s death in 1936, Mary of Teck became queen mother when her eldest son Edward VIII took the throne, but he abdicated the same year to marry Wallis Simpson. Human trafficking involves the exploitation of people—primarily through forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation—and is highly profitable, with the ILO estimating forced labor alone generated $150 billion annually as of 2014. The ILO reported 14.2 million people (68%) exploited for labor, 4.5 million (22%) sexually exploited, and 2.2 million (10%) subjected to state-imposed forced labor.

The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 informative and entertaining propaganda and training films, and it also created training films and trained combat cameramen.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the primary spokesperson for the U.S. executive branch, especially the President, senior executives, and policies. Kentucky, known as the Bluegrass State for the bluegrass in its fertile pastures, features the central Bluegrass Region that includes major cities Louisville and Lexington. Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event run from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW, initially broadcast via closed-circuit television and, starting in 1987, via pay-per-view—the first NWA event to do so. A floppy disk is a disk storage medium consisting of a thin, flexible magnetic disk enclosed in a rectangular plastic casing lined with fabric to remove dust, and is also known as a floppy, diskette, or simply disk.

Guatemala experienced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century, and from 1960 to 1996 it underwent a bloody civil war between a US-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military committed genocidal massacres against the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used to grasp and hold objects; in non-medical contexts they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.

Robert Palmer was a writer and music journalist known for his books, especially Deep Blues; his work for the New York Times and Rolling Stone; his production of blues recordings and the Deep Blues film soundtrack; and his earlier role as a clarinetist in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912–1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, in 1941. The Concert for Bangladesh, despite later financial issues due to its pioneering nature, is regarded as a highly successful and influential humanitarian initiative that raised significant awareness and funds, and provided lessons and inspiration for subsequent efforts, notably Live Aid.

The Freeport Doctrine was presented by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln–Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. Anne Rice (born Howard Allen Frances O’Brien, October 4, 1941) is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica; she launched her career with Interview with the Vampire in 1976 while in California, expanded it with sequels in the 1980s as her critical and popular reception grew, and was married to poet-painter Stan Rice for 41 years until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 population of 77,344, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state; historically, its early 20th-century population was predominantly European immigrants, and it fits the general definition of a city as a large, permanent human settlement.

Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader and received critical derision; the screenplay was an original work.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, known as The Great Debates of 1858, were seven debates in Illinois between Republican Abraham Lincoln, running for the U.S. Senate, and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas, held across seven Illinois towns.

Brad Wilk, who began with the band Greta in 1990, co-founded Rage Against the Machine with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991, served as drummer for Rage (1991–2000; 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007), and, as of 2016, played in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine’s lineup consists of de la Rocha (vocals), Commerford (bass/backing vocals), Morello (guitar), and Wilk (drums).

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. Aaron Burr served in multiple political roles: twice elected to the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), appointed New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), elected U.S. Senator from New York (1791–1797), and ultimately became vice president, the peak of his career.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) for the Soviet space program, succeeding Voskhod and originally intended for Soviet manned lunar missions; it remains in service today. The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft within the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with eight unmanned test flights and followed by the first 19 manned launches. The name “Soyuz” means “Union,” as in “Soviet Union.”
