Rage Against the Machine’s fourth studio album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000 by Epic Records. Tensions over the band’s direction led vocalist Zack de la Rocha to quit, causing the band’s breakup. De la Rocha pursued a low-key solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed together for the first time in seven years at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

The S&P BSE SENSEX (BSE 30) is a free-float market-weighted index comprising 30 well-established, financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one such company, being listed on the BSE (and included in the SENSEX), as well as on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with about 92.7 million people, making it the 14th most populous globally and ninth in Asia. It borders China to the north; Laos and Cambodia to the west; Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest; and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, it has had among the world’s highest economic growth rates and held the top spot in the 2011 Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam is one of four remaining one-party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two dramatic anti-British actions and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, with his popularity growing posthumously.

James VI and I (James Stuart, 1566–1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 1603 until his death, uniting the Scottish and English crowns in a personal union while the kingdoms remained separate sovereign states with their own institutions. He strongly advocated creating a single parliament for England and Scotland and encountered significant difficulties with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress known for originating in Shortland Street and for TV roles including Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, and Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor; her work also includes the film Separation City (2009), the Australian series Rake, and most notably Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, which she led for four years until her departure in 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, primarily recognized for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who starred or co-starred in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed critical reviews but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, becoming Lady Gaga’s second consecutive US number one, selling 757,000 copies in the US, and ranking as the ninth best-selling album of 2013 worldwide with 2.3 million copies.
In 2006, the Red Hot Chili Peppers released Stadium Arcadium, their fifth and final album featuring guitarist John Frusciante, who later confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism; she remains a controversial figure, widely praised as one of Britain’s most influential politicians while debates over her policies continue.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of the Valencian Community (also called the Valencian Country) and the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 residents in the administrative center; its metropolitan area is Spain’s third largest, with a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the original film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The television series Make It or Break It ended with its third season, as announced on April 26, 2012, and the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary area of computational linguistics that develops methods to convert spoken language into text, drawing on linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. It powers applications such as voice dialing, call routing, smart home control, search within audio, simple data entry, structured document preparation, speech-to-text for writing, and aircraft direct voice input. The field has advanced notably with deep learning, reflected in increased academic output and widespread industry adoption by companies like Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, many of which publicly attribute their core SR technologies to deep learning methods.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded San Diego Comic-Con International and became its chairman starting in 1970. The event, initially founded in 1970 by Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, was first called the Golden State Comic Book Convention, later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention, and is now known as San Diego Comic-Con.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee in the lead role.

France’s Victor Dubuisson shot a 67 to share the lead at 16 under with South Africa’s overnight leader Jaco Van Zyl, while Rory McIlroy posted a third consecutive 67 to sit one shot back at 15 under alongside Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy, seeking his first win since May, overcame early three-putt bogeys at the 3rd and 10th—with visible frustration—to rebound with a birdie on 11 and a near-perfect four-iron to set up eagle on 13. After returning from a summer ankle ligament injury and a modest restart to his season, McIlroy is chasing a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leads Danny Willett by 271,214 points with three events left post-Turkish Open. Overnight English contenders Chris Wood (-13) and Richard Bland (-12) slipped to fifth and seventh, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman of al-Wefaq urged meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, saying the government must offer concrete solutions and that a royal family representative—ideally reformist Crown Prince Salman—should lead talks. He contrasted reformists with hardliners around long-serving PM Sheikh Khalifa who oppose dialogue, fearing concessions. Salman noted youths’ disillusionment with moderate opposition but argued working with reformists is the only path, recalling a seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy agreed with the crown prince before GCC troops intervened on 14 March 2011, halting talks. He called for stronger, public pressure from the US and UK—expressing hope in John Kerry’s appointment—and criticized Britain’s private diplomacy. Despite bans, he pledged continued peaceful demonstrations and demanded the release of 13 opposition figures imprisoned on allegedly tortured evidence, warning dialogue will fail without them.

Christopher Hogwood, a leading figure in the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after several months of illness; his funeral will be private with a memorial service later. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it worldwide for about 30 years and producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a landmark 1980 Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson. Trained at Cambridge and with noted mentors, he began with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and co-founded the Early Music Consort of London. He served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic roles at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, scholarship, advocacy for historically informed performance, and lasting legacy in nurturing leading musicians.

Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims in the year to March 31, 2016—five fewer than the previous year, the lowest since 1976 and half the total from nine years earlier—with only one case unresolved. Sharp instruments were used in 51% of cases (29), nearly all involving knives (26). Police identified 31% of accused (20 people) as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs, though most had unknown substance status. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted continued efforts in education, enforcement, and cross-service support to reduce violence, especially related to alcohol. Labour’s Claire Baker welcomed the decline but cautioned against premature claims, noting previous upward revisions to homicide figures and pointing to rises in sexual crime and a 27% increase in attempted murder and serious assault. The prior year’s homicide total was revised from 59 to 62 after reclassification of three deaths.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 at Sunderland, becoming the first Premier League team to be beaten by the Black Cats this season despite taking the lead through Dan Gosling, their first goal in three games. Manager Eddie Howe, noting they had scored six against Hull recently, lamented missed chances and the failure to score despite creating enough opportunities “to win three games,” even after Sunderland went down to 10 men following Steven Pienaar’s red card. Sunderland’s goals came from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and Howe emphasized the need to accept such outcomes and focus on moving forward.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott defended Australia’s policy of detaining boat-arriving migrants in offshore camps, arguing that “stopping the boats” is necessary to prevent deaths at sea, amid international criticism including a New York Times editorial calling the approach brutal, inhumane, and legally dubious. He linked his stance to the tragic image of Syrian child Alan Kurdi, while urging Europe not to adopt similar policies. Abbott also sparked backlash from Australian Jewish groups by saying Islamic State was worse than the Nazis, a comparison condemned as inappropriate and historically inaccurate; he later maintained his remarks but said he was not in the business of ranking evil.

The US suspended bilateral talks with Russia on sustaining Syria’s ceasefire, blaming Moscow and the Assad government for intensified attacks on civilians in Aleppo, targeting hospitals, and blocking aid, including the 19 September convoy strike; it warned last week it would halt talks unless Russia stopped bombing Aleppo. Aleppo has faced heavy bombardment since the truce ended two weeks ago, with hundreds killed, a key rebel-held hospital hit three times in a week, and about 250,000 people trapped in the east. Russia denied involvement in the convoy attack, accused the US of failing to improve humanitarian conditions, shifting blame for the truce’s collapse, and not separating jihadist groups from moderates. Planned US-Russia coordination in Geneva was canceled and US personnel withdrawn, though both sides will maintain deconfliction talks on counter-terrorism to avoid clashes.

Policy Exchange’s report proposes selling vacant high-value social housing (worth above the regional average) to fund large-scale construction of new social homes, estimating £4.5bn annually after debt repayment—enough for 80,000 to 170,000 homes—and potentially cutting the 1.8 million waiting list by about 500,000. Downing Street supports councils choosing this approach to use stock more efficiently; Housing Minister Grant Shapps cites broader reforms aiming for up to 170,000 affordable homes. The think tank argues this would reduce “lucky” high-value allocations, remain present but smaller in expensive areas, and is popular with 73% of the public. Critics, including Labour, warn it would force low-income families out of affluent neighborhoods, erode mixed communities, and create segregation, instead calling for measures like a bank bonus tax to build 250,000 affordable homes. The report notes 21.8% of UK social stock (816,000 homes; £159bn potential, £70bn in London) is “expensive,” with about 28,500 units vacating annually that could generate the projected funds.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, was found dead at his Swansea home amid a local measles outbreak of 942 cases; while lab tests confirmed he had measles, the post-mortem could not determine if it was the main cause of death, and an inquest was opened and adjourned for further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have been hospitalized. Colfer-Williams, recently treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital, became unwell with a widespread rash, saw an out-of-hours GP on April 17, and died the next morning. His family do not know how he contracted measles; no close relatives have it, and his three-year-old daughter is vaccinated.

Cumbria Police charged 54-year-old Vincent Hudson of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, reportedly occurring in 2001, and he is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in a National League match, extending Gateshead’s unbeaten run to nine and Guiseley’s to five. Guiseley took a 15th-minute lead when James Hurst’s throw-in led to Jake Lawlor finishing into an empty net. Gateshead’s Liam Hogan made a key block and Guiseley keeper Jonny Maxted saved from Wes York before halftime. Gateshead equalized on 62 minutes when substitute Derek Asamoah slipped, allowing Wes York to curl into the top-right corner. Bookings were issued to Simon Walton (Guiseley) and Gus Mafuta (Gateshead), with late substitutions for both sides as the match finished 1-1.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to redevelop the football club’s stadium by replacing two stands to increase capacity, opting for this over a new Ashton Vale stadium delayed by a town green application. The redevelopment, approved by Bristol City Council in November, will proceed if no judicial review arises after signing the section 106 agreement. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown said they expect to sign soon, then wait six weeks; if there’s no judicial review by March, work will start in May.

Cuadrilla suspended fracking near Preese Hall after a 1.5-magnitude tremor—the second in Lancashire since operations began in March—pending analysis of British Geological Survey (BGS) data. The BGS reported the April 1 quake at magnitude 2.3 with a similar location and mechanism to the latest event, both about 2 km deep and within 2 km of the site, noting that pressurized fluid injection can induce earthquakes. Cuadrilla’s CEO said operations will remain halted for weeks during consultations with authorities. While fracking faces controversy in the US over environmental risks, the UK Commons energy select committee recently supported the practice under tight regulation. The BGS is monitoring the situation with temporary instruments near the drill site.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old Liverpool busker who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was found guilty of one fraud count for playing bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner in April 2015, though he was cleared of two other counts by a jury at Liverpool Crown Court. Police said he gave the impression he was collecting for the campaign; Carpenter argued he was simply busking and that the banner was a tribute, noting he had previously piped for the charity. The campaign’s chairman confirmed he permitted the banner’s design and display but expressly forbade its use for fundraising. Carpenter, known at Anfield on match days, will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with Grant Ward opening the scoring, Luke Varney adding a second after keeper Alex Smithies’ miskicked clearance, and Tom Lawrence finishing following a deflected Cole Skuse shot; Ipswich created numerous chances and could have scored more, while QPR offered little, coming closest when Sandro headed against the post. The result lifted Mick McCarthy’s side to 14th, above QPR in 15th. McCarthy praised Varney’s work rate and acknowledged Smithies both erred and prevented a heavier loss, while Ian Holloway blamed a defensive lapse around the second goal and called for greater mental toughness from his team.

Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, impressed in last season’s T20 Blast with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66, and he praised the club’s elite-performance environment under the coaches, saying it shows the club is moving in the right direction and motivating the players.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second straight win by beating third-placed Chinnor 29-12, driven by standout efforts from front-row leaders Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, with the pack making over 70 tackles. Coach Churcher praised the dogged display but noted it wasn’t a complete performance and emphasized the need to build on it. The Reds’ upcoming run includes seven teams below them in the table and a matchup with leaders Old Elthamians.

Police in Kolkata arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu and allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, as the suspected rapist of a 74-year-old nun in the 14 March Ranaghat convent attack, which involved theft and ransacking and sparked nationwide protests. This is the sixth arrest in the case; eight suspects have been identified and two remain untraced. Authorities say all five previously arrested accused named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on a tip that Nazu, who had fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV, would return by train. Earlier, in May, police arrested Milon Sarkar as the alleged gang leader, though his precise role remains unclear.

The passage introduces an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of London’s Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explaining why consumer purchases change over time, highlighting impacts from domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports on UK shopping preferences and product availability. It also notes that brand ownership and rankings among major UK brands are shifting, and provides links to non-interactive resources—including information on Chinese ownership, food-freezing tips from BBC Good Food, a UK top 20 consumer brands survey, and the Museum of Brands—while advising that the video works best in full screen and may not function on older browsers.

Two women in Scotland were scammed by callers posing as BT technical support: a 71-year-old from Sandyhills on 15 September and a woman from Stranraer seven days later. In both cases, the fraudsters cited internet problems, obtained remote access to victims’ computers, and stole substantial sums. PC Siobhan Pellett warned about the ease of such access, urged caution with cold calls seeking remote control, and emphasized never sharing banking or account details by phone, noting legitimate institutions do not request this information.

John Duffy, 37, has been appointed head coach of third-placed Championship club Featherstone Rovers on a one-year deal after leaving Swinton Lions, where he is credited for strong work under difficult circumstances. He will lead Featherstone in their final league match against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy as a fantastic coach. A former player for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford over a 16-year career, Duffy is succeeded at Swinton by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded at 12:50 GMT on Sunday to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve, where a rider was found unconscious on wet sand with head injuries and hypothermia; after on-site treatment, she was airlifted to the University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

At a UN World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a radio frequency for satellite-based aircraft tracking, enabling satellites to receive ADS-B transmissions for real-time global tracking. This decision, driven by shortcomings revealed by the 2014 disappearance of MH370 (with 239 people aboard) and the fact that about 70% of airspace lacks coverage under ground-based radar, was praised by ITU leaders as a rapid response. The system will allow continuous monitoring anywhere in the world, and ICAO has set a November 2016 deadline for airlines to adopt new guidelines requiring position reports at least every 15 minutes, with more frequent updates in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in 2002, has been found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is held in Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail, facing charges including tampering with records to obtain a driver’s license in 2012. The FBI confirmed Julian’s identity after a college application issue led to a tip on 30 October, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children; his mother has been notified. Authorities had long suspected the father, who claimed he was taking Julian to pre-school before fleeing.

A fire on 2 March at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site caused days of firefighting, reduced train services, and travel delays. Despite Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service finding the site operators, Asset and Land Group, broadly compliant with fire safety law during nine visits over the past year, the service had raised concerns to the Environment Agency (EA) in February about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment. Following joint inspections and consideration of the facts, the EA suspended the company from accepting waste after the fire and has now decided to revoke its environmental permit, effective 7 August pending any appeal; the company must remove all waste. The cause of the fire is undetermined, and the firm could not be reached for comment.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia proposed two bills linked to the Ukraine crisis, especially Crimea: one would allow Russia to annex territories based on a local referendum or leaders’ appeal without needing a treaty, justified for situations where a neighboring state is disintegrating; the other would fast-track Russian citizenship for Ukrainians by removing fees, residency and financial requirements, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship, enabling applications at Russian missions until 1 August with citizenship granted in two months. The measures target Russian-speaking Ukrainians, citing protection against a “brown threat,” and were announced in Sevastopol, where many residents, especially in the Russian Black Sea Fleet base, already hold Russian passports. Several Russian MPs and celebrities visited Crimea, and the context references Russia’s control over Abkhazia and South Ossetia after the 2008 Georgia war.

The passage charts McLaren’s cyclical rise and decline in Formula 1: from historic dominance—182 wins, 12 drivers’ titles, eight constructors’ titles, and peak eras with Honda (1988–92) and later Mercedes with Mika Hakkinen—to scandals (2007 spy case, $100m fine; 2009 “lie-gate”), near-misses (2007), and a downturn beginning in 2013 due to chassis issues. Despite current struggles and a weak Honda power unit after the renewed partnership, the team believes its car has recovered and that Honda will soon deliver a competitive engine. Ron Dennis, who has steered multiple rebuilds since being installed by Marlboro in the early 1980s, insists McLaren will be the next to break Mercedes’ supremacy. Fernando Alonso’s 2015 return embodies this bet on revival, but for now McLaren’s future hinges on belief that progress will translate back into “championships, plural.”

Thomas “Tommy” Baker, 44, from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest on 27 January at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool after leaving Phoenix Gym and getting into his car; he died in hospital. Three Liverpool men (two aged 29, one 32) have been arrested and remain in custody. Police believe the assailants waited outside the gym for about an hour and are seeking a silver VW Polo that sped from the scene along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road. Detectives are appealing for CCTV witnesses near the market to come forward, noting their information could be crucial.

The passage explores ways to enjoy a more spiritual, tech-enabled Christmas, highlighting: Everyday Church Online, a UK-based virtual church with a global chat-and-sermon format and a Star Wars-themed “Hope Awakens” series; Guardians of Ancora, a free Scripture Union game for 8–11-year-olds where players recover Bible stories, with Christmas quests about Jesus’s birth; viral nativity reinterpretations like Viral.de’s “The Digital Story of Nativity” (nearly six million views) and the Churches Advertising Network’s “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle” (about 250,000 views), the latter reportedly rejected by cinemas for being “too religious”; Next Manga’s Manga Messiah nativity available as apps and e-books in many languages, including 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees; and churches’ growing use of social media to prompt brief spiritual reflection, with commentators suggesting Jesus would embrace platforms like Twitter.

An eight-day inquiry in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land for a circuit, with backers offering 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts gave conflicting evidence on environmental impacts: Natural Resources Wales said it was difficult to conclude the replacement land matched the original’s value but did not oppose the project; developers’ ecology report claimed a net biodiversity gain through nearby habitat enhancement, which Gwent Wildlife Trust disputed. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend a course of action after the inquiry, with Welsh ministers making the final decision.

After Novaya Gazeta reported on 1 April that over 100 men suspected of being gay were detained and at least three killed in Chechnya—claims corroborated by the Russian LGBT Network, which detailed torture near Argun—Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April, decried the report as insulting, and vowed “retribution,” a stance the mufti publicly affirmed. Novaya Gazeta warned this amounted to calls for reprisals against journalists, urged Russian authorities to protect them, and pledged to continue investigating abuses, noting past killings of reporters linked to Chechnya remain unresolved. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, with his spokesman asserting there are no gay people in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is aiding victims to flee, accuses Russian authorities of inaction, and threatens to take the case to the International Criminal Court if prosecutions do not occur.

Investing Solutions, a lettings agency operating across seven London boroughs, partners with the charity Fresh Start Housing to place single homeless men—often over 35—into shared properties, enabling the agency to claim individual housing benefits per tenant and generate substantial profits by passing only a portion of rents to private landlords. Both organizations share a south London address and were founded by Samir Patel (Investing Solutions in 2002, Fresh Start in 2010), though Patel says the charity is independent. Example figures show £2,114 per month claimed for two tenants while the landlord received £1,150, yielding over £11,500 annual gross profit on one property. Nearly half of the agency’s recent two-year receipts—over £2.1m—came from Wandsworth Council. While the firms deny illegality and say most rent goes to landlords, a Crisis representative called the charity-business pairing “a new low,” and a tenant reported substandard, unsanitary housing. Fresh Start reports housing 788 people since inception and 222 in the past year but did not disclose how many via Investing Solutions. The government says local authorities must safeguard taxpayers’ money with investigations and inspections.

Great Britain lost a well-contested warm-up to the Netherlands after leading for most of the first three quarters, with Andrew Lawrence scoring 14 and Ben Gordon adding 13, including three consecutive third-quarter threes to briefly restore the lead. The Dutch, led by Worthy De Jong’s 18 points, opened the fourth with a 10-0 run to go up 71-60 and held on despite a late GB rally. Coach Joe Prunty, who used his strongest lineup before cutting the roster for a six-game EuroBasket qualifying campaign starting midweek in Hungary, stressed the need for consistent effort on both ends and praised Gordon’s impactful third-quarter stretch.

Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves for his 154 lb bout with Floyd Mayweather, a deviation from NAC rules requiring 10oz gloves at that weight; the NAC will publicly debate the request on 16 August, prioritizing fighter safety. Mayweather had indicated he’d wear 8oz gloves but had not filed a waiver initially. NAC executive director Bob Bennett cited multiple reasons for sanctioning McGregor’s boxing debut—Diaz’s boxing pedigree, McGregor knocking Diaz down multiple times, McGregor’s chin, youth, height, and reach—while noting Mayweather’s lack of recent KOs. Bennett has reviewed footage of McGregor’s progress, declared him ready, and advised hiring a boxing referee, leading to Joe Cortez’s involvement. Tensions arose in camp after Paulie Malignaggi left following contentious sparring images.

The passage marks the end of Fleet Street’s journalistic era as the Sunday Post closes its London office, with its last two reporters, Darryl Smith and Gavin Sherriff, departing after decades on the street. Once the heart of British newspapers since the Daily Courant in 1702, Fleet Street was famed for its dense cluster of titles, boozy pub culture, and hectic print operations, supplying most of the nation’s news before TV and social media. Veterans recall smoky newsrooms, typewriters, truck deliveries of paper, and entrenched sexism, alongside rituals of heavy drinking. Fleet Street’s decline began with Rupert Murdoch’s 1986 move to Wapping and the industry’s shift to computerized printing, prompting most papers to leave by 1988 and buildings to be repurposed. Smith will freelance and Sherriff will write memoirs, while former editors urge looking forward as this storied chapter reaches its final deadline.

J.K. Rowling reflected on both support and abuse she received on Twitter, saying the positive messages reminded her of the world’s decency while noting her “personal line” had been crossed by abusive comments; she defended standing up to bullies, revealed she’d been called a “traitor,” and blocked some users she believed were SNP supporters, though she also engaged positively with other SNP supporters and found common political ground. The backlash followed news of her £1m donation to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum, mirroring a £1m donation she made to the Labour Party in 2008. She joked about bringing marshmallows after someone suggested burning her books, and the piece notes the SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats in the recent election, becoming the UK’s third largest party.

A long-term University of Edinburgh study of 4,300 youths found that poverty significantly increases both offending and victimization: deprived children are twice as likely to face police action for the same crime, five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision, and more likely to offend even after controlling for other risks. Prior police contact was the strongest predictor of being NEET by age 18. Gender strongly predicted violence—boys were three times more likely than girls to be violent—while poorer girls were twice as likely as affluent girls to engage in violent crime, independent of factors like truancy or substance abuse. The research warns that juvenile justice contact can worsen poverty-related risks, perpetuating violence. A companion AQMeN study showed that despite Scotland’s overall crime decline, crime remains highly concentrated in deprived communities, which also face high chronic health problems and unemployment. The Scottish government highlighted record-low crime and investments aimed at tackling poverty and inequality.

Karl Haugh, 25, died after being stabbed in a laneway in the Marian Estate, Kilkee, early Sunday. Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm and was remanded in custody until 14 August, amid reported local tensions. Police allege Walsh and two others entered the estate around 01:00 seeking Haugh, encountered him and another man, and a fight involving weapons ensued, with additional individuals joining. Haugh sustained a fatal stab wound to the back and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Gardaí recovered knives, a knife handle and blade with blood, and golf clubs at the scene. Two other men arrested were released without charge, with files being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions.

In May 2014, Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted a claim that Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, had harassed and shot people during his UDR service; alerted by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster, Elliott learned of the tweet, which Flanagan deleted within an hour. The High Court heard Elliott has a clear MoD record, and ordered that Flanagan post a Twitter apology admitting the tweet was untrue and wholly without foundation; Judge Stevens reserved judgment on compensation. An insurance firm that indemnifies MLAs refused to cover Flanagan’s costs and compensation, a decision he is challenging separately. Elliott stated he felt vindicated and disappointed the matter took so long, saying it could have been resolved 19 months earlier.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff and founded in 1874, has boosted weekly sweater production from about 7,500 to 9,500 to meet rising demand driven by stronger-than-expected sales of its new Hawick Knitwear-branded range launched in January and continued growth in its private-label business. Acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year, the company sells across Europe (including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, Spain) and internationally (USA, Canada, Mexico, Japan). Hartop attributes the production increase to surging orders at home and abroad and expresses confidence in the firm’s future, crediting dedicated staff.

At Luton Crown Court, Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, admitted hitting 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn with his VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the low-setting sun and could not recall the traffic light color. Prosecutors said his car failed to stop at a red light as Blackburn, in appropriate clothing, stepped out to help a woman and child cross, while traffic in the opposite direction had stopped. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse, and the judge briefly paused proceedings to let him compose himself. The court heard the sun was about 10 minutes from setting and may have been in Wright’s eyes. The trial continues.

NATO’s “Dynamic Mongoose” exercise simulates hunting a German submarine (U33) to train against rising Russian submarine activity, highlighting both the challenge of detecting quiet, advanced subs and a critical UK capability gap. Ten NATO warships, including USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, plus ASW helicopters, a French Atlantique patrol aircraft, and NATO research drones, practice locating an elusive undersea adversary—likened to finding a needle in a haystack—using periscope sightings, sonar, and unmanned systems. Experts note Russia’s modern, skilled submarine force—about 60 boats including very quiet designs—poses a formidable threat, with subs able to remain undetected for months and “fingerprint” other vessels. The exercise underscores that Britain, having retired its Nimrod maritime patrol aircraft, must rely on allies for long-range ASW coverage, a “key vulnerability” that could expose its nuclear deterrent and demands attention in the UK’s defense review.

UN officials warn that South Sudan risks genocide and ethnic cleansing as violence since July spread to southern Equatoria, driving 340,000 people—averaging 2,500 daily—into Uganda, surpassing 2016 Syrian refugee outflows. Testimonies from refugees describe killings, rape, and ethnic targeting, with Dinka forces accused of attacking Equatorians and Nuers amid a conflict rooted in a power struggle between President Salva Kiir (Dinka) and ex–Vice President Riek Machar (Nuer). Refugees recount brutal escapes from Yei, including gender-based violence and murder; one woman’s husband was hacked to death by soldiers. Uganda, praised for its response, allocates land and shelter within 36 hours and supports farming, but strains are growing as Bidi Bidi swells to over 250,000 people within a 250 sq km area and the country hosts nearly a million refugees, with water supply a key challenge. Half of the refugees are children, schools are operating, and despite resilience, trauma is pervasive, prompting UNHCR calls for international pressure to halt the civilian massacres.

At 38, McKenzie is set to fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title. A former Norwich and Peterborough footballer, he turned professional in boxing in 2013 after quitting football in 2011 and holds an unbeaten record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The coalition’s £330m investment in new NHS facilities includes £33m for a new Bridgwater Community Hospital to replace the cramped, outdated 1813 building. Funded partly by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, the hospital is planned for Bowers Lane (subject to planning permission) and targeted for completion by autumn 2014. It will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray services, and space for mobile scanners. Local clinicians highlight the benefits of a modern, one-stop setting for integrated care, and the project follows recent replacements of three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals and ongoing work on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton.

A man was fatally shot in the chest near a black Mercedes outside a home on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, around 13:35 GMT; armed police cordoned the area, and he died after being taken to Northern General Hospital. Neighbours said he belonged to a nearby family gathered for a celebration, with relatives rushing out to help after the shot. The killing follows a spate of recent shootings in Sheffield—previously concentrated in the north—including a 25-year-old injured in Shiregreen, shots fired into an elderly couple’s home in Southey Green (believed mistaken identity), and two January incidents targeting houses in High Green.

The passage outlines cyber warfare activities by three prominent groups linked to the Ukraine-Russia conflict: pro-Ukrainian Ukrainian Cyber Troops, anti-Western Cyber Berkut, and Russia-focused Anonymous International. Led by Yevhen Dokukin, the Ukrainian Cyber Troops conduct DDoS attacks, hack CCTV and printers, target rebel funding via electronic payment systems, and claim intrusions into Russian interior ministry servers, with volunteer group Inform Napalm analyzing leaked data suggesting wounded Russian servicemen in Ukraine; officials deny using untrusted hacker-sourced data for targeting. Cyber Berkut aims to disrupt Ukraine’s military and propagate anti-Western narratives, claiming hacks on Ukrainian government sites during Joe Biden’s visit, accessing purported U.S. assistance documents, hijacking Kiev billboards, disrupting vote-counting, leaking defense data, blocking President Poroshenko’s site, and promoting an unverified claim about MH17. Anonymous International (b0ltai/Shaltay Boltay) publishes leaked Kremlin-related materials of unclear provenance, including letters and emails tied to the Ukraine conflict, and is blocked in Russia.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick grew emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond delivered valedictory speeches before standing down ahead of the 5 May election. Salmond, noting Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” welcomed new powers from the Scotland Bill while arguing they fell short of referendum pledges, and mixed gratitude with humor before signing off with “goodbye from me... for now.” Marwick praised Salmond’s service, while McNeil, departing after serving since 1999, urged Holyrood to strengthen accountability and scrutiny, suggesting it learn from Westminster’s committee system. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also bid farewell, joking about her exchanges with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Wales’s Older People’s Commissioner, Sarah Rochira, is gathering testimonies from pensioners and their families about residential care to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies as part of a review into older people’s quality of life in Welsh care homes. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, and will also consult providers, staff, and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both good and poor care and address unacceptable regional variations, ensuring decision-makers understand daily realities and enact necessary changes. Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but criticizes the exclusion of provider experts and people with direct care home experience from the main advisory panel, calling it a missed opportunity for partnership.

Harbro Group, an Aberdeenshire-based animal feed manufacturer with 19 Country Store retail outlets across Scotland, increased pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to June 2016 despite a £1m fall in turnover to just over £100m. The company reported growth in international sales in Europe and new markets, serves beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors, and its stores offer products for farming and rural communities. While noting recent challenges in agriculture and uncertainty around Brexit, the board expressed confidence in the group’s positioning for future business conditions.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden near Berkhamsted, and a man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are treating the death as murder and urgently want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), warning the public not to approach him. He is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight greying collar-length hair, average build, and was believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved button-down shirt. Police are asking for information via police or Crimestoppers and have increased patrols to reassure residents.

IMF deputy David Lipton warned that the global economy is weakening and at a “delicate juncture,” following data showing Chinese exports fell about 25% year-on-year; the IMF expects to downgrade its current 3.4% global growth forecast in April, signaling ongoing risks for businesses and industries tied to China’s growth.

At a council scrutiny meeting about problems with the new Cowes chain ferry, council leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings until 2 July to acknowledge issues and gather feedback, and ordered an auditor review after a “frustrating and disappointing” start marked by breakdowns, a grounding, MCA suspension over training, and vehicle damage. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth warned of severe business losses and asked about compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward said was under discussion. Ward called the ferry a prototype with expected teething problems, noted electrical issues had been fixed, ramp extensions were approved to prevent vehicle scraping, and said groundings linked to seamanship had been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred around 07:30 GMT on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man at the scene. Police arrested a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road between Thursley and Liphook was closed until early evening for investigations.

Matching Models, a London-based agency calling itself “an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” posted job ads specifying female appearance requirements—such as a PA with long brown hair and B–C cup and a “sexy female driver”—prompting condemnation from the Equality and Human Rights Commission as unlawful and demeaning, and from campaigners as sexist and outdated. Employment lawyer James Lynas said the ads are clearly unlawful under the Equality Act 2010, potentially discriminatory against older women, and could expose the firm to unlimited compensation claims, including from men rejected for sex discrimination. CEO Rebecca Hilsenrath said the EHRC will write to the agency to demand clarification of hiring practices; she urged modern, non-discriminatory standards. Agency founder Nathalie Jansen defended the focus on looks, citing client demands (e.g., a “Jackie O” look with specific cup size, or a blonde, blue-eyed Greek woman), and noted high-profile clients and thousands hired worldwide, while the agency’s website argues first impressions justify appearance-based criteria—claims at odds with legal prohibitions on discriminatory adverts and intrusive personal criteria unless essential to the job.

A rare school shooting in Bangalore occurred at a hostel of the private Pragati Residential School, where Mahesh, an office assistant, allegedly barged into 18-year-old Gautami’s room on Tuesday evening and fatally shot her, then shot another student, Sirisha, who was severely injured but is out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and remanded until 12 April; the motive remains unclear. India generally has strict gun control, and such incidents are uncommon, though a 2007 case near Delhi saw a 14-year-old shot dead by two students.

GLAAD’s “Where We Are on TV” study of scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series from June 2016 to May 2017 counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, including an increase in transgender characters from seven to 16. The report noted concern over the deaths of more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters, citing Poussey Washington (Orange is the New Black) and Bea Smith (Wentworth). It also found a record high percentage of Black characters on broadcast TV, driven by shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis called the progress heartening but emphasized that numbers are only part of the story.

Conservative MP David Mackintosh, representing Northampton South since 2015, announced he will not seek re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his deselection was likely, following criticism over a £10.25m loan from Northampton Borough Council—approved when he was council leader—to Northampton Town FC for stadium redevelopment, much of which is now missing and under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities; the stadium stand remains half-built, and while Mackintosh denies wrongdoing, a majority of the local executive had indicated they would vote to deselect him.

In April in Balch Springs, near Dallas, former police officer Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car of teenagers leaving a house party, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards; video contradicted initial police claims that the car had reversed toward officers, showing it driving away. Oliver was fired for policy violations, indicted for murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon (for the other teens, including two of Edwards’s brothers), and is free on bail with no trial date set. He faces 5 to 99 years in prison if convicted; a conviction would be the first murder conviction of a Dallas County officer since 1973. The Dallas County DA emphasized that justice is proceeding, while the family’s lawyer urged caution, noting Texas’s long history without convicting officers. Edwards’s coach remembered him as an exemplary player and person.

The passage discusses reactions to Melania Trump and son Barron delaying their move to the White House until his school year ends, noting social media criticism and support and placing the choice in historical context. Only two first ladies—Martha Washington and Anna Harrison—did not live in the White House, though variations existed, such as Frances Cleveland spending much time away. Historian William Seale notes children often finish school before moving, citing examples from the Tylers and Madisons, while recent first families like the Clintons and Obamas moved in by Inauguration Day, with the Obamas relocating early to avoid midterm disruption. The first lady’s role is ceremonial but influential; figures like Lou Hoover and Eleanor Roosevelt expanded its public dimension, while Nancy Reagan initially preferred privacy. Melania has emphasized prioritizing Barron and hinted at focusing on cyberbullying, raising speculation that Ivanka Trump might assume some duties, with precedents of family members helping. The White House adapts to each family’s needs, as shown by the Clintons’ and Obamas’ efforts to balance public roles with private family routines.

A 72-year-old man was later found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October; the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service has instructed the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, to investigate Police Scotland’s initial response to the man’s call, with Police Scotland fully engaging and a report to be submitted to COPFS in due course.

Forecasters issued a yellow wind warning for parts of Wales, predicting locally gusty winds up to 75 mph (120 km/h), with an unusual easterly direction likely to heighten impacts and cause travel disruption on roads and at sea. Affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts felled a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which the council expects to keep shut for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants beat the Panthers in a high-scoring game: after Derrick Walser’s short-handed opener and Jeff Dimmen’s equaliser, Mike Forney’s power-play breakaway made it 2-1 before Andy Bohmbach leveled again. Mike Radja restored the lead from a tight angle, James Desmarais extended it to 4-2, and Nottingham’s David Ling pulled one back. The teams play again Saturday in a double-header, with Nottingham leading the league on 28 points, Sheffield at 27, and Belfast at 25.

Nico Rosberg won a collision-strewn Chinese Grand Prix to extend his perfect start to the season, while Lewis Hamilton’s race unraveled after first-lap damage forced five pit stops, leaving him to salvage limited points and face a 36-point deficit with 18 races left. Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first-lap clash with Ferrari teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth behind Red Bull’s Daniil Kvyat (third) and Daniel Ricciardo (fourth); Vettel later confronted Kvyat over his aggressive dive, calling him a “torpedo.” Ricciardo briefly led from pole-sitter Rosberg before a puncture dropped him back, and Mercedes opted not to pit Rosberg under an early safety car, letting him pull away. Hamilton, hindered by further car damage from contact with Felipe Nasr and significant aerodynamic losses, could not match Ferrari’s recovery and now faces an uphill title fight, with history favoring drivers who win the opening three races.

Former Germany international Thomas Hitzlsperger came out as gay in a Die Zeit interview to spark discussion of a topic he says is ignored in German football, drawing widespread praise from players, officials, clubs, politicians, and public figures. Supporters included Lukas Podolski, Arne Friedrich, Bayern Munich, Gary Lineker, Joey Barton, John Amaechi, former DFB president Theo Zwanziger, Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball, and Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman, who called it a brave, important step against homophobia. The move is seen as a watershed in a sport still struggling with openness about sexuality, contrasting with past caution from figures like Philipp Lahm and recalling earlier limited disclosures such as Marcus Urban’s. Commentators expressed hope that Hitzlsperger’s announcement would embolden active players and help make sexual orientation a non-issue in football.

Steve Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances to help Brighton secure promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years and, with his contract expiring at season’s end, he hopes to sign a new deal. Brighton, recently promoted after beating Wigan and holding a four-point lead over Newcastle, aim to clinch the title in their final two matches. Sidwell, who played 19 games on loan in 2015-16 before a one-year deal in June 2016, believes his strong performances this season merit another contract and a return to the top flight, where he has previously played for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Nathan Delfouneso set up Jamille Matt to put Blackpool ahead after 12 minutes, but Colchester equalised five minutes later when Kurtis Guthrie prodded in from a corner after Sam Slocombe had made a superb save. Slocombe produced further brilliant stops, including from George Elokobi just before half-time, while Guthrie headed against the bar. Blackpool missed late chances, notably Tom Aldred heading wide unmarked, and Colchester finished with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in stoppage time. Multiple bookings were issued, and both sides had efforts saved or blocked in a competitive match.

A 29-year-old player named Reid, who made 37 appearances for Coventry City (the Sky Blues) last season when they were relegated from League One and has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, could debut for Colchester United in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa; Colchester began the season with a 3-1 loss at Accrington.

After PC Keith Palmer’s murder outside Parliament in March, momentum grew for a permanent UK Police Memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, to honor more than 1,400 officers and staff who have died on duty over the past 250 years. The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for £1.5m toward the project, which totals £4m, with the government committing £1m. Sir Hugh Orde emphasized the need for a national place of remembrance for families, colleagues, and the public. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out and given to families as personal tributes, and it is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United beat Sunderland 1-0 to stay 15 points clear at the top with eight games remaining, having set a record of 25 wins in their first 30 matches and earning 50 of the last 54 available league points. Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized focusing only on the next game—the upcoming derby against Manchester City, entered with a 15-point cushion—and noted United have a chance to surpass Chelsea’s 95-point record. He plans changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea after injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and a knock to David De Gea, with Wayne Rooney’s fitness to be assessed and Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez, and others available. Ferguson praised a strong first-half display and credited determined defending and courage for withstanding Sunderland’s second-half pressure.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt told the BBC the company has paid what is legally required—£10m in UK corporate taxes from 2006 to 2011—and that it is the UK government’s role to change tax laws if it wants firms to pay more. He emphasized taxes are not optional and Google will comply with any changes, while noting most UK sales are routed through Ireland. Amid criticism of multinationals’ tax arrangements, Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to scrutinize major firms’ tax practices, potentially taking evidence in secret. EU leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance via automatic information exchange. Schmidt has argued taxes should be levied where economic activity and risk occur, called for international tax reform, and urged politicians to set and defend clear, simple rules that law-abiding companies can follow.

NHS Improvement aims to cut the NHS agency staff bill by £1bn this financial year from last year’s £3.6bn, citing “promising” but insufficient progress. A pay cap introduced in October—limiting agency rates to no more than 55% above normal shift rates for most roles except senior managers—has saved £600m and seeks to reduce both costs and reliance on agencies. Trusts remain about 10% behind target, and it’s unclear if other pay costs (bank staff and overtime, not included in the figures) have risen. The regulator plans league tables of trusts’ agency spending and will collect data on the top 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust amid evidence of excessive quotes, such as £130/hour for a surgeon (cap £76) and £70/hour for a junior doctor (cap £35). CEO Jim Mackey warned the NHS cannot sustain high agency spending and more action is needed.

Longford’s empty, modern town centre symbolizes Ireland’s post–Celtic Tiger crash, but locals see tentative recovery. Shopkeeper Matt O’Brien reports business improving from a low base after diversifying into childrenswear and dress hire, though he previously cut staff and remains 30% below boom levels. Fianna Fáil criticizes the Fine Gael–Labour government’s regional policy, arguing water meter spending should go to broadband and noting the IDA hasn’t brought a client to Longford in over four years. The government cites a proposed €200m Center Parcs resort in Ballymahon, expected to create about 1,000 jobs by 2019 pending planning permission, with Fine Gael’s James Bannon touting the area’s scenic assets. Traders still want practical boosts like free parking to draw shoppers. Overall, the midlands show early signs of recovery but need further targeted support.

An eight-team tournament runs to a final on 29 May at the same stadium, with each team playing the others twice and the top four advancing to play-offs (Qualifier 1 on 24 May, Eliminator on 25 May, Qualifier 2 on 27 May, Final on 29 May). Current leaders: run-scorers Warner (294), Kohli (267), De Villiers (249); most sixes Warner (12), De Villiers (12), Kohli (8); highest innings De Kock (108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*); most wickets McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), Rahman (7). England players involved: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). Fixtures span 25 April–22 May with listed matchups, followed by the play-offs leading to the final. Scores, fixtures, and results are available via BBC Sport.

DEFRA reported a 200 million rise in plastic carrier bag use since 2013, highlighting environmental harm as many non-recyclable bags are discarded and pollute landfills and rivers. To curb this, England will introduce a 5p charge for plastic bags from October to promote reuse. Similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have reduced bag usage, and campaigners expect England’s fee to cut waste and benefit the environment.

High winds across Wales led to widespread disruption, including part of a school roof torn off in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, power cuts to hundreds of homes, train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and ferry cancellations. A yellow wind warning was in place until midnight Friday, coinciding with one of the busiest pre-Christmas travel days. The strongest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey. Irish Ferries canceled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, Arriva Trains Wales imposed speed restrictions between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead, and the National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge were later lifted as winds eased Friday evening. A blustery Christmas weekend forecast also prompted postponement of Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip to Tuesday, 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan said he was “super excited” to join Black Panther and hinted at a different spin on his role without giving details; the film reunites him with Creed director Ryan Coogler, and he expressed enthusiasm about working with Lupita Nyong’o, an Oscar winner for 12 Years a Slave who also played Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, and Chadwick Boseman, then starring as Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War. Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the poorly received 2015 Fantastic Four reboot. Black Panther is slated for release in February 2018.

Alexandra Palace’s east wing is undergoing a £26.6m restoration to create a new cultural destination, including refurbishing the 1875 theatre for performances, cinema, comedy, and live music, and repairing the BBC studios; the glazed east court will become a public and exhibition space. Funding includes £18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8m from Haringey Council, and a final £1m to be raised by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust by summer 2017, with hopes to reopen the theatre in 2018. The long-unused theatre retains much of its original decor and stage machinery, reflecting its historic role hosting opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema.

James Milner, 30, has retired from England duty after earning 61 senior caps since his 2009 debut, featuring in squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but playing only three minutes at Euro 2016; he wished Sam Allardyce and the team well, holds the record with 46 England Under-21 caps since 2004, and scored his sole senior international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, escaped a fast-moving house fire after her young son David, awake on FaceTime with his father, spotted the flames and alerted them; although the house was destroyed and their dog and cats died, the community has supported them with donations. Smith believes the fire started from rubbish burned in their wood stove, a routine she’d done many times, and noted their fire alarm did not go off. She credits David with saving their lives and vows to ensure he understands the significance of his actions.

Reports suggested an energy drinks company was considering a £200m bid for West Ham United, a club valued at £105m when David Sullivan and David Gold acquired a majority stake in 2010; they now own over 85%. Since moving to London Stadium in August, the club has also been linked with Qatari and Chinese takeover interest. Sullivan previously indicated a minority stake might be sold to reduce debt, but he and Gold plan to keep ownership within their families.

At a lively, fan-voted awards show in Los Angeles, The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking best movie, while Shailene Woodley earned best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with Ansel Elgort, dedicating her speech to author John Green. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, Channing Tatum took best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods; other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers co-stars. The event doubled as promotion for upcoming films, showing clips from Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron, with Zac Efron again winning best shirtless performance.

St Mirren have signed 21-year-old Cammy Smith on loan from Dundee United, where he had been since July and scored five goals this season; a Scotland U21 international, Smith debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and netted four times in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie club. Manager Jack Ross called him a “brilliant acquisition,” praising his maturity and fit for the team’s attacking options. Championship bottom side St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that warmer weather allows its Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, targeting about 145 fixes per day over the next four months, and that additional staff will repair rain-damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016 on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland, six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (alpha radiation) while removing pipework during a shutdown. Innes said they had worked without proper PPE, were informed partway through the trip, and now fear cancer, with ongoing blood tests; he claims EnQuest failed in its duty of care and that his raising concerns has hurt his employment. EnQuest stated exposure was under 1% of the threshold requiring HSE reporting, yet it notified HSE, investigated, and implemented additional precautions. Wood Group downmanned staff for medical assessments and supported a joint investigation, emphasizing safety. The Unite union criticized the workers’ treatment and called for transparency. HSE confirmed awareness but said the event was not reportable under RIDDOR and no investigation was conducted.

Singapore’s Asian Civilisation Museum bought a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later confessed to selling looted Indian antiquities. Although there is no conclusive proof the piece was stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, allegations surfaced during a 2012 trafficking case, and after the Archaeological Survey of India officially requested its return in May, the museum decided to repatriate it. The ACM had purchased 30 objects from the dealer; none of the others are believed stolen, though the ASI was allowed to inspect them. The museum plans legal action to seek compensation for apparent fraud.

A magnitude 4.8 earthquake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) at a depth of 15.5 km with an epicentre in Garfagnana, about 35 km north of Lucca, and was felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena; there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, though phone lines and power were cut in the Garfagnana area, aftershocks occurred, and schools were evacuated for checks. In Lucca, people fled into the streets. The INGV described the quake as medium-strong and fairly shallow. The region is seismically active: two quakes last May in the same area killed over 20 people, and Italy is still dealing with the aftermath of the 2009 L’Aquila disaster that killed nearly 300 and led to the 2012 conviction of six scientists and an ex-official for giving falsely reassuring risk assessments prior to that quake.

On 8 September 2016, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, Austin Grant, who had doubted South Yorkshire’s climate was suitable, finally saw success growing a fruit that remains attached to the plant and not yet ripe, prompting him to say he was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar delayed the release of Grand Theft Auto V on PC from 27 January to 24 March to allow extra testing and polish, stating the decision is in the best interests of the game and fans. Online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch. New PC screenshots promise higher detail, with Los Santos and Blaine County running at 1080p/60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitors; minimum PC specs have been published so players can prepare. GTA V originally launched on 17 September 2013 and became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, earning $1bn in three days.

A 76-year-old artist, previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for Squint (19), a roughly 7ft-high painting depicting a medieval “leper squint” that allowed marginalized people to view church services. Judge Ansel Krut praised the work as technically subtle, minimal, and emotionally resonant, calling it “quite extraordinary” despite being “difficult to look at.” The artist chose this piece for its manageable size and familiarity within an ongoing series and plans to spend the prize money on quality materials. Established in 1957, the biennial prize is one of Britain’s oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig; Sir Peter Blake, now patron, won the junior title in 1961.

Two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked almost simultaneously at night by masked assailants, with no casualties reported. Four masked attackers targeted the Yeni Safak building, causing a fire that was quickly extinguished; both sites suffered shattered windows from gunfire, and police found numerous spent bullet casings. The areas were cordoned off, and authorities are pursuing the perpetrators, though no group has claimed responsibility. Both papers support President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s AK Party, and the incidents follow a September attack by pro-government protesters on the Hurriyet daily over alleged misquoting of Erdogan.

A 24-year-old player under contract with the Stags is joining Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer, officially on January 1, becoming Bignot’s first signing; he previously spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, and is a former Burton player.

Arsene Wenger, whose club contract runs until the summer, praised interim England manager Gareth Southgate’s competency and experience, saying Southgate has a good opportunity to earn the role permanently through upcoming matches against Scotland (11 November) and Spain (15 November), while deflecting questions about his own links to the England job. Wenger also said Arsenal will offer 21-year-old right-back Hector Bellerin a new contract despite transfer speculation from Barcelona and Manchester City, insisting Bellerin’s long-term future is at Arsenal. Additionally, he confirmed midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury sustained on 14 August.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday, prompting a joint investigation by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive, with the company cooperating fully.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that will return two freight vessels, Hellier and Hildasay, from Seatruck to Serco Northlink next month, resolving a dispute over low seafarer pay highlighted by the RMT union. Seatruck had argued the UK minimum wage didn’t apply to many non-UK crew, while Serco Northlink said it had offered to cover and backdate the pay gap. Yousaf said, pending final financial and regulatory details, the new charter will ensure all crew are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, which holds a six-year £243m contract awarded in 2012 to operate heavily subsidized Northern Isles routes, runs three ferries and two cargo boats.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole following a drunken confrontation involving his partner and her son, Jamie Mitchell, 35. Mitchell had intervened in an argument between Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57, after they all drank at a holiday park bar on 7 May. Members of the public separated the men; Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault related to the fight. Both Jamie and Samantha Mitchell admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about the events, later acknowledging Jamie’s intervention led to what he called a “tragic accident.” Jamie reacted emotionally as a jury delivered its verdict at Winchester Crown Court, and both are due to be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter famed for penning Michael Jackson hits including Thriller, Rock With You, Off the Wall, Baby Be Mine, and The Lady in My Life, died in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer, with a private funeral held. Born in Cleethorpes, he rose from a factory job to join disco group Heatwave, writing Boogie Nights, Always & Forever, and Groove Line, which led Quincy Jones to recruit him for Jackson’s albums. His work helped make Thriller the best-selling U.S. album, and his songs were recorded by artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. Temperton won a 1990 Grammy for Birdland on Quincy Jones’s Back on the Block and earned two 1986 Oscar nominations for The Color Purple. Known as “The Invisible Man” for his low profile, he credited early radio for shaping his craft and advocated writing songs that move the writer first. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, and others, while his family requested privacy.

Researchers including Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott helped uncover over 450 large geometric earthworks (“geoglyphs”) in Acre, western Brazilian Amazon, likely around 2,000 years old. Excavations suggest these ditched enclosures were not villages or defenses but sporadically used ritual gathering sites, though unlike Maya pyramids they were probably not visible above the canopy. Analyses of phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes indicate construction amid taller vegetation, minimal large-scale burning, and long-term human shaping of forests over 6,000 years by favoring economically valuable trees (e.g., palms). This challenges the notion of a pristine pre-Columbian Amazon and points to ancient agroforestry practices whose biodiversity legacy may persist in Acre’s forests today.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career-high No. 12, defeated world No. 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the Shanghai Masters second round, days after winning the Japan Open and nearing the top 10. He said he felt tired and subdued due to travel, poor sleep, and the long commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium, aiming simply to “get the job done.” The tournament was notable for him last year when he was fined $1,500 for calling it a “circus.”

Charities, medical organizations, and researchers in Wales are urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination to boys to reduce rising head and neck cancers linked to the sexually transmitted virus, noting that cases increasingly affect younger, mostly male, non-smoking patients with an average age of 55. While girls aged 12–13 have been routinely vaccinated since 2008, with 85% coverage in Wales, advocates argue that vaccinating boys would address HPV’s role in about 5% of global cancers. The Welsh government says it is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before considering changes to the programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School pupil and Rangers fan, died from the rare gamma delta T-cell lymphoma after documenting his illness and upbeat journey on the widely followed “Jak’s Journey” Facebook page. Despite severe decline—learning on 23 January that his cancer had spread and further treatment would stop—he continued sharing milestones, including a brief 10-minute appearance at a prom held in his honor, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. His family announced his death on Facebook and collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. Throughout his illness he received visits from sports teams and performers, enjoyed special outings, and inspired fundraising for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, with more funds expected from a charity football match at Livingston FC’s Energy Assets Arena.

Egypt beat Uganda 1-0 in a largely drab Group D match on a poor Port-Gentil pitch, with Abdallah El Said scoring in the 89th minute from a Mohamed Salah assist after Uganda had an earlier Joseph Ochaya goal rightly ruled offside. The result keeps top spot in Group D undecided ahead of Egypt’s meeting with Ghana on Wednesday, while Uganda are eliminated from their first AFCON since 1978; Ghana had already qualified for the quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Mali. Uganda next face Mali, who need a win and for Ghana to beat Egypt by two or more goals to advance.

Lancashire County Council has chosen land at the former Glenburn Sports College and the unused Skelmersdale College Westbank campus as the preferred site for a new Skelmersdale railway station, following a Network Rail study comparing these sites with one near the Concourse shopping centre. Working with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, the plan could provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. Councillor John Fillis called it an exciting step, noting the site’s capacity for future expansion and good transport connectivity. The council will begin acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale’s original station closed in 1956; designated a new town in 1961, it remains one of the largest North West towns without a station.
Police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house during a Saturday morning search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old woman was found late Sunday with severe injuries after reportedly being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was airlifted to a specialist clinic. Her 38-year-old ex-partner from nearby Bad Muender later surrendered to authorities and is in custody. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive remains unknown, and police have secured the area and appealed for witnesses.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin analyzing 4,600 workers from Australia’s 2013–14 workplace relations survey found that women are as likely as men to ask for pay rises but are 25% less likely to receive them when comparing like-for-like full-time and part-time workers; the results, controlling for employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications, showed no support for the “reticent female” theory or fears of upsetting bosses, suggesting an element of discrimination.
