The researchers noted that under-40 men and women ask for and receive raises at similar rates, indicating possible generational change, with co-author Dr. Amanda Goodall highlighting that younger women appear to negotiate more successfully than older women.

Oxford City Council has spent funds on ground investigations for new burial sites but found none suitable due to issues like site size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants. The remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. After that, only reopening family plots, using a few reserved plots, and interring ashes will be possible. Despite ongoing efforts, the council says suitable land within Oxford has effectively run out, and the last expansion of burial space occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) is introducing an augmented reality app that lets visitors scan signs and posters to access videos, band interviews, ticket purchasing, and other information on phones and tablets; content will be updated before and during the event, enabling both attendees and people worldwide to experience the festival’s atmosphere. This year’s acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage shortly after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Veterinary staff treated him on course before pronouncing him dead, and the British Horseracing Authority emphasized such incidents are rare and can occur without underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had previously shown post-race overheating and ataxia, he displayed no such symptoms on the day, and the report concluded his death was due to the rare haemorrhage rather than prior issues. The gelding, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, was a notable winner of the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, with trainer Oliver Sherwood calling him the “horse of a lifetime.”

At Portsmouth Crown Court, Davina (formerly David) Ayrton, now 34 and with learning difficulties, was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004 while two others slept nearby; the victim testified she resisted and clearly recalled the events after minimal alcohol. Ayrton, who changed her name in 2012 and has made no physical or medical gender transitions, denied the charge but will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely to a male prison in Winchester with special protocols due to self-harm risk and risk of absconding, noting the case was unusual. In 2014, Ayrton disclosed the assault to a care home worker.

Serbia’s doubles team lost 6-4, 6-4 to Brazil’s Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a day after Novak Djokovic was eliminated from singles by Juan Martin del Potro. Earlier, Djokovic, 29 and ranked world number one with 12 Grand Slam titles, had a shock third-round Wimbledon exit to Sam Querrey, but rebounded to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

An event in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms will feature over 20 competitors who must use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human figures, with entrants regularly coming from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US; last year’s champion, Pete Bowsher of Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Wales scrum-half Rhys Webb, out since a serious foot injury in a September World Cup warm-up, says he is close to returning and aims to be fit for the Six Nations in February, possibly a couple of weeks earlier with physios’ approval. He is currently in a pre-season-style training phase and will assess progress weekly. Wales open their Six Nations away to Ireland on 7 February. Webb, capped 16 times, has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to remain with his home region to strengthen his prospects of playing for Wales.

US border agents disrupted an alleged ecstasy smuggling attempt from Canada to San Francisco near Sumas, Washington, encountering two men with backpacks containing 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA. One suspect, Nathan Hall, allegedly fired at agents and fled before being arrested in British Columbia; the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately detained. A California driver’s license with the name William Nickerson but Hall’s photo was found in a backpack. Investigators later arrested Kali Henifin, accused of planning to pick up the men, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who allegedly expected $11,000 to transport the drugs to San Francisco; Henifin reportedly said they were monitoring police radio on a phone and left after hearing of a shooting. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy and drug charges. Authorities note the wooded area east of a highway crossing is a known route for drug and firearms smuggling, and such cases are a significant part of federal prosecutions in the district.

Childline reports a sharp rise in counselling for online bullying, from about 2,400 cases in 2011–12 to over 4,500 in the past year, with actual numbers likely far higher; victims include children as young as seven describing torment that affects their willingness to attend school. The NSPCC says online trolls inflict widespread misery and humiliation, and Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen calls the figures a wake-up call, stressing that cyberbullying follows children home and worsens without intervention. She urges parents, teachers, and schools to take the problem seriously and ensure children seek help. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, led by the Anti-Bullying Alliance, which is working with families, schools, and organizations to address the issue. A young caller’s account illustrates the severity, including being told to kill themselves and feeling unsupported by parents who underestimate the impact.

Ahead of a major speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry and following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office, Jerusalem’s planning committee postponed a vote to authorize 492 new homes in the Ramat Shlomo and Ramot settlements to avoid further straining ties with Washington. The move came after the US abstained on a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction as illegal and an obstacle to peace, which Israel rejected. Netanyahu accused the Obama administration of helping draft the resolution—an allegation the US denied—and retaliated diplomatically by summoning US and other ambassadors, recalling envoys, cutting aid to Senegal, and canceling a Ukrainian PM visit. Over 500,000 Israelis live in settlements in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem, whose status remains disputed; Palestinians seek East Jerusalem as their future capital. Kerry is expected to outline his vision for peace and counter Israeli critiques, while Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution supports a planned French peace conference on 15 January.

On the eve of Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday, Prince William told the BBC she is a “guiding example” of monarchy, praising her duty, service, and commitment, while addressing “work-shy” criticisms by stressing he takes responsibility seriously and will assume greater duties in time with family support. Celebrations include the release of ten Royal Mail stamps—featuring a four-generation portrait with the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George—her visit to Windsor’s Royal Mail office marking 500 years of the postal service, opening a new bandstand, and community singing. On her birthday, she and Prince Philip will walk Windsor, unveil The Queen’s Walkway, and light a beacon to start a chain of 900 worldwide; the Obamas will join her for lunch at Windsor the following day. Political leaders praised her service, while the group Republic criticized the BBC’s coverage as disproportionate.

West Ham United beat Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup, securing control before half-time with quick goals from Diafra Sakho—his first since November, set up by Sam Byram—and Andre Ayew, both finishing into the same bottom corner. Cheltenham, unchanged from a 3-0 league loss to Carlisle, had their best chance when Harry Pell’s low volley flashed across goal with Dan Holman unable to connect, and also went close through Pell’s volley and Jordon Forster’s header. West Ham, who made seven changes after Premier League defeats, could have won by more, with Kyle Storer clearing Angelo Ogbonna’s header off the line and Jonathan Flatt denying Sakho from Ayew’s cross. The result mirrored West Ham’s previous narrow win over Cheltenham at the same stage four years earlier and ended League Two’s representation before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion after Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, turned his VW Transporter right and failed to see McNicholl’s motorcycle. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim’s family opposed a jail sentence, viewing it as a momentary lapse, and Werner expressed remorse without offering an explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall who fought in Syria with the IS-affiliated Rayat al Tawheed under the name Abu Daigham al-Britani, became a prominent masked propagandist posting slick videos, appeals for donations, and gruesome images—including one showing him holding a bag containing a severed head—aimed at recruiting young British Muslims. Monitored by MI5, he attempted to return to the UK in June after faking his death online; his cousin Tahir Bhatti drove to Bulgaria to collect him, and both were arrested at Dover. Police describe Khawaja as a dangerous, trained extremist who concealed his return; held in Belmarsh’s high-risk unit, he has admitted four offences, while Bhatti pleaded guilty to assisting an offender. Khawaja faces up to life imprisonment; an additional charge of soliciting to murder will lie on file.

Kayden Jackson, 22, who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season and turned down a new contract there, has become Barnsley’s third signing for next season ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley, with caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praising his pace and attacking style as a good fit for the team.

Detergent bottles, believed to have spilled from a container lost overboard during stormy weather—possibly from the MV Blue Ocean near Land’s End in May—have washed up at Poldhu Cove and nearby Cornish beaches, prompting National Trust-led cleanups and monitoring by local authorities and agencies. While most bottles are sealed, some have leaked, raising concerns from Cornwall Wildlife Trust about risks to sensitive marine life. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency says links to the MV Blue Ocean are only circumstantial, and Vanish has not commented. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away and not to attempt recovery of any bottles.

A crash on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00 resulted in several minor injuries, led to the road’s closure with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale–Melvich route, and is under ongoing investigation by Police Scotland.

French centre-back Dorian Dervite, 28, has signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers after making 14 appearances last season that helped the club finish second in League One and earn promotion. Joined from Charlton in 2014, he has 83 appearances in all competitions for Bolton. Manager Phil Parkinson praised his late-season impact, and Dervite’s renewal follows new deals for David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan as Bolton prepare for the Championship.

After jointly defeating the government in the Lords on EU citizens’ rights and requiring parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, Labour and the Liberal Democrats split when MPs overturned those amendments: Lib Dems pushed to keep insisting, while Labour deferred to the Commons. Lib Dem Lord Oates and Baroness Ludford accused Labour of conceding to a “hard Brexit,” while Labour’s Baroness Smith and a party source said the Lib Dems were grandstanding and giving “false hope” to worried EU citizens. Despite past cooperation on issues like higher education and housing, Labour predicts lingering tensions, whereas the Lib Dems say they will still work across parties where they agree, with both sides expecting relations to remain business-like.

The passage outlines how UK defence has become a low electoral priority despite rising global instability, with public combat fatigue and parties offering sparse manifesto detail. UK forces have been significantly reduced (Army to 82,000; Royal Navy to 19 warships; RAF to seven or eight fast jet squadrons), creating capability gaps such as lacking Maritime Patrol Aircraft. UK defence spending has fallen from fourth to sixth globally and is likely to drop below NATO’s 2% GDP target to around 1.7–1.5% by decade’s end, straining credibility with the US. With major parties aiming to cut the deficit and not protecting defence, the MoD’s £34bn budget faces further pressure, though some parties’ stances (notably UKIP and Conservative pledges on Trident, equipment budget growth, and army size) limit room for savings. Trident renewal is a major, divisive cost (four submarines, at least £20bn), with Conservatives and UKIP backing like-for-like replacement, Labour examining a three-sub CASD, Lib Dems proposing a non-CASD deterrent, and SNP/Greens opposing it. New aircraft carriers risk becoming a “hollow force” due to crew and F-35 shortfalls (12 jets planned vs capacity 36), underscoring the challenge of sustaining Britain’s traditional claim to punch above its weight.

Barcelona insisted it committed no offense in Neymar’s transfer but made an additional tax payment of €13.55m to cover differing interpretations of the contracts, while maintaining its original tax compliance. The club initially stated it paid €57m (£48.6m) for Neymar, though allegations and investigations suggest the true cost, including fees to his parents and other expenses, totals about £106.8m. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid related accusations, which he denies, and a Spanish judge has allowed investigations to proceed; it is unclear if Barcelona’s payment will end the case. Neymar, 22, has scored seven goals in 18 league games and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

A 27-year-old Nottingham man, Michael Luciw, died when the van he was riding in was hit by a Mazda traveling the wrong way on a Leicestershire motorway; the Mazda’s driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, also died. Luciw’s grieving family and the injured van driver, Andy Harrington, called for stricter checks on older drivers—such as regular driving tests or medical examinations—arguing some retirees should not be on the road. Currently, UK drivers over 70 renew licenses via a self-assessment form every three years without mandatory medicals or driving tests. The DVLA says evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents and has no plans to restrict licensing by age, while Age UK emphasizes supporting older people to drive safely to maintain independence.

Amid widespread concerns over debilitating complications from transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and prolapse, Scotland’s health secretary confirmed continued implementation of an independent review’s recommendations—avoiding routine use for prolapse, ensuring patients are offered a range of treatments with full information, and making adverse event reporting mandatory—while noting the government cannot impose a ban, which is the UK regulator’s power. After two patient members and a consultant resigned over claims the final report was watered down and sections removed, independent expert Alison Britton was appointed to review how the report’s conclusions were reached and identify lessons. The review’s chair, Tracey Gillies, apologized for failing to secure consensus amid intense division, facing public criticism during evidence. Over 20,000 Scottish women have received mesh or tape implants in the past two decades, with some suffering severe complications, and more than 400 women are pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old indoor 5,000m British record by 14 seconds with 14:49.12 at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena. Despite McColgan initially questioning whether the mixed-race setup and procedures met UK Athletics criteria—such as being a “genuine race” and potential drug testing—British Athletics said the time is expected to be ratified, noting no doping control is required for record recognition if none is conducted at the event. McColgan praised Muir’s performance and potential, suggesting she could run closer to 14:30 and contend for world medals, and drew parallels to her own solo record run, adding it was a bonus that a fellow Scot surpassed her mark. Muir previously broke the British 1500m record in Paris and made the Rio 2016 Olympic 1500m final.

Jung won gold riding Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou’s July infection; France’s Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton bronze. Great Britain’s William Fox-Pitt, returning 10 months after an induced coma from a fall, led after dressage on Chilli Morning but dropped to 21st due to cross-country time penalties and finished 12th despite a faultless final show-jumping round. Ireland’s Jonty Evans placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray, 30, defeated 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 in two hours 39 minutes, clinching match point at 20:57 BST to reach Wimbledon’s last 16 for the 11th time, where he will face Benoit Paire on Monday; after a fluctuating match marked by fading light, Fognini’s temper and a point penalty, and Murray’s complaints over slow play, the Italian led 5-2 in the fourth and held five set points to force a decider, but Murray saved them and won five straight games to close it out, later noting he didn’t move as well as earlier rounds but was pleased to finish in four, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time with a 6-4 6-1 win over Maria Sakkari.

After paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, police found people still on the premises and till receipts showing alcohol served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar closed for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing consumption of alcohol outside licensing hours; O’Neill faced two counts and Thomas one. The defense acknowledged lax adherence to licensing laws and that the bar operated into the morning. The judge condemned O’Neill’s “appalling record,” lamented the lack of power to impose custody, and imposed fines of £3,000 on O’Neill and £1,000 on Thomas.

Ulster Unionist leader Mike Nesbitt, launching the party’s ‘Real Partnership’ manifesto, framed the election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and broader “incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption,” while defending his call for voters to back UUP first and then transfer to candidates they trust—stressing he would prefer partnering with the SDLP over Sinn Féin in government. Despite public distancing by colleague Danny Kennedy, Nesbitt said he stood by his comments, reported strong support on the doors in unionist areas, and argued attention would return to RHI losses and the DUP–Sinn Féin record. The manifesto prioritizes cutting waiting lists, raising PSNI numbers to 7,500, delivering the York Street interchange, supporting LGBT rights, and ensuring no group is worse off from Brexit, alongside proposals to “clean up Stormont.”

Justice Minister Claire Sugden will bring a motion to Northern Ireland’s assembly to introduce pardons for men convicted under now-abolished sexual offences, aligning with England and Wales’ “Turing’s Law.” The proposal provides both posthumous pardons and a process for living gay and bisexual men to apply, aiming to ensure equal treatment and address past injustices more quickly than an assembly bill. She has secured executive agreement, and the legislative consent motion will now go to the assembly for consideration.

Laura Muir, 23, set a Scottish mile record with 4:19.12, finishing second to Kenya’s Faith Kipyegon and surpassing Yvonne Murray’s 1994 mark of 4:22.60; the time places Muir second on the UK all-time list behind Zola Budd’s 4:17.57. Already the Scottish 1500m record holder and fifth at last year’s World Championships, Muir expressed delight at the record and her form, noting it was her first race of the season at the distance and that training is going well. Congratulated by Murray via her husband, she aims to earn a Rio Olympics spot at the British trials in Birmingham (24–26 June), after opening her season with an 800m win in Montbéliard and planning a 1500m race in Stockholm, all while balancing training with her veterinary studies, having completed her fourth year of vet school.
The passage presents photos from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as “most excellent” for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that Russian suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko and that the Russian state likely sponsored the 2006 poisoning, citing polonium-210 as indicating state involvement, though not necessarily by President Putin. Litvinenko, 43, who defected to the UK in 2000 after accusing the FSB of corruption and murder and who had attacked Putin personally, died nearly three weeks after drinking contaminated tea during a meeting with the suspects. Horwell said Litvinenko was poisoned twice, the suspects left a “trail of polonium,” and had no credible answer to the scientific evidence; risks to the public from radiation exposure remain unknown. Extradition attempts have failed, the men remain in Russia, Kovtun did not give evidence, and while police wanted a murder trial, it is now unlikely; the inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed Australia’s Test captain following Michael Clarke’s retirement after the Ashes defeat, adding to his existing roles leading the one-day side and captaining the Twenty20 team in injured Aaron Finch’s absence; David Warner, 28, has been named vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and suitability, noting his prior experience captaining three Tests against India, and highlighted Warner’s maturation despite past disciplinary issues. Smith, a New South Welshman with 32 Tests and 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66, and Warner will also lead Australia in the limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test starting 20 August at the Oval.

Tim Farron, newly elected Liberal Democrat leader, repeatedly refused to say whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, instead stating “we are all sinners,” while emphasizing he is passionate about LGBT+ rights. He pledged to prioritize defending and extending equal marriage, specifically citing the need to address the “spousal veto” that limits transgender people’s marital rights. Questioned about his 2007 vote against the Equality Bill, he said the Lib Dems had tabled an amendment over concerns about protecting individual liberties; after it was defeated, he voted against the bill, while maintaining he supports equal legal access for all regardless of sexuality.

After Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, cutting 450 jobs, Accord Healthcare will take over the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi employees. The company expects the investment to have an extremely positive local impact, a view echoed by Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes, who said it boosts the region’s science and healthcare reputation and economy. Accord, a global pharmaceutical player, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to about 60 countries.

A local authority announced that Richard Ellis, former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, will leave on Friday at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan (head of the chief executive’s office) and Ewan Sutherland (head of human resources and customer services) are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn said the exits reflect the council’s difficulty retaining senior staff and predicted more departures, while council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

Gunmen from the so-called Islamic State attacked Kabul’s 400-bed Sardar Daud hospital, entering after an explosion at the gate and shooting staff and patients; more than 50 were wounded before Afghan special forces killed all four attackers after a six-hour operation. IS claimed responsibility and shared images via Amaq, while the Taliban denied involvement. Officials, including President Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah, condemned the assault, noting that hospitals are protected sites. This marks a shift for IS in Kabul from targeting civilian gatherings to directly confronting security forces using tactics resembling the Taliban, suggesting increased resources and training and raising fears of more such attacks. Since declaring a Khorasan Province in 2015, IS has conducted multiple deadly attacks in Afghanistan and Pakistan, while Afghan forces claim gains in the east but have not dislodged IS from mountainous strongholds.

English rider Guy Martin, who crashed at this year’s TT and has faced mechanical problems with Honda’s Fireblade, clarified he hasn’t quit racing but has no plans to do more road racing on Hondas this year. He skipped the North West 200 after team-mate John McGuinness’s practice crash and will also miss the Ulster Grand Prix. Calling the TT a disaster and feeling like a test rider, Martin said post-Cadwell testing showed the bike wouldn’t be competitive at the Ulster, and the team withdrew him without informing him directly. He says he has no unfinished business and aims to race classics and unconventional events instead.

Nigeria’s ruling landscape shifted as the All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared governorships, handing the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) its biggest defeat since 1999 and reinforcing its loss of last month’s presidential election to Muhammadu Buhari, who is to be inaugurated on 29 May. The PDP lost key northern states including Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, though it retained Rivers and won eight governorships largely in the south-east; Taraba’s result was pending and Imo’s was inconclusive, with elections not held in seven states. The APC also kept Lagos, giving the incoming president control of the commercial hub for the first time in the multiparty era, but it failed to capture any of the five oil-producing states, raising concerns over managing militant disruptions and oil revenues. The polls saw 66 violent incidents, particularly in southern states, yet were more peaceful than previous cycles. Analysts say the PDP, weakened by defections, corruption allegations, and its handling of the Boko Haram insurgency, has been reduced to a regional party and must rebuild under new leadership as voters signaled a desire for change.

A Mighty report accuses Singapore-based trader Olam and majority shareholder Temasek of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices—allegedly sourcing from unknown or “rogue” suppliers—that may contribute to Southeast Asia’s haze, and of clearing forests in Gabon; both firms reject the claims. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third parties and holds under 1% of the global market, says it enforces a “no burn-no peat-no deforestation” policy, has now disclosed 14 suppliers, and will remove noncompliant producers, though full vetting will take years. Temasek denies involvement in Olam’s operations, supports no-burn policies, and says governance rests with Olam’s board. The controversy reflects wider industry tensions over deforestation, labor abuses, and the difficulty of policing third-party supply chains, amid governments balancing environmental standards with rural economic benefits. Olam defends its Gabon ventures as responsible, transparent conversions of limited, low-value forest land.

A restaurant began serving “puppy platters” after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they are outdoors; this update was reported on 27 August 2016 at 12:34 BST, and a clip showcases the dog-friendly meals, humorously described as a “dog’s dinner.”

Forward Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee issue after only featuring from the bench in the last two games; Derby’s David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing the draw with Huddersfield; and midfielder Jacob Butterfield is pushing for a recall after coming off the bench to score a late equalizer against the Terriers.

Pakistan lifted its YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version, with the PTA directing ISPs to restore access and the IT ministry noting a new process for the PTA to request blocking of “offending” material for users in Pakistan. While many young Pakistanis welcomed the move, activists called for transparency about the terms with Google. YouTube denied allowing authorities to filter content, stating removals follow its community guidelines, and that locally illegal videos may be restricted after review, with government requests logged in its Transparency Report. The original ban was imposed in 2012 after the film “Innocence of Muslims” sparked deadly protests; Google also recently launched local YouTube versions in Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Liberian FA boss Musa Bility demands that Domenico Scala, head of FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee and a Swiss-Italian like candidate Gianni Infantino, step down from overseeing the presidential election or face a challenge at the Court of Arbitration for Sport, citing Article 7.4 on conflicts of interest; he notes Scala and Claudio Sulser previously withdrew in 2015 due to shared nationality with candidate and incumbent Sepp Blatter. Scala’s spokesman counters that sharing nationality with a candidate does not constitute a conflict under FIFA regulations and that Scala stepped aside in 2015 only to avoid the appearance of bias because the Swiss candidate was the sitting president; with five non-incumbent candidates now—Prince Ali, Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale—there is no conflict. Bility, who was barred from running after failing eligibility checks and has endorsed Prince Ali, presses for Scala’s withdrawal before the 26 February Zurich vote by FIFA’s 209 members, citing the need for fairness after FIFA’s turmoil.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint-spraying area at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, a company that makes digger buckets. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been conducted, and Det Ch Insp Paul Durham reported significant progress with forensics and witness statements, indicating a flashover explosion likely caused by a build-up of toxic fumes ignited to create a fireball. The Health and Safety Executive, along with electrical safety experts, is gathering evidence.

Tunisia narrowly avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to Caf for a post-match complaint over a controversial penalty in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea; the Tunisia FA denied alleging corruption but criticized the referee’s appointment, and a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou resolved the dispute. Morocco, initially banned for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns, had their suspension overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which also cut their fine from $1m to $50,000, enabling them to enter 2017 qualifying. In the 2017 qualifiers, Tunisia were drawn with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti (Group A), and Morocco with Cape Verde, Libya, and São Tomé (Group F); if Tunisia qualify for the finals in Gabon, it would mark a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

After Chelsea’s 3-1 win at the Etihad, a mass fracas in the 95th minute led to charges, with Manchester City’s Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho sent off while Cesc Fabregas faced no further action. Pep Guardiola apologized for City’s role. Aguero received a four-match ban for a high, late challenge on David Luiz—his second violent conduct dismissal of the season—and Fernandinho was banned three matches for clashing with Fabregas in the ensuing scuffle. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

Cymru a rhannau eraill o’r DU sydd â rhai o’r cyfraddau goroesi canser gwaethaf yn lansio cynlluniau peilot yng Nghwm Cynon ac yn Ysbyty Castell-nedd Port Talbot i gyflymu diagnosis i gleifion heb symptomau brys clir, gan fabwysiadu model canolfannau diagnostig a welwyd yn Nenmarc. Yn ardal Cwm Taf, dim ond 35% o gleifion â symptomau pryderus sy’n cael diagnosis ar hyn o bryd, ac mae oedi oherwydd atgyfeiriadau lluosog a phrofion araf yn golygu bod triniaeth yn dechrau’n hwyr. O dan y peilot chwe mis, bydd 40 o feddygon teulu yng Nghwm Cynon yn gallu atgyfeirio cleifion i ganolfan ddiagnostig yn Ysbyty Brenhinol Morgannwg o fewn saith diwrnod, gyda thua chwe chlaf yr wythnos yn cael profion lluosog yn un diwrnod, gan gynnig sicrwydd i gleifion a chyflymu diagnosis. Datblygwyd y treialon yn ystod y flwyddyn ers ymweliad ag Aarhus, a bydd llwyddiant yn arwain at ehangu’r gwasanaeth i fyrddau iechyd eraill.

England leveled the series with a dominant win over Pakistan at Old Trafford, declaring at 589-8 and 173-1 to secure their second-biggest runs victory over Pakistan after bowling the tourists out for 198 and 234. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for a career-best 254 in the first innings, an unbeaten 71 off 48 in the second, four catches, and a wicket; captain Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76*. Coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root’s response after errors at Lord’s, while Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott lauded England’s complete performance and Pakistan’s broken spirit. Pakistan struggled, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 across the first two Tests; Misbah admitted poor shot selection and low confidence but backed his team’s resilience. Pakistan play a two-day tour match at Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August, with Vaughan predicting a tight series despite England’s emphatic win.

With Warren Gatland leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and Rob Howley joining his staff, Wales forwards coach Robin McBryde will serve as Wales’ head coach for the summer tour, his third stint after 2009 and 2013. McBryde called it an honor and an exciting opportunity, while the WRU, led by CEO Martyn Phillips, will finalize and announce additional assistant coaches soon. WRU chairman Gareth Davies said Welsh coaches’ involvement with the Lions will provide valuable development and long-term benefits for Welsh rugby, with the demanding New Zealand tour offering significant inspiration and growth.

Hull City overturned an early deficit to beat Southampton 2-1 at the KCOM Stadium, ending a six-game Premier League losing streak. Charlie Austin’s sixth-minute penalty put Saints ahead and Hull lost strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first-half injuries, but substitute Robert Snodgrass transformed the match after the break, equalizing on 61 minutes from Sam Clucas’ cross and then delivering the free-kick for Michael Dawson’s quick-fire winner. Southampton pushed late, with David Marshall making key saves and Clucas producing a dramatic goal-line clearance in stoppage time. Hull remain in the bottom three heading into the international break, while managers Mike Phelan and Claude Puel reflected on Hull’s character and Southampton’s lapse in concentration after European action.

A motorcyclist from the local area was killed in a collision with a tractor around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa; the tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police have not released further details and are appealing for witnesses. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov cancelled an investigation into alleged abuse of power exposed by covert recordings, saying he aimed to end national “agony” before June early elections, but the move drew condemnation from the opposition and EU officials. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev called it illegal and urged protests in Skopje, while EU Commissioner Johannes Hahn warned it undermined the rule of law and jeopardized Macedonia’s EU aspirations. The crisis began in 2015 with leaked recordings allegedly showing vote-rigging, cover-ups of a murder, widespread wiretapping of 20,000 people, and high-level corruption; the government denies the allegations and accuses Zaev of trying to destabilize the country.

After Bob Bradley’s sacking, Alan Curtis and assistant Paul Williams will lead Swansea against Bournemouth while the club seeks a swift appointment, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement the preferred candidate. Curtis warns relegation would make an immediate return difficult given a stronger Championship and Swansea’s likely inability to retain top players, contrasting with clubs like Newcastle. Reflecting on Swansea’s rise from near-bankruptcy to Premier League promotion in 2011, he says the club has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure due to frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements, though he still believes the current squad can stay up and emphasizes to new signings the importance of the club’s journey and its significance to the area.

Leyton Orient beat Dagenham & Redbridge, with Armand Gnanduillet scoring the winner after Orient led 2-0 and the Daggers briefly drew level through Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, a result that relegated Dagenham to the National League and kept Orient two points off the League Two play-offs. Dagenham, promoted to the Football League in 2007 and to League One in 2010 under John Still, return to non-league with the division’s worst goal difference, having conceded 20 more goals than at this stage last season and struggled in attack, with 40-year-old Cureton scoring nine compared to 20 the previous campaign. Still, back for a third spell since December, pledged to target promotion next season, while Orient’s interim boss Andy Hessenthaler emphasized professionalism and the need to keep winning after a turbulent week that saw player-manager Kevin Nolan removed.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to the club in February as a youth coach, his first role since retiring in November after a 19-year career. Jurgen Klopp called the appointment “wonderful news,” noting Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager and the need to learn the job, predicting a bright future given his playing experience. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and won the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup, and three League Cups before moving to LA Galaxy in 2015, turned down the MK Dons managerial role as too soon and is working toward his UEFA A coaching licence.

Morton secured a comfortable win after McManus opened the scoring on 15 minutes and Ross Forbes’ deflected effort made it 2-0; Alloa pulled one back through Kyle McAusland before halftime, but a second McManus goal and a late strike from Denny Johnstone sealed the victory for the hosts.

Ofsted found children being taught in squalid conditions at three unregistered Birmingham sites, now closed, amid an investigation of 18 largely Muslim-community settings in the Midlands that may be illegal schools. Chief inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw warned these cases are likely the “tip of the iceberg,” raising risks of abuse or radicalisation, and criticized officials for slow, confusing responses. By law, provision over 20 hours a week must register as a school; some part-time or “flexi” centers support home education legally, but authorities fear others exploit this to operate illegally. The government has funded a six-inspector team, will pursue prosecutions (with Education Secretary consent), and is consulting on tighter regulation for settings teaching more than 6–8 hours weekly, with rules to apply across all religious groups.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is a small-scale gin distillery aiming to showcase local Teviot Valley botanicals and the Scottish Borders “terroir.” Lead distiller Kate Macinnes sees it complementing several proposed whisky distilleries that could revive regional distilling for the first time since 1837, positioning the Borders as a distilling hub. Despite operating one of the UK’s smallest production stills in a cowshed, the team prioritizes flavor and local sourcing, aligning with the site’s Scottish Borders Brewery. Named after Lilliard, the heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor near the distillery, the brand reflects the local landscape and its strong female production team.

In August 2013 at Swithens Farm near Leeds, 11-year-old Harry Whitlam died when Gary Green, 51, reversed a tractor into him on private land while more than twice the legal alcohol limit, having drunk the equivalent of 13 pints before bed. Prosecuted under health and safety laws rather than road traffic law, Green admitted failing to ensure others’ safety and was jailed for 16 months and two weeks. The Health and Safety Executive found Harry was in a closed-off area when Green backed the tractor at about 09:15 on 9 August; an inspector called the conduct reckless. Harry’s mother, Pam Whitlam, said the family was “changed forever,” urging that no one should drive drunk on public or private land and hoping her son’s life would be remembered beyond the day of the accident.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport upheld most of FIFA’s sanctions on Luis Suarez for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup but ruled it “excessive” to bar him from all football activity, allowing him to train, attend matches, take part in promotional work, and play in friendlies. Barcelona confirmed the 27-year-old, signed from Liverpool for £75m, will join training and be publicly presented, though it’s unclear if he’ll face Club Leon; his competitive debut is likely in El Clasico at Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez must still serve the remaining eight international matches of his nine-game ban and the four-month competitive suspension, but he can play Uruguay friendlies in September and October. Fifpro criticized the decision for not reducing the bans further or requiring treatment, while legal commentators noted CAS’s emphasis on proportionate sanctions. Suarez previously received bans for biting Otman Bakkal and Branislav Ivanovic and an eight-match suspension for racially abusing Patrice Evra.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a wife-carrying race, narrowly beating Lithuania’s Vytautas Kirkliauskas and Neringa Kirliauskiene after a week of training. The 380-metre course featured haystack hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistol dodging. The event allowed various pairings, including men carrying women or men, and a woman carrying a woman. Rich and Anna qualified for the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government will scrap paper car tax discs in October 2014, replacing them with an electronic system that allows monthly direct debit payments. Minister Stephen Hammond told Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that while the change and a likely drop in refunds will alter job roles at the DVLA, any reduction in tasks will be handled through retraining and redeployment rather than redundancies. Hedges welcomed the assurances, noting fewer job opportunities but benefits for motorists, and said the response should reassure the DVLA’s 5,000 employees.

Hungary’s government, facing EU pressure over tight controls on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law, refuses to backtrack, asserting these are domestic matters. Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó told Reuters that Poland would veto any EU move to strip Hungary’s voting rights, a step requiring unanimity. The contested measures include forcing asylum seekers into secured shipping containers, a Higher Education Law that could close Budapest’s Central European University founded by George Soros, and draft NGO legislation labeling groups as “foreign-backed.” Despite protests in Hungary and warnings from EU officials of impending action, the right-wing Fidesz government maintains its stance.

A live-action Beauty and the Beast film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou. Kevin Kline plays Belle’s father Maurice, and the star cast as Mrs. Potts takes over the role voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated original.

Adrian Gill, the celebrated and often controversial Sunday Times columnist known for his dazzling, fearless prose and for dictating copy due to dyslexia, has died after revealing last month he had the “full English” of cancers and undergoing chemotherapy. Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens called him “a giant among journalists” and “the heart and soul” of the paper, with tributes from figures including Jay Rayner, Tim Shipman, Stig Abell, John Witherow, Andrew Neil, and Piers Morgan. Gill’s career spanned art reviews in the 1980s, Tatler, and the Sunday Times from 1993, marked by both popularity and controversy over provocative remarks and incidents. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, educated at St Christopher School, Central Saint Martins, and the Slade, he was married to Cressida Connolly, then to Amber Rudd (with whom he had two children), and later became engaged to long-term partner Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins; his final column on coming to terms with his diagnosis was to run in the Sunday Times.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar (Amraa), lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was allegedly assaulted in Ulan Bator—reportedly hit with a bottle and kicked—after performing in a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol predating Nazi use. His father said Amarmandakh spent about 10 days in a coma with serious brain injuries, while displaying traditional swastika patterns to stress its cultural meaning; his lawyer and band denied claims he shouted “Heil Hitler.” A Russian diplomatic officer is suspected but not detained; police say the injury is not considered serious and deny immunity prevented arrest. The Russian embassy said it is investigating and called media reports distorted regarding details of the incident.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a protest on Heathrow’s northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday against the airport’s expansion plans; police charged the men and women with aggravated trespass and entering a security-restricted aerodrome area, set a court appearance for 19 August, and said airport security would be reviewed.

In a balanced day dominated by bowlers, Glamorgan posted around 220, built on Nick Selman’s 101 off 144—his second first-class century and a return to form after four ducks—after being dropped on eight. Aneurin Donald added a brisk 36, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten scrambled a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire’s seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles shared regular wickets in cloudy conditions, with Taylor repeatedly hitting the stumps and satisfied to bowl Glamorgan out for 220. Gloucestershire then faced a survival task in evening gloom, with the match finely poised. Glamorgan were captained by Michael Hogan in Jacques Rudolph’s absence due to a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police after drunken late-night online chats with Tennessee’s Hope Line Crisis Centre in which he outlined a plan to make a false crime report and ambush responding officers to shoot them on the Dee Estuary. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody, noting a 2009 firearm possession conviction. Although his legal team argued he neither intended suicide nor to carry out threats against police, authorities were especially concerned as he was then on bail for separate firearms offences, for which he was later cleared. The Hope Line provides confidential support and counseling.

Surrey recovered from 8-2 to post 255-7, driven by a 130-run stand between Davies (who hit a six and 10 fours) and Ben Foakes (90), despite drops by Matthew Waite, who still took 3-48. Yorkshire’s chase faltered after a rapid three-wicket burst in nine balls from Stuart Meaker (3-61), removing Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance, and Jack Leaning. Tim Bresnan (68) and Waite (38) rallied, but needing 27 off the final three overs proved too steep, and Yorkshire were all out for 236, Bresnan last to fall. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised the collective effort and pivotal Davies-Foakes partnership, while Yorkshire skipper Alex Lees lamented missed top-order contributions despite strong bowling, noting they fell short when it mattered.

A 56ft (17.1m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, reported at 07:00 BST that its onboard pump couldn’t handle incoming water; Holyhead coastguards responded, and an RNLI lifeboat provided an additional pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Middle-distance runner Laura Muir, balancing her final year of veterinary studies, will miss the April Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her exams are in May, though she hopes to target the World Indoor Championships in March. The 24-year-old, who finished fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Championships, set a new outdoor 5,000m personal best of 14:52.07 in London and expressed confidence about her future, suggesting she has two or three more Olympics ahead. She’s disappointed to miss representing Scotland but prioritizes completing her degree, while noting she feels in reasonable shape and would like to race in Birmingham.

Robbie Savage argues Liverpool are far from last season’s title-challenging level and should view a top-four finish as success, citing unrealistic fan expectations after overachieving, poor striker recruitment following Luis Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries, a loss of pressing intensity and first-half goals, diminished set-piece threat, and unresolved defensive frailties despite heavy spending. He criticizes Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini as inadequate fits, questions Dejan Lovren’s form, and highlights Simon Mignolet’s lack of command. For Chelsea’s visit, he suggests a lineup of Mignolet; Johnson, Skrtel, Toure, Moreno; Can, Gerrard; Sterling, Coutinho, Lallana; Borini, emphasizing balanced full-back involvement and midfield solidity, yet still expects Chelsea to win due to their superior form. On Steven Gerrard, he acknowledges the psychological weight of his April slip but insists he remains vital in a deeper role, can extend his career with physical and mental resilience, and remains central to Liverpool’s future.

A £45m education campus is planned for Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, incorporating primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council intends to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after William McIlvanney, the Kilmarnock-born writer and former English teacher who left teaching in 1975 to write full-time. Celebrated as the “Godfather of Tartan Noir,” he gained recognition with his debut novel Remedy Is None, wrote the Laidlaw trilogy and works like Docherty and The Big Man, and was also a notable poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributor to Scotland’s political and sporting discourse. Council leader Douglas Reid praised the move as preserving McIlvanney’s legacy and passion for education; McIlvanney died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

A suspected British sea mine from the 1940s–50s was found near Gourock, prompting precautionary evacuations of three streets, safety advice for residents within 500m, and exclusion zones on the river and at sea (about half a mile), with small boats told not to sail; ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted. Authorities emphasized there was no immediate danger, but due to the mine’s deterioration and unknown explosive content, the Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit chose to relocate it to a safer area before disposal. Residents were thanked for their patience during the cordon and evacuation.

UK Sport will invest £345m in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020—£2m less than for Rio—setting medal targets of 51–85 Olympic and 115–162 Paralympic medals after Britain won 67 and 147 respectively in 2016. Cycling’s funding drops by over £4m to £25.98m, while archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby also miss out. Badminton, despite winning a Rio bronze and meeting its target, loses all £5.74m funding, prompting strong criticism from Badminton England; judo, which also won a bronze, sees a slight increase. UK Sport leaders and the sports minister defend prioritizing medal potential, while basketball, handball and volleyball accuse UK Sport of neglecting team sports. Funding for new Tokyo sports (baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sport climbing, surfing, plus Para-taekwondo and Para-badminton) is pending, with £9m yet to be allocated.

Councillors in Bournemouth voted 7–3 to approve a redevelopment on East Cliff that will demolish three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View—to build a six‑storey, four‑star, 90‑room hotel and two assisted‑living blocks of nine and seven storeys with 122 apartments. Despite strong objections from English Heritage and others citing “severe harm” to the conservation area and loss of historic character, supporters argued the existing buildings were no longer functional and that the project would boost tourism and improve housing for older residents. The council received 246 letters in support and 49 objections, including from the Ancient Monuments Society.

Off-duty soldier Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, from Carrickfergus and serving with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked outside The Cellar bar in Brecon on 8 May after a night out; CCTV showed 24-year-old Jake Vallely, drunk after a seven-hour binge and boasting he was the “hardest man in Brecon,” punching Boyd, beating him unconscious, dragging his body away, and fleeing. Boyd’s body was found by police in the early hours, and Vallely is due to be sentenced on 8 December. Vallely’s friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter after the jury heard he had left before the violence began. Police condemned the “despicable” attack and urged people to avoid violence, while Boyd’s family paid tribute to him as a loving, lively “all-rounder” with a promising career, saying Vallely created an irreplaceable void but praising the Brecon community’s support.

Barnet Council’s chief executive Andrew Travers left by mutual agreement after a major election-day error where voters were initially turned away from all 155 polling stations due to missing names on poll lists. An independent investigation is being arranged, with findings due by the end of May to the General Functions Committee, including a review of arrangements for the June EU Referendum. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will serve temporarily. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and Travers blamed electoral registration lists for the issue, while residents questioned the fairness of the result. The council praised Travers’s contributions during his three and a half years in post.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2-1, with Josh Gillies opening for Gateshead via a free-kick, Sean Newton equalizing for Wrexham with his own set-piece before half-time, and Ryan Bowman heading the second-half winner from a right-side cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised the improved second-half passing and the quality of the winning goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills lamented a drop-off after the break, defensive openness, and missed chances despite limited clear opportunities for Gateshead.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of people over 60 across 96 countries, with Norway rated best and Afghanistan worst, followed by Mozambique; the piece is a brief 15-second report.

OneWeb and Airbus are building a low-cost, high-volume satellite constellation to deliver global broadband, targeting every school, with at least 600 satellites initially and potentially over 2,000. To achieve this, Airbus has developed car/aircraft-style assembly lines in Toulouse and soon in Florida, aiming to produce three satellites per shift at under $1 million each, with trolley robots and an upscaled supplier chain. The first 10 satellites are due to launch in April next year, followed by another batch in November, with over 20 Soyuz launches planned to deploy clusters of 32–36 satellites to 1,200 km, reaching ~300 satellites by late 2020/early 2021, 600 a year later, and 800+ by mid-decade. Competing mega-constellations are planned by SpaceX, Boeing, and ViaSat, but OneWeb claims first-mover advantage, having raised $1.7 billion in equity and seeking further loans. Registered in the UK’s Channel Islands, OneWeb will be licensed by the UK Space Agency, highlighting UK economic and regulatory benefits. Addressing debris concerns, OneWeb commits to de-orbit satellites within two years, adding hardware for reliable re-entry and adapters for potential retrieval by chase vehicles. Airbus may use these lines for other customers, though bespoke satellites will remain necessary for specialized missions.

Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney warned that the UK government’s spending review is putting unprecedented pressure on Scotland’s finances, arguing UK-imposed cuts since 2010 will leave Scotland’s discretionary budget 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20, with 4.2% of that reduction still to come and over £1bn in cuts remaining. He pledged to protect schools, hospitals, and police despite “austerity,” highlighting past achievements such as more police, lower crime, better schools, free university tuition, and record health spending. The UK government countered that Scotland will have £390m more to spend next year (or £750m including underspend), with a block grant near £30bn, and urged focus on new powers rather than “grievance,” citing low oil prices as validating the Union. Labour’s Jackie Baillie criticized Swinney’s “anti-austerity posturing,” calling for a long-term budget with different tax choices from both the Conservatives and the SNP.

The passage highlights the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families due to the scarcity of fully accessible “Changing Places” toilets, which provide extra space and equipment like hoists and benches beyond standard accessible toilets. While there are 893 such facilities in the UK and guidelines (BS 8300:2009) recommend them in larger buildings, they are not compulsory, leading to inconsistent provision and distressing situations for families, as described by parents like Lorna Fillingham and Alison Beevers. Campaigners seek to make Changing Places mandatory in new large complexes (e.g., shopping centers, cinemas, stadiums) to ensure dignity and inclusion, despite logistical and financial barriers, particularly in existing buildings. Positive examples include community “pop-up” solutions and venues like Arsenal Football Club adapting facilities, demonstrating both demand and benefits when accessibility is prioritized.

Italian consumer groups filed a formal antitrust complaint to the European Commission alleging McDonald’s abuses its market dominance by imposing above-market rents, high fees, and unusually long contracts on franchisees, limiting their ability to switch competitors and leading to reduced consumer choice and higher prices in franchised stores. The complaint is backed by SEIU and European unions, while McDonald’s defends its model as a long-standing risk-and-reward partnership that supports franchisees and customers. The Commission will review the submission and may investigate if warranted. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald’s European restaurants, and McDonald’s earned $9.27bn in global franchise revenues in 2014.

A billboard with the hashtag #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood as part of a viral social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital discovered and removed a large primary tumor and five smaller growths during a planned appendix operation. Launched by Bangor Elim Church—where Josh’s father serves—on Facebook and Instagram, the hashtag spread widely, with one update shared 948 times and viewed over 79,000 times worldwide. Church senior pastor Gary Beattie expressed amazement at the global support and noted the church hadn’t organized a campaign or the billboard; a mystery donor funded the sign at Holywood playing fields. Support has also surged on Twitter, including from Josh’s classmates at Bangor Grammar, as people globally rally behind his recovery.

The UK is restructuring its military estate, prompting the proposed closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic site since 1805, which Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned as disrespectful to its legacy and harmful to Brecon’s economy and military tourism; he plans a petition and notes local unemployment concerns. While about 85 civilian and 90 military staff work at the barracks, jobs are not thought to be at risk, and nearby Sennybridge training ground and Dering Lines infantry school are expected to remain open. Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, with Cawdor Barracks closing in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025. Labour’s Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith agreed on the need to restructure but warned of uncertainty for affected communities.

A House of Lords report warns that, despite strong pro-Brexit sentiment in UK fishing regions, the sector risks being sidelined in negotiations due to its small economic size, and that Britain may need to allow continued EU access to UK waters to preserve tariff-free access to EU markets. The report stresses that most key fish stocks are shared with EU states, the UK exports most of its catch to the EU while importing much of what it consumes, and that continued market access and cooperation are essential. It recommends retaining science-based quotas and elements of the Common Fisheries Policy, notes potential complications if devolved administrations create four separate regimes, and highlights international obligations to collaborate. While many in the industry see Brexit as a chance to regain control of UK waters and expand as a coastal state with a 200-mile exclusive economic zone, the Lords emphasize inevitable trade-offs, even as recent CFP quota increases for UK species bolster industry optimism. The government says it seeks maximum single-market access while using Brexit to review fisheries for fair quotas, sustainability, and a healthy marine environment.

Edward Snowden, a 29-year-old former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks showing that the NSA conducts large-scale surveillance, accessing chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, social networking data, and millions of Verizon phone records (including call duration, location, and numbers). Documents allege the Prism program provided “backdoor” access to servers of major tech firms, though all deny involvement and its workings remain unclear; experts suggest access may be limited and court-controlled. U.S. officials defend the programs as vital for security, asserting access is targeted, while acknowledging the privacy-security trade-off. Data-protection laws typically regulate companies, not governments, and cloud storage plus U.S. laws like the Patriot Act and FISA facilitate U.S. access to foreign users’ data with limited transparency. The extent of other governments’ involvement, including the UK’s GCHQ, is unconfirmed; the EU has sought details and raised concerns. Privacy advocates argue Prism confirms fears that global users of U.S.-based services have little recourse, while Snowden says he acted due to alarm over pervasive surveillance.

OpenAI is a nonprofit AI venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aiming to advance digital intelligence for broad human benefit without needing financial returns. Its mission emphasizes maximizing positive impact, ensuring AI aligns with human wills, and distributing benefits widely and safely. The effort acknowledges both transformative potential and serious risks of AI, echoing warnings from Musk and Stephen Hawking, while noting some experts see the threat as remote. Although $1 billion is pledged, only a small portion will be spent in the next few years.

Doncaster-based L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, carried the Olympic torch for nearly half an hour on 26 June with assistance, drawing huge public support. Despite a brain injury that initially took his speech, he now speaks unaided, trains and rehabilitates for 12 hours a day, walks with crutches, and raises funds for military charities as a patron of Pilgrim Bandits. Following his torch-bearing, he received over 5,000 Facebook friend requests—hitting the personal profile limit—along with massive online engagement and mail, leaving him “buoyed up,” according to his mother. Facebook suggested he use a public page or the subscribe feature due to his public figure status. The torch relay involves 8,000 carriers over 8,000 miles in 70 days, leading to the London 2012 opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate held at 15%, encompassing 46.2 million people, after rising for three prior years; this followed a record 15.1% in 2010. Real median household income fell 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021 (£14,300). Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose 1.6%, the first annual increase since 1993. The share of Americans without health insurance declined from 16.3% to 15.7%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new deal keeping him at the club until 2019. He holds England’s three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan. Lancashire’s cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler’s talent, impact on their T20 Blast triumph, and positive influence in the dressing room. After playing in the IPL for Mumbai Indians, Buttler will return for Lancashire’s T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham, and Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and up for sale, with bids registered by 23 January and viewings due in late February and March; no preservation proposals have been submitted, and a final decision is expected in spring. The UK’s Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one ship to a UK recycler to test domestic capacity, while MP Penny Mordaunt supports giving UK recyclers a chance but hopes at least one ship is saved, ideally as a reef and diving attraction to boost tourism and value. The MoD says it will consider all options for best taxpayer return and won’t disclose bid details for commercial reasons. Type 22s, originally anti-submarine vessels, became versatile surface combatants with strong anti-surface, anti-submarine, and anti-air capabilities, noted for command-and-control strengths and crews of about 280; HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3m last year.

Since 1987 Fiji has faced recurring coups and ethnic-political tensions, beginning with an indigenous Fijian coup against an Indian-dominated government, a withdrawn pro-indigenous constitution, and a 2000 coup that held the first ethnic Indian prime minister and others hostage, damaging the economy—especially tourism—and global standing. Disputes over amnesty and ongoing divisions led to a bloodless military takeover in 2006, suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009, and reinstatement after promised 2014 elections restored ties with Australia and New Zealand. Demographically, the population on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu is split between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, though Indo-Fijian numbers declined after emigration, leaving indigenous Fijians a small majority amid deep informal segregation; small minorities include Chinese and Rotumans. Economically, Fiji relies on sugar and tourism but is diversified with mining, services, and light manufacturing, yet persistent trade and budget deficits make it a high per capita aid recipient.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said Syria is trying to meet its chemical weapons destruction timetable but missed a deadline after convoys were twice attacked en route to Latakia, blaming “terrorist groups” and wartime conditions. He rejected US criticism over alleged barrel bomb use in Aleppo and denied targeting civilians, while US and UK-based monitors reported hundreds of civilian deaths from barrel bomb attacks. Conflicting claims emerged over rebels seizing Aleppo’s central prison, with activists saying it was captured and state media saying the attack was thwarted. Of Syria’s declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, the US said only about 4% had left the country, prompting concern from Washington; Russia urged transfer to the coast by 1 March, and all destruction is due by end-June. The OPCW acknowledged security-related delays, and Mekdad reaffirmed Syria’s commitment to its obligations.

The Man Booker Prize, in its first year open to all English-language authors regardless of nationality, will be announced at London’s Guildhall, with Neel Mukherjee’s The Lives of Others the 5/2 bookmakers’ favorite and Richard Flanagan next at 3/1. The shortlist comprises three British writers (including former winner Howard Jacobson for J and Ali Smith for How To Be Both), two Americans (Joshua Ferris for To Rise Again at a Decent Hour and Karen Joy Fowler for We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), and Australian Richard Flanagan for The Narrow Road to the Deep North. Fowler’s novel is the bestseller (55,000+ copies), far ahead of Ferris (~6,000), and all titles saw sales spikes after the shortlist announcement. Commentary from academic David Brauner questions the list’s strength and notes potential reluctance to give Jacobson a second win, while the perennial “merit vs readability” debate resurfaces. The prize, in its 46th year, is judged by a panel chaired by AC Grayling; shortlisted authors receive £2,500, last year’s winner was Eleanor Catton, and the ceremony will be covered by BBC.

A celebrity known as PJS is seeking to appeal a Court of Appeal decision that lifted a ban on naming him in England and Wales, while the UK Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and has kept an interim injunction in place until that hearing concludes. The case concerns The Sun on Sunday’s attempt to publish allegations of PJS’s extra-marital activities involving a three-way encounter with individuals referred to as AB and CD, initially denied an injunction by the High Court but later granted anonymity by two appeal judges. News Group Newspapers argued the injunction was ineffective due to widespread publication in the US, Scotland, and online, and on Monday the Court of Appeal agreed that confidentiality was likely lost and a permanent injunction was unlikely, though it allowed time to seek a Supreme Court appeal and maintained the anonymity order until the next hearing.

Fosse Park, a retail area near M1 junction 21 opened in 1989, was bought in August for £345.5m, and its new owners plan improvements to parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units and common areas. Blaby District Council leader Ernie White said the owners engaged with the council on planning questions and view the site as an investable gateway to the city that currently presents unattractive “backs of sheds.” Crown Estates’ investment director Paul Clarke emphasized upgrading tired areas, focusing on better parking, reduced congestion, and enhanced pedestrian and parking facilities to raise overall quality.

Disney’s live-action Beauty and the Beast faced controversy in Malaysia over an “exclusively gay moment,” leading Disney to delay its planned Thursday release for a content review. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor cut and a P13 rating, noting release timing is outside its jurisdiction, while homosexuality remains illegal in the country. A new release date has not been announced, cinemas offered refunds, and online criticism labeled the review and potential ban as “stupid and laughable.” The gay moment involves LeFou’s conflicted feelings for Gaston as a side-plot.

Southampton City Council reports many landlords are avoiding House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) licences—costing about £1,000—despite fines up to £20,000, estimating 1,500 unlicensed HMOs locally. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to properties of three or more storeys with five or more unrelated occupants, while in Southampton additional licensing covers areas including Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (since 2013), and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (since 2015). Shelter’s Nadeem Khan says tenants frequently fear eviction and poor conditions amid a shortage of affordable homes, receiving five to six related calls daily. The council says most landlords cooperate but a minority resist, and it has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are seeking to avoid a second election by forming a minority government, with Fianna Fáil willing to facilitate but not back a full programme for government. A key sticking point is water charges: Fianna Fáil wants them abolished immediately, while Fine Gael supports their continuation, with a commission on the future of Irish Water under consideration. After the election nearly two months ago, seat totals were Fine Gael 50, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and Labour 7, leaving no majority and preventing the election of a taoiseach.

A fire broke out Tuesday afternoon on a car deck of the ferry Sorrento while en route to Valencia, forcing a full evacuation about 27 km from Mallorca after initial hopes of avoiding abandonment. Passengers and crew were moved to lifeboats and rescued by nearby ships, ultimately boarding the ferry Puglia. At least three people were injured, one seriously, and airlifted to hospital. Spanish officials said the rescued passengers were being taken back to Palma de Mallorca, with psychologists requested for support. The cause of the blaze is unknown, and authorities warned the Sorrento, owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, might sink at its current location after issuing a distress call at 13:50 local time.

The Electoral Commission reported concerns about potential double voting, with 38 MPs citing cases, and highlighted systemic issues causing duplicate registrations due to unlinked local electoral registers and the national online system. Despite a record 46.8 million registered voters for the 8 June election and the highest turnout since 1997 (68.7%), a surge of 4.9 million applications between December 2016 and May 22 yielded only a 1.4 million net increase, implying 30–70% duplicates in some areas. The watchdog urged better integration of registers, clearer online guidance, and a verification function (as used in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland), and suggested requiring people registered in two constituencies to preselect where they will vote. While noting lawful dual registration for local elections, it stressed that voting twice in a general election is a criminal offence. Labour supported enforcement but warned against measures that would hinder young people and students, opposing a blanket ban on dual registration.

Officials say former NFL running back Lawrence Phillips, 40, died by apparent suicide in prison, where he was serving over 30 years for assaults including driving into a group of teenagers and attacking a former girlfriend. A standout at the University of Nebraska who later played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, Phillips’ career and life were marred by legal troubles. He had been housed alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward, and a judge had just ruled there was enough evidence to try him in that case. The method of his suicide is unclear. Former Nebraska coach Tom Osborne remembered Phillips as intelligent with good qualities but struggling with anger and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier-mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal in Chester for “good behaviour,” receiving the honor from Brigadier Andrew Williams during the regiment’s eighth anniversary event. He is the 30th in a lineage of mascot rams dating back to the 1858 origins with the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot, and became part of the Mercian Regiment upon its formation in 2007. Joining in February 2014, he has an army number, is paid for his rations, takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate, and has participated in public events including switching on Ashbourne’s Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at the 1914 Christmas Truce memorial unveiling.

Liverpool staged a dramatic 4-3 Europa League win over Borussia Dortmund at Anfield, overturning early deficits through goals from Origi, Coutinho, Sakho, and a stoppage-time header by Lovren, embodying Jurgen Klopp’s mantra of turning “doubters into believers.” The night featured an intense atmosphere, including a long rendition of “You’ll Never Walk Alone” and a minute’s silence for Hillsborough’s 27th anniversary, with Klopp’s touchline passion and Tuchel’s acknowledgment of the belief shift in the stadium. The result put Liverpool into the semi-finals and closer to a Champions League spot via the Europa League, showcasing Klopp’s imprint—resilience, high energy, and rising performances from Origi and Can—while highlighting lingering defensive vulnerabilities, notably at left-back and in positional play. Klopp cautioned against complacency, evoked the spirit of Istanbul 2005, and reinforced standards by reserving the right to touch the “This Is Anfield” sign for when silverware is won.
