After a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis proposed monthly meetings and a two-way information flow to keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed and to gather their views as the UK shapes its negotiating strategy with the EU, emphasizing constructive engagement to secure the best deal for the whole UK. Scotland’s Brexit minister Michael Russell welcomed involvement but criticized the UK government’s lack of clarity on whether it seeks to remain in the single market or customs union, stressing that single market membership is essential for Scotland’s economic prosperity and calling for more transparency. Meanwhile, the UK hopes the High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 is overturned by the Supreme Court, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this in the appeal, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking to be heard.

A University of Nottingham team led by Prof Kevin Sinclair is closely monitoring 13 cloned sheep, including four genetically identical “twin sisters” of Dolly, to assess whether cloning accelerates aging. Concern stems from the possibility that adult-cell DNA used in cloning carries “age-memory,” potentially causing premature age-related diseases, as suggested by Dolly’s osteoarthritis before her death at six-and-a-half. The researchers have subjected the sheep to extensive exams, X-rays, and fMRI scans focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. While full results will be published next week, the clones—now nearing nine to ten years old—currently appear healthy, a finding that could strongly influence the future of cloning.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes on very soft ground, beating Vintage Folly by 1¾ lengths, and will target the French Oaks at Chantilly over 1¼ miles rather than the Epsom Oaks, where Gosden will rely on Enable and Coronet. Tasleet (14-1), for William Haggas and jockey Jim Crowley, won the Duke of York Stakes from Magical Memory and Comicas. Gosden, pleased to have a month to prepare Shutter Speed for France, remains cautious about running his colt Cracksman in Thursday’s Dante Stakes due to ground concerns and the short 16-day gap to the Derby.

Sterling fell against the dollar, euro, and yen amid heightened Brexit uncertainty, briefly recovering before dropping again, with the volatility index reaching 2008-crisis levels. By the session cited, the pound was down 0.2% to $1.4226, 0.6% to €1.2605, and 1% versus the yen to just over 151. Market nerves were stoked by polls showing Leave ahead and Betfair cutting Remain’s implied probability to 68.5% from nearly 80%, prompting expectations of sharper pound moves as new polls arrive and increased short-selling by hedge funds. Equities slid globally: Japan’s Nikkei fell 3.5%, Hong Kong 2.5%, and the FTSE 100 closed down 1.1% at 6,044.9, with Lloyds down 4.2%. Leave figures argued the pound remained around March levels and that a weaker sterling could aid exporters, noting April’s narrowed UK trade deficit due to higher exports.

Braintree Town, nicknamed the Iron, sit sixth in the National League, one point outside the play-offs, after a third consecutive defeat to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten run to nine games. Manager Danny Cowley told BBC Essex he was proud of his part-time team’s effort despite conceding early following a long trip, calling their season so far “remarkable” and stressing that the challenge is tough but they will embrace and enjoy it.

From April 2015, most planning decisions in Northern Ireland will shift from the central Planning Service to local councils, putting elected politicians in charge of accepting or rejecting developments. Supporters like Michael Corr of PLACE see this as a democratic opportunity for councils to shape community and development plans, provided voters choose politicians with planning expertise. Critics, including Friends of the Earth’s James Orr, warn of risks of favoritism, echoes of 1960s discrimination, and close ties between developers and parties, urging strict codes of conduct and transparency. The debate extends to political donations: campaigners argue more disclosure is vital as planning powers grow, while some politicians resist citing donor security and the limited scale of local donations. The Northern Ireland Secretary holds the power to decide when to increase transparency under recent legislation.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun in Winchburgh, suffering shoulder wounds and such severe damage to her left back leg that it was amputated; her owner, Sarah Nisbett, reported she is relearning to move and expressed concern about the danger in a housing estate with children. The Scottish SPCA condemned the “callous” attack, urged anyone with information to come forward, and used the incident to call for urgent implementation of air gun licensing in Scotland. While the Scottish government had consulted on licensing air weapons, 87% of respondents opposed the proposal—some calling it draconian—though a few felt it did not go far enough; the proposed scheme would require owners to show a legitimate reason to possess an air gun and help police trace irresponsible users.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa on a long-term deal after triggering his release clause, making him their second most expensive signing and seventh of the summer following Raheem Sterling’s £49m sale. The 24-year-old Belgium striker, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after joining from Genk in 2012, aims to win trophies and fits Brendan Rodgers’ plan to revive an attack that struggled post-Luis Suarez and amid Daniel Sturridge’s injuries. Liverpool have also added Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and welcomed back Divock Origi. Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles injury but returned to score 15 goals to help Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final, has been backed to succeed at Anfield by former manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge for his strength, pace, and goal threat.

A study of 671 UK state and independent schools found widespread and growing use of tablets—68% of primaries and 69% of secondaries use them, with 9% providing one per pupil and highest adoption in academies—with numbers projected to double from about 430,000 to nearly 900,000 between 2014 and 2016; however, researchers found no clear evidence that tablets improve academic results, as impacts cannot be isolated, though head teachers reported motivational benefits, greater family involvement when devices go home, and alignment with real-world technology use. A related National Literacy Trust/Pearson study suggested touch screens particularly aid boys and pupils from poorer backgrounds in learning to read, who are more likely to read on devices than in print. The research also highlighted heavy personal use: many pupils take connected devices to bed, a quarter of secondary pupils in 1:1 schools self-described as internet “addicts,” and about 70% of 5–15-year-olds have home tablet access. Advocates like a head teacher in Essex argue tablets offer portability, instant-on convenience, and foster empowerment and trust, even if benefits are not easily captured in league tables.

The Museum of Liverpool’s exhibition “Growing Up in the City” presents 25 photographs from the 1880s to the 1990s that depict children’s lives and social history in Liverpool, highlighting both play and work. Curated by Kay Jones, who selected the images from hundreds in National Museums Liverpool’s collections, the display includes notable shots like an 1887 portrait of the affluent Rollo children in fancy-dress for a mayoral ball and an early-1900s image of a young maid, illustrating changing childhood experiences and marking special street occasions. The exhibition aims to show both the joys and hardships of childhood and runs until 25 September.

Torquay United have signed 27-year-old centre-back Myles Anderson, who mutually terminated his Barrow contract and could face his former club on 18 February, and 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, recommended by Micky Adams and previously with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson’s leadership qualities despite limited appearances and described Keating as raw but hungry. Torquay sit four points above the relegation zone, with one win in their last six matches.

Bolivia passed a law allowing 12-year-olds to work for others with parental authorization, reflecting the country’s economic realities where over 500,000 children already work, while also imposing harsher penalties for violence against children, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide. Signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in President Evo Morales’s absence, the law aims to balance local needs with international norms and help eradicate extreme poverty. The International Labour Organisation, which generally sets 15 as the minimum working age (14 for developing countries), is reviewing whether the legislation violates its standards.

Rosie O’Donnell, 50, described surviving a severe “widow maker” heart attack after experiencing chest ache, nausea, and fever following an incident helping a woman near her Nyack, New York home. She looked up “women’s heart attack symptoms,” took aspirin, and saw a cardiologist the next day, who placed a stent in a coronary artery that was 99% blocked. Though she did not call emergency services, she urged readers—especially women—to recognize symptoms and call 911. O’Donnell, known for roles in Drop Dead Diva, Will & Grace, and Nip/Tuck, had her OWN talk show, The Rosie Show, which was canceled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was fatally stabbed around 00:30 GMT in an alleyway near a party on Belvedere Way, Kenton, after a group of youths who had been denied entry earlier returned; he was pronounced dead about an hour later, and a 16-year-old boy was also stabbed but is stable. Police said the party was well-run with adults present, Che had been invited and was not involved in the initial altercation, but appeared to be targeted later. Det Chief Insp Chris Jones appealed for witnesses near the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate. A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December, and a 14-year-old was held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

Denmark overhauled its cancer diagnosis system after poor survival statistics and long waits, especially for patients with vague or hard-to-diagnose symptoms. Analysis of 30,000 cases showed over 25% arose from patients without obvious cancer signs, prompting a three-route model: fast-track pathways with strict time targets for “alarm” symptoms (and a legal 30-day investigation limit after GP referral); diagnosis centres for undifferentiated symptoms to rapidly run comprehensive tests; and “yes-no” centres offering quick, simple tests for minor symptoms to rule out serious disease, detecting about 1% with significant illness and avoiding months-long delays. The reforms improved organization without overwhelming referrals, enhanced collaboration between GPs and specialists, and contributed to faster-improving survival rates, with Denmark catching up to other Nordic countries—offering lessons relevant to Wales’ similar health system.

Following the UK government’s disbanding of the Office of Fair Trading, Powys County Council won a competitive bid to take over enforcement of estate agent regulations, receiving £170,000 annually. The new Powys-led team, headed by James Munro, can issue warning and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching the Estate Agents Act. Consumers will still report issues to local authority trading standards, which may prosecute and will refer potential Act breaches to Powys. Munro hopes the role will demonstrate Powys’s capacity to handle additional contracts and external work.

NHS Employers endorsed a Nuffield Trust plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong NHS workforce by expanding roles for nurses, pharmacists, and other staff through additional training, aiming to cover doctor shortages and better manage long-term conditions like diabetes and heart disease. The review cited existing examples of nurses substituting for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs, arguing that with doctors only about 10% of staff, broader skill expansion could improve care and job satisfaction—but it requires dedicated funding. Supporters, including report author Candace Imison and NHS Employers’ Danny Mortimer, see major opportunities, while critics such as BMA’s Dr Mark Porter and Unison’s Christina McAnea warn against undermining doctors’ training or using workforce development as a quick, underfunded fix amid chronic staffing and funding pressures.

A crash at 03:00 GMT led Avon and Somerset Police to close the A36 Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot, causing significant rush-hour disruption and bus delays until the road reopened at 14:00 GMT. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First reported that some services had resumed but full normalization would take a few hours, with Managing Director James Freeman aiming for a full service by the evening commute and thanking the public and staff for their support and efforts.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon could cause annual deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout during migration, prompting Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) to dispute the figures as lacking a clear scientific basis and alleging NRW would not share its methodology. TLP’s own expert modeling suggested a worst-case mortality of 2% across all fish species. NRW rejected TLP’s criticism, stating it had shared extensive data and methods over 18 months and that independent and internal experts validated its approach as the best available evidence. The £1.3bn project is seen by TLP as a pilot for larger lagoons at other Welsh sites, while the Welsh Government is supportive but awaiting the UK government’s imminent decision following a six-month review of the scheme’s viability.

Northern Ireland’s DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of an industry-led agri-food marketing body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board, modeled on Scotland Food and Drink. Citing the sector’s importance—nearly 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution—she said the body will provide strategic leadership and coordinate marketing across government and private organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move as supporting export-led growth and addressing the need for better coordination, while noting potential implications for other organizations, including her department, and anticipating further discussions with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public on Saturday to help plant thousands of native trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley as part of one of its most ambitious four-year UK-wide planting programmes commemorating WW1. The project aims to plant millions of trees overall and specifically 40,000 at Brackfield Wood to honor the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who died in the conflict, under the pledge “We will stand for those who fell.” Director Patrick Cregg urged volunteers to join in planting provided saplings, wear welly boots or sturdy footwear, and noted the site—about seven miles from Derry off the Glenshane Road with limited parking—will feature wildflowers like poppies and become a place for wildlife and quiet reflection, serving as a lasting tribute to soldiers, their families, and loved ones.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award at Harrogate’s crime writing festival for Someone Else’s Skin, praised by judges as a finely crafted, powerful thriller addressing domestic violence and honour crime and launching Det Insp Marnie Rome. Judge Alison Graham called it emotionally exhausting and powerful, while programming chair Ann Cleeves lauded its tight writing, atmosphere, and plotting. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career creating Chicago PI VI Warshawski, a groundbreaking strong female protagonist portrayed by Kathleen Turner in a 1991 film and a BBC Radio 4 adaptation; Cleeves credited Paretsky with changing perceptions of female writers and co-founding Sisters in Crime to support women in the genre.

Worcestershire will re-sign New Zealand all-rounder Mitchell Santner, 24, to rejoin the Rapids after June’s ICC Trophy in England, following his 2016 stint cut short by a broken finger in only his second game. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes called his loss a major blow to their qualification hopes and sees “unfinished business.” Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner who debuted in Tests in 2015, said he’s eager to make up for lost time and contribute with bat and ball. Separately, Worcestershire have also signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season across all formats.

In 2008, British millionaire Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding, unlit car with stolen plates while trying to hail a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway; an Exeter coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, ruled it an unlawful killing, citing overwhelming circumstantial evidence and noting investigative difficulties abroad. Pring’s wife, Ganna (Anna) Ziuzina—19 years younger, whom he met online in 2006 and married in 2007—had returned to a restaurant for a glove at the time, later tried to claim his assets within days, sold his property, moved funds, and was entitled to the first £200,000 of his estate; records indicated she was having an affair. Family and friends believe he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run for financial gain, and a police detective reported witnesses viewed the act as deliberate at about 75 mph. Ukrainian authorities closed, then in 2011 reopened, a murder inquiry that remains active but not actively pursued; Ziuzina did not attend the inquest despite efforts but said she had given statements to Ukrainian police.

Sophie and Rob Fearns from Litherland, Merseyside, say their son Charlie, ill since age three and facing a third relapse with no UK treatment options, must return to Seattle Children’s Hospital for urgent T-Cell therapy after a failed first transplant; they were “ecstatic,” “overwhelmed,” and “extremely grateful” when the hospital emailed confirming an anonymous donor would fully fund the experimental treatment, giving Charlie financial clearance so therapy can start as soon as possible, with a start date expected next week.

Apple expanded its two-step verification to cover iCloud backups after celebrity photo thefts linked to third-party tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker, which had exploited a gap allowing backup downloads despite enabled two-step login. The strengthened system, still opt-in, requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device for new-device access and blocks iCloud and store purchases without it; users can recover access with a 14-character recovery key, which some experts warn can be lost or stolen. Elcomsoft’s owner says the update shuts down his technique and now even prevents listing linked devices, with added email alerts when backups start. While Apple plans to push users toward two-factor and stronger passwords, some security experts argue two-factor should be the default across major tech firms.

Dan Groves said details are pending on a deal for Mark Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town, with The Sun reporting the 30-year-old would join as a director. Billericay sit eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points off the play-offs. Wright, a 2011 I’m A Celebrity runner-up, previously played non-league for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multimillionaire Glenn Tamplin, who pledged to invest £10,000 per week, and signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

A BBC investigation into a Derbyshire company’s warehouse practices prompted the BIS select committee, chaired by MP Iain Wright, to seek evidence from owner Mr Ashley about worker treatment and minimum wage enforcement. After Mr Ashley invited the committee to meet at Sports Direct’s Shirebrook base, the committee insisted on a public Westminster session and offered multiple dates, none of which he accepted. Wright’s letter gives Ashley until 21 March to agree to attend, warning the committee may seek House of Commons support over potential contempt if he refuses. Sports Direct did not comment to the BBC, though it has previously pledged to review worker rights under Ashley’s oversight.

Colleagues of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin, completed his unfinished report “Putin. War,” compiling existing media evidence to argue that President Vladimir Putin orchestrated and directed the war in eastern Ukraine for political gain. The report claims Russian regular troops, equipment, and generals were decisive in rebel victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, contradicting Moscow’s assertion that only volunteers are involved; it cites soldiers’ admissions, documented unit details, weapon photos, and accounts of paid volunteers earning $2,000–3,000 a month. It estimates Russia’s spending at 53 billion roubles and notes Nemtsov began the work after learning relatives of dead soldiers were denied promised compensation, though many remain too afraid to speak publicly. Despite a limited initial print run and publishers’ reluctance, the opposition seeks wider distribution, while acknowledging many Russians accept the intervention as support for separatists. The report concludes Putin used the war to revive his popularity, and, like Nemtsov’s prior exposés on corruption and the Sochi Olympics’ costs, it may not galvanize significant protest.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday; a post-mortem determined he died from head injuries, and a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

The passage discusses tensions between the UK and Welsh governments over the handling of the Article 50 letter, with Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones criticizing not being consulted or shown the letter before publication, calling it part of a pattern of disrespect toward devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns counters that discussions have been ongoing and the UK government must act for the whole UK, noting Wales was referenced. Theresa May’s letter to Donald Tusk promises full consultation on which repatriated powers should go to Westminster versus devolved governments, expecting a significant increase in devolved decision-making, but specifics remain unclear. Questions persist over which powers (e.g., farming, economic aid) will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them after 2020, with Jones fearing a funding shortfall and some Whitehall voices arguing for Westminster control over EU-related funds. Further details might come in a Great Repeal Bill white paper, but the exact powers to be devolved are still a mystery.

Two cars were damaged during an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead areas of Newry on Friday night, where police officers carrying out duties were attacked. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the “mindless attacks” on PSNI officers and the Newry community, and a PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post appealed to parents to be aware of their children’s whereabouts and activities.

American Apparel’s board, in a San Francisco court filing, asserted that ousted founder and former CEO Mr Charney, removed the previous year over employee complaints and alleged misuse of company funds, is not expected to return due to documented misconduct, including illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts that violated company harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The filing responds to Charney’s defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. Charney’s lawyer denied the allegations, calling the company’s actions an invasion of privacy and extortion. The board argued rehiring him would pose unacceptable risk to the company and shareholders, and earlier in the month the firm obtained a restraining order barring Charney from making negative public statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app will stream Great Britain’s only home game before FIBA EuroBasket 2017, a rematch against Greece at the Copper Box, where Greece recently won 92-64 in Patras. Greece will be missing three players, giving GB a chance at revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, a Stratford native, expects a great atmosphere and says the game is vital preparation. After facing Greece, coach Joe Prunty’s team will play a four-team tournament in Poland before EuroBasket begins in early September in Istanbul. Coverage runs 17:30-19:30 BST on both platforms.

A journalist recalls the 2007 iPhone unveiling, securing brief on-camera access to Phil Schiller’s device for a BBC segment that drew criticism for promoting a product. He defended coverage by arguing truly transformative products merit attention, a view he later felt validated as smartphones proved revolutionary, putting powerful computing in billions of hands and reshaping industries, notably photography through instant, high-quality mobile capture and sharing enabled by intuitive interfaces. While earlier phones offered cameras and internet, Steve Jobs’s focus on user experience sparked the mobile connected era; today, firms like Amazon and Google advance AI-driven innovations, but that January morning in San Francisco marked the turning point.

Multiple cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting a toxic substance confirmed by tests, with seven-month-old Meereen dying on Monday from antifreeze poisoning. In total, three cats died in the past week and another two weeks earlier. Meereen’s owner described the cat’s rapid decline after returning home unwell. The RSPCA says it is unclear if the poisonings are accidental or deliberate and urges residents to securely store chemicals and check for car antifreeze leaks and clean up spills, especially at this time of year.

Despite impending austerity and liberalization measures under a third €86bn bailout, Athens sees no street protests and tourism is booming, with airport arrivals rising from 21m to 25m. Greeks may be awaiting details of Alexis Tsipras’s concessions, which follow July’s near-collapse that pushed Syriza to accept “there is no alternative.” Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and compounding it with monetary austerity from semi-closed banks, threatening business credit and even holiday retail orders. Greece faces a severe squeeze that will deepen poverty, and the bailout’s success hinges on offering hope—likely requiring substantial debt relief of one-third to one-half, with Brussels and especially Berlin eschewing triumphalism and granting real forgiveness.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell to reunite the Mitchell family for Peggy’s final episodes after Dame Barbara Windsor’s character revealed her cancer had returned and would lead to her death in emotional scenes airing in spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990–1999 and in 2005–2006, said he couldn’t turn down the chance to be there for Barbara and to reunite Grant with Phil. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins called Grant an EastEnders legend and said the storyline will showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best as the brothers face losing their mother, revisiting classic relationships and family drama.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon, 26, who had become obsessed with and stalked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles, fatally attacked her in October; despite denying murder, he was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Her parents, Sue Hills and Prof Clive Ruggles, recalled police informing them of her death and their immediate belief Dhillon was responsible. Dr Hills expressed guilt for having reassured Alice and dismissed another daughter Emma’s warning shortly before the killing, while Prof Ruggles said none of them, including Alice, realized the severity of the threat. In response, they founded the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking, hoping Alice will be remembered for her vibrant, smiling, and cheeky personality.

EDF’s board approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear project in Somerset, with contracts due to be signed, but the UK government unexpectedly announced a further review, prompting EDF’s CEO to cancel a site visit and raising doubts about policy direction post-Brexit. The project, expected to supply 7% of UK electricity, is backed one-third by Chinese investors and touted by EDF as a major Franco-British industrial asset, yet faces criticism over environmental impact, high consumer costs, foreign government involvement, and EDF’s financial strain—highlighted by executive resignations and a €4bn share issue. Industry figures urge a swift decision to secure energy supplies and climate goals, while environmental groups argue it’s poor value versus renewables. Key milestones include UK support for nuclear since 2006, construction approval in 2013, a guaranteed £92.50/MWh strike price, a 2015 EDF-CGN investment deal, and the 2016 board approval followed by the UK’s delay to autumn.

A new online divorce application form in England and Wales explicitly asks for the name of a spouse’s alleged adultery partner, prompting concern from family lawyers that naming third parties adds conflict, complexity, delays, and cost. Although the Ministry of Justice stresses there is no obligation to name anyone and the guidance says it is “not normally necessary,” lawyers warn the prominent prompt may encourage petitioners—often acting without legal advice—to include names, which then makes the third party part of the case. Practitioners note judges disapprove of dragging new partners into proceedings and advise against it despite many clients’ urges. In 2015 there were just over 100,000 divorces, with 12,148 citing adultery and 46,815 citing unreasonable behaviour. The MoJ says it has always been possible to name the alleged partner and that the new form clarifies this while emphasizing it is optional.

Wales’ forestry sector, worth over £450m annually, faces tension between environmental priorities and commercial timber needs. Confor warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and must be replanted, noting Britain is the world’s third-largest wood importer and that current planting (90 hectares last year) falls far short of the 20,000 hectares per year ministers’ long-term targets require. While half of Welsh woodland is managed by Natural Resources Wales and half by private firms, commercial operations face challenges including hard-to-reach forests, harvesting difficulties, and conflicts over timber transport. Ministers promote a balance of environmental, economic, and social goals via strategies like Woodlands for Wales and the Glastir scheme, favoring native broadleaf species and public access, but Confor argues policy and bureaucracy overemphasize environmental aspects at the expense of timber supply despite strong market demand.

A boy was badly injured after being struck on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge around 16:40; emergency services responded and he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Russian defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko awarded Ushakov medals to surviving veterans of the WWII Arctic Convoys, including 91-year-old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, who described the missions—once called by Churchill “the worst journey on earth”—as simply doing their duty. The convoys, which ran from Britain to northern Russia under extreme weather and constant German attack, cost 104 merchant ships, 16 military vessels, and over 3,000 lives by May 1945. After the Russian Embassy proposed the Ushakov medal in 2012, the UK Foreign Office initially blocked it due to rules on foreign awards given long after service; despite the UK creating the Arctic Star in 2012, campaigners sought the Russian honor. An exception was granted in 2013, with President Putin presenting the first medals in London, recognizing the convoys’ vital role in arming the Soviet Union and symbolizing the wartime alliance.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found significant failings in England and Wales’ unpaid work (“community payback”) scheme, including delays starting placements, poor enforcement of attendance, and offenders being turned away despite reporting on time; one offender completed only 16 hours in 17 months. While inspectors noted some high-quality projects, skill gains, and generally positive attitudes among many offenders, they concluded the system often treats unpaid work merely as punishment, missing rehabilitation opportunities. The report, based on 100 cases and 86 interviews, made 15 recommendations, including reducing turnaways and tailoring objectives to offenders’ circumstances. The Ministry of Justice accepted all its recommendations and pledged action to ensure punctual attendance and meaningful consequences for non-compliance, amid longstanding organisational challenges in managing a cohort with complex needs.

A newspaper labeled comedian Russell Brand a hypocrite for advocating economic and political “revolution” while living in a luxury London home, a charge often repeated and highlighted during a confrontation with a TV reporter about his rent. Brand, who has shown his spacious home in his vlogs, criticized the media’s focus and tweeted under #TheSunLogic but didn’t confirm legal action. In past statements, he acknowledges his wealth and past excesses, admits he must change personally and share wealth, but argues that without systemic change individual gestures are futile. He maintains that calling him a hypocrite is a distraction from genuine issues of inequality and ecological crisis that need addressing.

The passage profiles Dr. J. Craig Venter, a bold and controversial biologist-entrepreneur who accelerated genomics by pioneering rapid gene sequencing methods, challenging scientific norms, and spearheading private efforts. After early struggles and transformative service in Vietnam, he excelled in research at NIH, adopting automation and shifting focus from DNA to RNA to speed discovery, which drew criticism and led him to found The Institute for Genomic Research. He produced the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995 and, through Celera Genomics, raced the public project to publish the human genome in 2001. Wealth from these ventures enabled independent projects, including forming the J. Craig Venter Institute, creating the synthetic organism “Synthia,” and an oceanic expedition (Sorcerer II) to catalog microbial diversity. Though often vilified for perceived disregard of open science and for his self-promotion, Venter’s work significantly hastened genomics and he envisions synthetic microbes driving a new industrial revolution by producing alternatives to oil and capturing CO2.

An online survey of about 1,000 English parents, commissioned by the School Food Trust, found that among the 628 with children eating school lunches, four in five said their child had tried foods at school they hadn’t tried at home, and half reported children asking for school foods to be cooked at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. Trust and Mumsnet leaders noted that school meals, now governed by strict nutritional standards and offering healthier variety, can help children expand their diets through positive peer influence. Around 40% of primary pupils in England eat school lunches (slightly fewer in secondary), compared with about 46% in Scotland. The survey ran online from 26 February to 5 March among parents of children aged 4–17.

Alvaro Morata, 23, a 6ft 3in striker playing for Spain at Euro 2016, moved from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014 with a Real buy-back option reportedly up to €30m (£23m). Linked previously with Arsenal and Chelsea, he has scored three times for Spain in France. At Juventus he netted 27 goals over two seasons, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in consecutive Champions League finals—coming on as a substitute in Real’s 2014 win and scoring in Juventus’ 2015 loss to Barcelona. A Real academy product, he debuted for their first team at 18 and scored 10 goals for the club.

Wilson, 30, rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 and made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground; released in May, he is currently without a team. He previously spent four seasons at Forest before moving to Celtic and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world’s third-largest retailer, is exiting the US by transferring about 200 Fresh & Easy stores and roughly 4,000 of its 5,000 employees to Los Angeles-based private equity firm Yucaipa, while about 50 remaining stores will be closed. The Fresh & Easy chain, which has lost money since its 2007 launch across California, Nevada, and Arizona, will cost Tesco £150m to dispose of, including an approximately £80m loan to the new business that may be repaid. Tesco describes the move as an orderly and efficient exit, retains an option to buy a stake if Yucaipa turns the business profitable, and this comes after Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years.

An athlete who initially faced racial abuse describes to BBC Sport’s Nick Hope how he overcame it, briefly considered competing for France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, with a note pointing readers to a guide on getting into martial arts.

Research presented at the AGU Fall Meeting shows French Alps glacier area has shrunk from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to roughly 275 sq km in the late 2000s—an average 26% loss over 40 years, with acceleration since the mid-1980s (after a brief advance in the late 70s/early 80s). The new inventory by Marie Gardent (University of Savoie) covers ~600 glaciers across massifs including Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves, and Mont Blanc, using historical maps, satellite images, aerial photos, and manual checks to correct for debris and shadow errors. Retreat is stronger in the southern Alps—glaciers nearly gone in Belledonne and losses over three times greater in Ecrins than Mont Blanc—likely due to lower elevations and drier, clearer climate, while the wetter, cloudier north retains more ice; La Mer de Glace on Mont Blanc is just over 30 sq km today, down slightly from 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s. These findings mirror accelerating glacier mass loss reported elsewhere in the Alps.

Scotland’s women, unbeaten with five qualifying wins, host fellow unbeaten Iceland at Falkirk in a likely group-decider, with a return match in Reykjavik on 20 September; victory would all but secure Scotland’s first major finals and they are also well placed to qualify as one of the best runners-up. Forward Lisa Evans, mindful of past play-off heartbreak for Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup, stresses focus and the boost of home support, noting Iceland are top seeds and ranked one place higher (20). Evans highlights the squad’s growing overseas experience—12 of 20 play abroad, including players in England, Sweden, the NWSL’s Seattle Reign with Kim Little, and her own Bayern Munich side—arguing exposure to elite leagues, especially Germany’s competitive Bundesliga, is elevating Scotland’s level.

Stuart Campbell, a pro-Scottish independence blogger behind Wings Over Scotland, was arrested in the west of England following a south London woman’s complaint alleging two years of online harassment. Released on bail pending further inquiries until mid-September, Campbell said the matter concerns tweets from his account, emphasized that none were threatening, and criticized media coverage for encouraging speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment reported by a woman in her 30s. Campbell, who lives in Bath and was born in Stirling, noted he would be posting less frequently due to circumstances beyond his control.

Peta urged Skegness to replace its Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish-themed “A Happy Plaice” to promote an animal-friendly image, arguing Jolly symbolizes cruelty associated with fishing. The mayor, Carl Macey, welcomed suggestions but doubted support for dropping Jolly, emphasizing the mascot’s long-loved status and denying it promotes cruelty. The Jolly Fisherman originated from a 1908 Great Northern Railway poster, “Skegness is so bracing,” and has become synonymous with the resort. Peta says a new mascot would rebrand Skegness as progressive, while the mayor says the current mascot works well and change isn’t needed.

Georgia struck first through Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland dominated thereafter, surging ahead before half-time with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try after Kote Mikautadze collapsed a maul (earning a yellow card), Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg, all supplemented by Greig Laidlaw’s conversions and a penalty amid overwhelming possession. Hamish Watson powered over early in the second half to make it 38-11, before Georgia replied via a dominant scrum that produced Lobzhanidze’s second, and Scotland’s Moray Low was sin-binned for scrum infringements. Scotland finished strongly as debutant Ali Price sparked a length-of-the-field move for Hogg’s second and Scotland’s sixth. Coach Vern Cotter praised Scotland’s first-half control, game management, and Laidlaw’s leadership, noting execution dipped in the wet second half but the team managed the game pragmatically. Line-ups for both teams were listed.

Widnes beat Castleford 38-30 after leading 14-6 at half-time through tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge, with Cas loanee Paddy Flynn replying and later completing a hat-trick. Early second-half scores from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor extended Widnes’ lead to 26 points, but a late Castleford surge with tries from Larne Patrick and Luke Gale plus Flynn’s third made for a tense finish. The result gave Castleford a fourth straight home league defeat and moved Widnes up to seventh, one point behind sixth-placed Castleford. Line-ups and referee: Castleford (Solomona, Monaghan, Crooks, Webster, Flynn, McShane, Gale, Jewitt, Milner, Patrick, Moors, McMeeken, Massey; subs Millington, Springer, Tickle, Cook); Widnes (Hanbury, Thompson, Runciman, Bridge, Ah Van, Mellor, Brown, Cahill, White, Buchanan, Whitley, Dean, Leuluai; subs J. Chapelhow, Manuokafoa, Walker, Heremaia); Referee: J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detained at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 after being arrested in Pakistan for alleged links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban—which he denies—was released following a US Periodic Review Board decision that he no longer posed a continuing significant threat. He had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court and returned to Kuwait on a government plane, where he will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation centre under the release terms. His lawyer reported he felt excitement and joy, without bitterness. The Kuwaiti government had advocated for the release of its detainees. Al-Odah said he had traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. He is the first Guantanamo inmate freed since a May prisoner swap involving five Taliban detainees for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl, reducing the facility’s population to 148. The US opened Guantanamo in January 2002, and President Obama has repeatedly pledged to close it.

The passage profiles the viral rise of “PPAP (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen),” a minute-long earworm performed by Piko-Taro, a fictional character by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, featuring a simple beat, absurd lyrics, and an easy dance. First posted on YouTube, it spread rapidly to Facebook, where 9GAG’s upload topped 44 million views versus the original’s 4 million, eliciting reactions ranging from amused obsession to irritation. Viewers commented on Piko-Taro’s flamboyant wardrobe, and while the song gained major international traction, it saw limited coverage and trend status in Japan. The phenomenon spurred numerous tributes and covers—including from Japanese celebrities, a heavy metal version, and Thai star Happy Polla—prompting comparisons to Psy and speculation that it was engineered to become a global meme.

Anzac Day in London was marked by a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner attended by thousands, followed by a parade of up to 400 people and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, with additional commemorations at Westminster Abbey where the New Zealand and Australian national anthems were sung. The day honors the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps’ role in World War One, particularly the 1915 Gallipoli landings during an eight-month, bloody campaign aimed at pushing the Ottoman Empire out of the war. First commemorated in the capital in 1916 with King George V’s attendance, Anzac Day has become a key occasion for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to remember sacrifices in all wars. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer paid tribute to the courage and heroism of the Anzacs, while veterans, service personnel, families, and schoolchildren participated in prayers and ceremonies.

Clarkson, 30, rejoined Premiership side Well in July and is set for a potential St Mirren debut against Alloa on Saturday in the Championship. After scoring nine goals for Dundee last season, he has mainly been a substitute this term but says he is fully fit, maintaining match sharpness through U20 games and training. Capped twice by Scotland in 2008 with one goal and nearly 400 senior club appearances, his previous clubs include Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren sit eighth, seven points above bottom Alloa, and Clarkson aims to help the team build confidence, go on a winning run, and climb the table.

Bernard Matthews, the turkey firm, was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, whose Boparan Private Office confirmed existing pension arrangements will continue; Unite said the final salary scheme closed in 2004 and current alternative pensions are unaffected. After talks, Unite received guarantees that all current agreements will be honored. The new owner aims to restore profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkey.

At a council scrutiny meeting about problems with a new chain ferry launched on 14 May, leader Dave Stewart announced free crossings at Cowes until 2 July to acknowledge issues and gather feedback, and said auditors would review the project after a frustrating start marked by breakdowns, a grounding, an MCA suspension over training, and vehicle damage on the ramps. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth warned of severe business losses and asked about compensation, which transport councillor Ian Ward said was under discussion. Ward characterized the ferry as a prototype with expected teething issues, noted electrical faults had been fixed, ramp extensions were authorized to prevent vehicle scraping, and grounding problems attributed to seamanship had been resolved.

A House of Lords EU Committee report warns that while UK fishing communities—strong Brexit supporters—see leaving the CFP as a chance to regain control of waters and grow exports, the sector risks being sidelined due to its small economic footprint. Most UK fish are exported to the EU and many eaten in Britain are imported, so continued tariff-free market access is vital and may require allowing EU boats access to UK waters. The report urges retaining CFP elements like science-based quotas and cooperation with neighbors, and flags potential fragmentation into four UK fisheries regimes post-Brexit. Despite concerns, recent CFP quota increases for key species buoy industry optimism about post-Brexit control of the 200-mile zone, while the government pledges to secure maximum single-market access and review fisheries for fair quotas, sustainability, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or permitting indecent images between April 2004 and February 2014 and was earlier placed on a community payback order, required to attend a sex offender program, and added to the sex offenders register. A General Teaching Council for Scotland hearing found his conduct—mostly involving images of partially dressed young boys—fundamentally incompatible with teaching, noting the long duration, volume of images, and lack of remedial action indicated a pattern and risk of recurrence. He was deemed unfit to teach, removed from the teaching register, barred from reapplying for two years, and did not attend the hearing; he was 69 at sentencing.

A fire on 2 March at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site led to days of firefighting, reduced train services, and travel delays. Although Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) said the site operators, Asset and Land Group, were broadly compliant with fire safety law and had been visited nine times in the past year, GMFRS raised concerns in February about risks to residents, transport, and the environment. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the firm from accepting waste after the blaze and, after joint visits and reviewing the facts, decided to revoke the site’s environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed. After that date the company cannot operate there but must remove all waste. The cause of the fire is undetermined, and the company could not be reached for comment.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said Syria is striving to meet its chemical weapons destruction timetable despite missing a deadline and facing attacks on shipments en route to Latakia, asserting commitment to OPCW and UN obligations. He rejected US accusations over barrel bomb use in Aleppo, denying strikes on civilians and alleging US support for “terrorists,” while activists and the Syrian Observatory reported heavy civilian deaths from barrel bombs and claimed rebels seized Aleppo’s central prison, a claim the government denied. Syria has declared about 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons; the US says only about 4% has been removed, prompting concern from US officials, while Russia urged Syria to complete coastal transfers by 1 March and the OPCW acknowledged security delays, with an overall destruction deadline by end of June.

England leveled the series against Pakistan with a dominant win at Old Trafford, declaring at 589-8 and 173-1 to set up their second-biggest victory over Pakistan by runs, as Pakistan were dismissed for 198 and 234. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was man of the match with 254 and an unbeaten 71, four catches, and a wicket, drawing praise from captain Alastair Cook and coach Trevor Bayliss for his controlled, corrective batting after errors in the first Test. Commentators Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott lauded England’s complete performance, calling it an “absolute hammering,” while predicting England’s strength would tell, though Vaughan expects a tight series. Pakistan’s batting struggled, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 across the first two Tests; Misbah admitted poor shot selection and low confidence, hoping for a response before the third Test at Edgbaston after a two-day tour match at Worcestershire.

Wales’s Older People’s Commissioner, Sarah Rochira, is gathering testimonies from pensioners, their families, and care stakeholders to review the quality of life and care in Welsh residential homes, aiming to produce recommendations for providers and public bodies. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, highlighting both good practice and the harms of poor care amid reported regional variations. While the commissioner emphasizes giving older people a voice and ensuring accountable services act on real-life experiences, Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but criticizes the absence of a provider expert or individuals with direct care home experience on the main advisory panel, calling it a missed opportunity for partnership.

Paul Sheerin, 39, former Aberdeen midfielder and player-manager of Arbroath since 2010, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen after Derek McInnes selected him through a comprehensive process. Despite Arbroath’s relegation to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013–14, chairman John Christison cooperated with Sheerin’s move, acknowledging his desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin’s playing career included several Scottish clubs and Sweden’s Östersunds, and he earned a Scotland U21 cap in the mid-1990s. As Arbroath manager, he led the club to its first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

After Bob Bradley’s sacking, Alan Curtis and assistant Paul Williams will lead Swansea against Bournemouth while the club seeks a swift appointment, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement the top target. Curtis stresses the need for a manager to steer them clear of relegation, warning that dropping to the Championship—now stronger—would not guarantee a quick return, unlike clubs with greater resources like Newcastle. Reflecting on Swansea’s rise from near bankruptcy to Premier League status in 2011, Curtis says the club has “lost its way” since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 departure due to frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements, diluting the “Swansea Way.” He maintains the current squad can survive and ensures new signings understand the club’s journey and the importance of staying up for the club and the community.

The passage profiles biologist-entrepreneur J. Craig Venter, highlighting his controversial but transformative role in genomics: after accelerating gene sequencing via RNA-focused methods and automation at NIH, he founded The Institute for Genomic Research, produced the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995, and then launched Celera Genomics in 1998 to race the public project to sequence the human genome, with both publishing in 2001. Criticized for challenging scientific norms and commercializing data, Venter nonetheless leveraged his wealth to pursue ambitious projects, notably creating a synthetic organism (“Synthia”) at the J. Craig Venter Institute and conducting global oceanic microbial genome surveys aboard Sorcerer II. Shaped by formative experiences in Vietnam that instilled urgency, he argues synthetic microbes could drive a new industrial revolution by enabling targeted bioproduction, reducing oil dependence, and helping mitigate climate change through carbon capture.

A Sutton Trust report, conducted with Boston Consulting Group, warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality, too short, and skewed toward older workers, with fewer than 200,000 of 520,000 annual starts at level three (A-level equivalent) and only 61,000 new starts for young people. Compared with Germany—where 51% of employers offer apprenticeships, 570,000 go to youngsters, and 90% are A-level equivalent—only 20% of English employers offer them, the system has 18,000 fragmented qualifications versus Germany’s 330, and 11 young people compete for each place. Since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships have been below level three and three-quarters aimed at over-25s. The Trust calls for up to 300,000 new starts annually, prioritizing three-year level three and some level four programs, limiting level two to 10%, and improving quality, facilities, teaching, and careers advice. While the Association of Colleges supports prioritizing level three, it urges preserving respected level two courses (e.g., construction) and notes employer uptake is a major challenge. The Department for Education says it is reforming apprenticeships to raise standards, including minimum one-year duration, stronger English and maths, and forthcoming further plans.

British Paralympian Sarah Storey won in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska, and can chase a 17th title in Saturday’s road race. The 37-year-old, Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian, has 22 Paralympic medals (11 gold, eight silver, three bronze) across six Games in swimming and cycling, including four golds at London 2012, and a total of 21 world titles. She began in swimming with six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005, and is targeting further success at Rio 2016.

Hereford United were expelled from the Conference after repeatedly failing to meet extended deadlines to pay £148,000 owed to football creditors, despite a late-season on-field escape and a takeover by Tommy Agombar. Chester, previously relegated on the final day, were reinstated to the Conference Premier, while Hayes & Yeading remained in Conference South. Financial woes included total debts around £225,000, over £70,000 owed to HMRC, unpaid wages prompting a winding-up petition by former boss Martin Foyle, and falling attendances since relegation from the Football League in 2012. A £1 rescue bid by the Hereford United Supporters’ Trust was not accepted, players departed amid unpaid salary issues, and the Conference—after multiple deadline extensions—acted on 10 June to remove the club, with critics stating Hereford had only themselves to blame.

James Milner, 30, has retired from England duty after earning 61 senior caps since his 2009 debut. He featured in squads for two World Cups and two European Championships, but played only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner, who wished Sam Allardyce and the team well, is also England’s most-capped Under-21 player with 46 appearances since 2004, and scored his sole senior international goal in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a pioneering conductor of the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness; his funeral will be private with a later memorial service. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it globally for about 30 years, producing over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a famed 1980 Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson. Trained as a keyboardist at Cambridge and with noted teachers, he began with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and co-founded the Early Music Consort of London. He served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and held academic posts at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, scholarship, and lasting legacy, noting his influence on leading players worldwide.

A Northern Ireland boy was withdrawn from mainstream school in June due to difficulties, and despite his parents requesting a special school place, they were told in September that all special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full with no timeframe for a placement. His mother left her job to care for him and says he feels isolated and confused as his siblings attend school. The family has since been told an extra classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, offering hope he can start within weeks, but they worry other families will face similar capacity issues. The Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case, citing privacy, and said it is reviewing special school needs to ensure places near children’s homes, with work ongoing to assist placements from 2016.

Newport County hold a contract giving them use of Rodney Parade with Football League fixture primacy until 2023, and chairman Gavin Foxall expects it to be honored amid a Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) takeover bid for fellow tenants Newport Gwent Dragons, which goes to a shareholder vote on 9 May. Newport RFC’s chair Will Godfrey says County and Newport Squash Club are protected under existing agreements, and the WRU has been informed, though the WRU’s plan to install an artificial surface conflicts with Football League rules. On the field, County sit two points above the League Two drop with two games left after an upturn under caretaker Mike Flynn and could secure safety this weekend with a win and a Hartlepool loss; Foxall warned relegation back to the National League would be a massive blow for fans and the city.

A former child soldier from Sierra Leone recounts being abducted by RUF rebels at 15, brutalized, drugged, and forced into violence during the civil war, before escaping to Freetown, where imprisonment led him to a preacher and the Lifeline Nehemiah project that helped rebuild his life through education and faith. After the Ebola outbreak in 2014, he and his team transformed their clinic to fight the “common enemy,” focusing on community education in local languages, large-scale food support, and partnering to establish an Ebola treatment unit despite scarce funds, saving many lives amid fear and stigma. He expresses remorse for past actions, commitment to nation rebuilding, and a belief in investing in youth. The passage notes the country was declared virus-free after 18 months, with Ebola death totals of 11,314 overall: 4,808 in Liberia, 3,955 in Sierra Leone, 2,536 in Guinea, 8 in Nigeria, plus one in the US and six in Mali.

A public fundraising campaign led by the Art Fund raised enough money in a month to prevent about 80,000 Wedgwood artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from being auctioned to cover pension debts stemming from Waterford Wedgwood’s 2009 collapse. Administrators Begbies Traynor confirmed the collection will stay on display at the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, after being gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum and loaned back. Following legal rulings that allowed a sale to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund and the museum’s own administration in 2010, the successful campaign averted the collection being dispersed worldwide. Figures involved, including administrator Bob Young, Alison Wedgwood, and MP Tristram Hunt, hailed the outcome as vital for Staffordshire and for preserving a significant part of Britain’s cultural heritage.

Dan Groves said details are pending on a deal for Mark Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town, with The Sun claiming the 30-year-old would become a club director. The Isthmian League Premier Division side sit eighth, three points off the play-offs. Wright, runner-up in I’m A Celebrity in 2011, previously played non-league for clubs including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay were recently bought by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week, and they signed 35-year-old ex-England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mark Carney, expected either to leave as planned in 2018 or stay until 2021, chose a “third way” to extend his term as Bank of England governor by one year to 2019. While some speculated political pressure or disillusionment post‑Brexit, Carney emphasized the decision was entirely personal, driven by family considerations—two daughters finishing key exams in 2018 and a desire to return to Canada—while ensuring he would not depart in the middle of Brexit negotiations. Officials deny tensions with the Prime Minister or that criticism of pre‑referendum forecasts influenced him. The plan allows Carney to help stabilize the economy through Article 50, after which a new governor will take over.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso set up Jamille Matt to score from close range. Colchester equalised five minutes later through Kurtis Guthrie following a corner and goalmouth scramble. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made several key saves, notably from Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi, while Guthrie also hit the bar before halftime. Tom Aldred missed a late chance to win it for Blackpool, heading wide from eight yards. Colchester ended with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for violent conduct in stoppage time.

Action Mental Health’s “Healthy Me” programme for P6 and P7 pupils in Northern Ireland uses interactive workshops to build emotional wellbeing, resilience, and coping skills for the stresses of transfer tests and the move to secondary school. Piloted in five schools and launched at Carrick Primary School in Lurgan, it encourages help-seeking, identifies support sources, teaches relaxation and breathing exercises, and provides basic teacher training in promoting wellbeing. Chief executive David Babington says the initiative targets a particularly stressful transition, amid rising transfer test participation (14,681 entrants vs 14,575 in 2015). Carrick’s pastoral lead Helen Hamilton notes pupil and parent anxieties about moving to secondary, emphasizing the need to meet social-emotional needs for learning. Chief inspector Noelle Buick’s recent report also calls for strengthening youth resilience through more explicit preventative education in the pastoral care curriculum.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to transform the disused Fawley power station site into a £1bn “merchant city” centered on converting its 198m chimney—the tallest such attraction south of The Shard—into a petal-shaped glass landmark, alongside a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The oil-fired station, commissioned in 1971 on the western shore of Southampton Water, once produced 2,000 MW—enough for one million homes—with a 198m chimney and 1,100 miles of internal cabling, and closed in 2013 after over 40 years. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside in 2016, with outline planning expected later this year and construction potentially starting in 2018; the developer argues retaining the chimney offers a cost-effective, iconic centerpiece comparable to Brighton’s i360 or Portsmouth’s Spinnaker Tower.

At the Hong Kong track cycling World Championships, 23-year-old Ollie Latham won bronze in the men’s scratch race—GB’s second medal after Elinor Barker’s silver in the women’s scratch—finishing behind Poland’s Adrian Teklinski (gold) and Germany’s Lucas Liss (silver). Latham credited smart positioning behind Felix English for his late sprint, earning praise from Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy for his timing and energy conservation, while noting Teklinski’s long, gutsy sprint. GB missed medals in both team pursuits: the men lost the bronze ride to Italy, and the women’s young squad, boosted by Barker, placed fifth but were encouraged by their progress and potential. Joe Truman exited in the men’s keirin semi-final, and Katy Marchant, GB’s sole female sprinter, was eliminated in the first round after qualifying 16th; she cited post-Rio form and will race the 500m time trial and keirin later in the week.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell to support the storyline of Dame Barbara Windsor’s character, Peggy, who has returned to reveal her cancer has come back and will die in emotional scenes this spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990–1999 and in 2005–2006, said he couldn’t turn down reuniting the Mitchell family for Peggy’s final episodes, citing his close friendship with Windsor. Producers highlight the reunion of Grant and Phil (Steve McFadden) as a chance to showcase the actors and revisit classic dynamics, including Grant’s past entanglements with Kathy and Sharon. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins called Grant’s return a homecoming to say goodbye to his mother and reconnect with old loves and his brother.

After a 2-0 defeat at Liverpool in which Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds, Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team’s lack of desire and inability to handle pressure, warning that if Chelsea go 12 points clear it will be a major problem. He noted Spurs’ poor away form since late September—only two wins—and a broader struggle against top-six teams away, with just one win in their last 17 such matches. Pochettino said the first-half display showed a team not ready to fight for the Premier League. Pundit Danny Murphy added that Spurs’ defensive setup was wrong, arguing they should have kept a back three against a big side, and highlighted their stark drop-off in pace and mindset away from home.

Nigeria’s All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared governorships, dealing the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) its biggest setback since 1999 and reinforcing its loss of last month’s presidential election to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who takes office on 29 May. The PDP lost key northern states such as Katsina, Kaduna, and Adamawa but retained Rivers, while winning eight governorships mainly in the south-east; Taraba’s result was pending and Imo’s was inconclusive, with elections not held in seven states. Analysts say the APC achieved historic nationwide gains—including Lagos—while the PDP’s support narrowed to the south-east and Niger Delta; however, the APC failed to capture any of the five oil-producing states, posing revenue and security challenges for the incoming president amid potential militant disruption. Though marred by 66 reported violent incidents, especially in southern states like Rivers, the polls were overall more peaceful than previous years. The PDP, hurt by defections, corruption allegations, and its handling of the Boko Haram insurgency, faces introspection and rebuilding after 16 years in power.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) is introducing an augmented reality app that lets visitors scan signs and posters to access videos, band interviews, instant information, and ticket purchasing on phones and tablets; the content will be updated before and during the event and will also allow people worldwide to experience the festival. This year’s lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

Ofsted rated several Birmingham schools inadequate amid the “Trojan Horse” allegations, prompting the Department for Education to move to terminate funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary and warn Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock they could lose funding unless specified breaches are swiftly fixed. Letters from education minister Lord Nash cited failures in safeguarding, promoting pupils’ spiritual, moral, social and cultural development, and concerns including unvetted extremist speakers, segregation, and less favorable treatment of non‑Muslims; trusts were given until 4 July to respond and implement actions for a broader, balanced curriculum. A head teacher described intimidation by some parents and feeling isolated until the scandal surfaced. Birmingham City Council plans interim governance at Saltley School, the only council‑run school in special measures. Park View’s trust said it would legally challenge Ofsted and noted termination could remove it from running three schools. Ofsted’s chief said a culture of fear had taken hold, while some parents rejected the findings as biased and sought an open meeting with the education secretary.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, 38, was sentenced in Iran to five years’ imprisonment on undisclosed charges linked to allegedly plotting to topple the government; her appeal is being held in secret in Tehran, with no family attendance and an unpredictable outcome that could quash, reduce, or increase the sentence. Detained since April after her arrest at Tehran Airport, she spent time in solitary confinement, attempted a hunger strike, and felt suicidal, but has shown renewed resolve since being moved out of solitary over Christmas. Her two-year-old daughter Gabriella remains in Iran with grandparents after her passport was confiscated, has largely lost her English, and communicates mainly in Farsi; husband Richard Ratcliffe, who believes Nazanin is a diplomatic bargaining chip, is seeking a visa to visit and has criticized the UK’s lack of action. Amnesty International calls her a prisoner of conscience and hopes the appeal orders her immediate release.

Vinnie Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. At Ipswich Crown Court, prosecutors alleged that optometrist Honey Rose, 35, from Newham, east London, committed gross negligence manslaughter by failing to detect Vinnie’s swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. They argued that a buildup of fluid in his brain raised intracranial pressure, leading to his death, which they claim was preventable had Rose met the standard of a competent optometrist. Rose denies the charge, and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he sourced via an adult website and filming the encounters between September 2013 and September 2014; he also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim’s sister on Christmas Day 2014, intentionally caused the sister and father to view sexual images, and behaved threateningly or abusively. Assessed as a moderate risk of sexual re-offending and placed on the sex offenders register, his case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. The victim said she felt blackmailed; Judge Lady Wolffe said the sentence must reflect society’s abhorrence, and defence counsel noted Weatherhogg, a first offender, was shocked by being remanded before sentencing.

Afghanistan beat Ireland by six wickets in a T20 in Greater Noida, chasing 165-5 with 171-4 and two overs to spare. Ireland’s Stuart Thompson top-scored with 56, supported by Gary Wilson (41 not out) and captain William Porterfield (39), after losing Paul Stirling for a duck. Afghanistan’s chase was set up by Mohammad Shahzad (47), Najeeb Tarakai (27), and sealed by Samiullah Shenwari (56), while spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the only multiple-wicket haul. Porterfield felt Ireland were 15 runs short and didn’t execute well with the ball. Ireland were also without pacer Boyd Rankin for the T20s due to a back issue, though he is expected back for the ODIs starting 15 March. The teams meet again at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona maintained it committed no offense in Neymar’s transfer but filed a complementary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover differing interpretations of related contracts, while insisting its original tax payment met obligations. The club initially stated it paid €57m (£48.6m) for Neymar, though allegations suggest the true cost—including fees, wages, and taxes—totals £106.8m, with €34m going to Neymar’s parents. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation accusations and is under investigation, and a judge has allowed the probe into the transfer to continue. It is unclear if Barcelona’s payment will end the case. Neymar, 22, has scored seven goals in 18 league matches and three in seven Champions League games this season.

UK Metropolitan Police officers who traveled to Thailand to review the Koh Tao murders of British tourists David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, have completed their work and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families. Thai authorities are holding two Myanmar migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, who allegedly confessed and are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, facing a potential death penalty; Thai police deny reports the confessions were withdrawn and say DNA from Ms Witheridge matches the suspects. The UK Foreign Office previously raised concerns about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects, prompting the UK police visit after an agreement between the Thai prime minister and David Cameron. Post-mortems found Mr Miller died from drowning and a head blow, and Ms Witheridge from head wounds.

The passage explores how virtual reality is being used beyond entertainment to enhance understanding, training, and retail experiences. In public awareness, the UK’s National Autistic Society and Alzheimer’s Research UK created VR films to simulate autism and dementia, aiming to build empathy and understanding. Retailers use VR for marketing and visualization: estate agents offer virtual property tours, Westfield showcases fashion, and Ikea’s HTC Vive app lets users explore and customize kitchens—famously adding virtual meatballs—prompting consideration of in-store rollout. Healthcare applies VR for education and therapy: live-streamed surgery by Dr Shafi Ahmed led to the Virtual Surgeon product to broaden medical training, and VR exposure therapy has helped treat PTSD and arachnophobia. Education initiatives include Google Expeditions for virtual field trips and a Mandarin-learning app by Evanescent Studios, with advocates highlighting VR’s potential to boost engagement; however, costs and hardware needs remain barriers, and experiments like NetDragon’s propose using headset data to gauge student attention.

Russia publicly opened the Su-24 jet’s flight recorder in Moscow, but investigators said key flight data appears missing, with a full analysis due next week. The data is central to the dispute over whether the jet, shot down by Turkish F-16s on 24 November, was in Turkish or Syrian airspace. The incident severely strained Russia-Turkey relations: Moscow imposed sanctions (including a ban on package holidays) and demanded an apology, while Turkey maintains the jet ignored airspace warnings. One Russian pilot was killed after ejecting, the navigator was rescued, and a Russian marine died during a rescue operation; a helicopter was also destroyed on the ground. President Putin criticized Turkey, accusing it of subservience to the US and “creeping Islamisation.”

Scotland’s women have won all five Euro qualifiers and face unbeaten, top-seeded Iceland at Falkirk on Friday, with the two head-to-heads likely to decide the group winner; even as one of the best runners-up, Scotland are well placed to reach next summer’s finals in the Netherlands without a play-off. Forward Lisa Evans, 24, reflecting on past play-off heartbreaks for Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup, stresses taking it step by step but believes Scotland have a strong chance, urging a big home crowd. Evans highlights the squad’s growing overseas experience—12 of 20 players abroad, including Kim Little in the NWSL—and says the high standards in leagues like Germany’s Bundesliga, where she just won the title with Bayern Munich, are elevating the national team through tougher competition and diverse playing styles.

A review for Scotland’s Commission on Local Tax Reform found no simple fix for flaws in the council tax, which has had inherent problems since its inception and was worsened by a lack of reform.
