Examining international models, Prof Kenneth Gibb reported that property taxes, used by most OECD countries, are stable, hard to avoid, and can influence housing markets, but cause confusion over whether they fund services or tax wealth and are seen as unfair because they aren’t tied to current income. Local income taxes are viewed as fairer but create revenue volatility for councils and limit local rate variation. He concluded reform is complex and shaped by past experiences. The commission will conduct a public consultation and report in the autumn, while the Scottish government deems the current system unfair and awaits recommendations for fairer alternatives.

Apple expanded its two-step verification to protect iCloud backups after celebrity photo thefts allegedly enabled by Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker, which could previously download iCloud backups even when two-step was enabled for logins. The system now requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device for new-device access and blocks iCloud and store purchases without it, with a 14-character recovery key as a fallback; users also get email alerts when a backup download starts. Elcomsoft’s owner says Apple’s update closes his method with no workaround, though he warns about risks of lost or stolen recovery keys. Security experts argue two-factor should be the default rather than opt-in. Apple says it will push users harder toward two-factor and stronger passwords, emphasizing user awareness.

The Electoral Commission reported that during the 23 January–22 May campaign period, the Conservatives spent £2,980,815, UKIP £2,956,737, the Lib Dems £1,580,575, Labour £1,027,339, the Greens £534,249, and the SNP £267,372, totaling £9,347,087 among the six highest-spending parties. UKIP won the election, with spending equivalent to 68p per vote (4,376,635 votes). Per-vote costs were 79p for the Conservatives, 26p for Labour (which came second), £1.45 for the Lib Dems (who lost 11 of 12 MEPs), and 43p for the Greens (1,255,573 votes). All parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join their National League rivals and could face his former club on 18 February, while 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating is set to join Torquay United subject to international clearance after recommendations from Micky Adams, having previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Torquay boss Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson’s leadership qualities and described Keating as raw but hungry. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone with one win in their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage shortly after narrowly defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. Veterinary staff treated him on course, but he was pronounced dead, with the British Horseracing Authority noting such episodes are rare and can occur without underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had previously shown post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he had never collapsed and showed no such symptoms that day. Previously a winner of the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, he was described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as the “horse of a lifetime.” The BHA and commentators emphasized there were no significant underlying health issues and concluded the death resulted from a rare racetrack haemorrhage, though the sport aims to better understand and prevent such incidents.

Ahead of the 5 May election, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, former First Minister Alex Salmond, and Labour MSP Duncan McNeil delivered farewell speeches to the Scottish Parliament, with Marwick visibly moved by McNeil’s emotional address and Salmond’s valedictory remarks. Salmond reaffirmed his long-held view that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” supported greater devolution under the Scotland Bill while arguing it falls short of referendum pledges, and offered light-hearted jokes before concluding, “goodbye from me... for now.” Marwick praised Salmond’s service as MSP and First Minister. McNeil, stepping down after serving since 1999, urged Holyrood to strengthen accountability, scrutiny, and its committee system, suggesting it could learn from Westminster. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also announced her departure, quipping about her exchanges with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

A live-action Beauty and the Beast film, directed by Bill Condon, begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017; the cast includes Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Belle’s father Maurice, and a yet-unnamed star as Mrs. Potts, a role voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version.

The Crown Prosecution Service is set to announce charging decisions to Hillsborough victims’ families at an 11:00 BST meeting in Warrington, following new inquests that ruled the 96 fans were unlawfully killed. Evidence on 23 suspects was submitted in January: 15 from Operation Resolve into the disaster’s causes during the 1989 FA Cup semi-final, and eight from an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into South Yorkshire and West Midlands Police conduct afterward. Sue Hemming, head of the CPS special crime and counter-terrorism division, will brief relatives privately. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died and who chairs the Hillsborough Family Support Group, said the wait has been a long struggle, the day will bring mixed emotions, and families remain determined to secure accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has reported numerous recent attempts to smuggle contraband by throwing packages over its walls, with a nearby resident witnessing four incidents in two weeks and a former inmate describing widespread availability of mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. While the ex-prisoner claimed drones were used to deliver items to windows, the Ministry of Justice said there is no evidence of drone use at Chelmsford. The MoJ stated staff work hard to stop contraband but more action is needed, with the Justice Secretary seeking stronger tools to tackle the problem; laws now allow up to two-year prison sentences for those caught smuggling items over prison walls.

At Luton Crown Court, Brian Wright, 55, admitted hitting 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn with his VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming he was blinded by the setting sun and couldn’t recall the traffic light color. Prosecutors said he failed to stop at a red light as Blackburn, wearing appropriate clothing, escorted a woman and child; traffic from the opposite direction had stopped. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse, and the judge briefly paused proceedings due to his distress. The trial continues.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, will miss the April Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast due to university exams in May and her final-year studies, though she hopes to target the World Indoor Championships in March. She expressed disappointment at skipping a rare chance to run for Scotland but emphasized prioritizing her degree, while believing she has two or three more Olympics ahead. At the recent World Athletics Championships, Muir placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, where Hellen Obiri won gold, and set a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 despite it being her fifth race in 10 days, leaving her optimistic about her future potential.

Irish police have begun a weeks-long excavation search at a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, as part of a renewed investigation into the 2000 disappearance of 22-year-old Trevor Deely, last seen walking home from a Christmas party. A six-detective team reviewed the case and enhanced CCTV showing Deely speaking with a man in black outside his workplace on Baggot Street, likely after returning for an umbrella, and the same man apparently following him on Haddington Road. Despite releasing the footage in April, Gardaí have not identified the man and are appealing again for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165 after over two years out with wrist injuries and three surgeries, upset Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 at Wimbledon, celebrating a rejuvenated return to Grand Slam play and setting up a match against Lucas Pouille or Donald Young in Andy Murray’s half of the draw. Nick Kyrgios, also in Murray’s half, rallied past Dustin Brown in five sets after rain delays to face Feliciano Lopez, who came back from two sets down against Fabio Fognini; the winner could meet Murray or John Millman in the last 16. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga advanced with straight-sets wins.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to Caf for its complaints over refereeing during the 2015 tournament, where a controversial late penalty helped hosts Equatorial Guinea beat them 2-1; the FTF denied alleging corruption, instead criticizing the referee’s selection. A meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou resolved the dispute, and Tunisia was placed in Group A with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti, aiming for a record 13th straight finals. Morocco, initially banned for withdrawing as 2015 hosts over Ebola concerns, had its suspension overturned by Cas and its fine reduced from $1m to $50,000, allowing entry into 2017 qualifying; Morocco’s FA chief said the hiatus had minimal impact. Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

The passage charts McLaren’s cyclical rise and decline in F1, contrasting its illustrious history—182 wins, 12 drivers’ titles, eight constructors’ crowns, and dominant Honda and Mercedes eras (notably 1988’s 15/16 wins and titles in 1998-99)—with its current struggle to target only mid-grid starts and points. It recalls setbacks including exclusion and a $100m fine in 2007’s “spygate” and 2009’s “lie-gate,” and notes the post-2013 slump from chassis missteps, now compounded by an underperforming Honda power unit despite a strong car and two world champions, including Fernando Alonso. Ron Dennis, who previously led revivals, has retaken control and insists McLaren will be the next team to dethrone Mercedes, with faith that Honda will deliver a competitive engine and that “championships, plural” will follow—though for now, belief and reputation are all that sustain the team’s ambitions.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, after which police found people still on the premises and till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court heard that licensing laws were not strictly adhered to, and the judge, calling it one of the worst cases he had seen, ordered the bar closed for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, with an “appalling record,” was convicted on two counts of allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours and fined £3,000, while James Thomas, 44, was convicted on one count and fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry led the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers, scoring 45 points and breaking his own NBA single-season record for three-pointers by hitting eight (surpassing his previous 272), with nine assists; Klay Thompson added 26 as the Warriors rallied from 13 down and avoided their first three-game skid. For Portland, LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds, and Damian Lillard 20 points and eight assists. In another game, the Chicago Bulls erased a 19-point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89-78, sparked by a 39-8 second-half run; Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds, Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson 14 each, and Derrick Rose and Mike Dunleavy 12 apiece. Miami’s Hassan Whiteside posted 19 points and 16 rebounds, while Dwyane Wade struggled, scoring nine on 4-of-20 shooting as the Heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime.

YouTube free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen visited Liverpool’s Melwood training ground posing as a competition-winning fan, where Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic expected to give him a dead-ball lesson. After a few attempts, van Velzen revealed his skill by scoring impressive free-kicks, surprising the players and delighting the stand-in keeper. He described the experience as amazing, enjoying pretending to be average before impressing his idols, and relishing their reactions. Balotelli also converted a top-corner free-kick after an initial miss, and van Velzen capped the visit by referencing Balotelli’s famous “Why Always Me?” slogan from 2011.

A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that oophorectomy after diagnosis significantly improved outcomes for BRCA1 carriers: it reduced breast cancer mortality by 62%, all-cause mortality by 65%, and, when done within two years, cut death risk by 73%, with benefits appearing immediately and lasting up to 15 years; no similar breast cancer mortality reduction was seen for BRCA2 carriers. The 20-year survival for the full cohort was 77.4%, and nine ovarian-cancer deaths occurred among women who did not have oophorectomy. Researchers and journal editors suggested oophorectomy be discussed at diagnosis for BRCA mutation carriers, especially BRCA1 and those with estrogen-receptor–negative disease, while calling for more research, particularly in BRCA2 carriers. Context notes include Angelina Jolie’s preventive surgeries, high lifetime breast cancer risks (50–80% for BRCA1/2 carriers), availability of genetic testing, and higher BRCA mutation prevalence in Ashkenazi Jewish women.

On Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, married couple Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak’s northbound Carolinian train No. 80 while lingering on Norfolk Southern-owned tracks. None of the 166 passengers were injured, though one person fell ill during the nearly 2 hour 45 minute delay before the train continued from Charlotte toward New York City; the couple was pronounced dead at the scene. A man who knew them from scrap collecting suggested they may have been living in a homeless camp, and urged compassion toward people in difficult circumstances. Durham is about 25 miles from the train’s next stop, Raleigh; the full route typically takes about 13.5 hours.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid-level Medellin Cartel member who became a key DEA informant for 27 years, says he was promised U.S. citizenship for his unpaid undercover work that helped take down figures like Carlos Lehder and aided the prosecution of Manuel Noriega. Now retired due to declining health, he lacks legal status after his visa expired January 1, cannot collect Social Security without a green card or passport, and faces deportation the DEA refuses to help prevent after he went public. Fearing he would be killed if returned to Colombia, Toro says he will go into hiding if necessary; a former DEA handler and colleague have criticized the government’s inaction, with one giving him $5,000 for a medical operation when the DEA declined to assist.

ICANN is scrutinizing Canadian firm Vox Populi Registry over its .sucks top-level domain, after an advisory group representing companies like Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay called the rollout a predatory “shakedown scheme.” Vox Populi began offering early registrations to trademark holders and celebrities on March 30 at about $2,499 per year (often resold around $2,000), with plans to open consumer registrations at $10 per year in September. High-profile names and brands, including Kevin Spacey, YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, Yahoo, and Telus Mobility, have secured or removed .sucks domains; Spacey reportedly paid to have his taken down, and Taylor Swift has previously spent defensively on similar domains. ICANN has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to assess the legality of Vox Populi’s practices and may declare a contract breach or seek other remedies if they are found illegal.

Police solved a 27-year-old case after exhuming an unidentified baby boy found in 1988 in a Sainsbury’s bag in a Norfolk pond, using DNA from his leg bone to trace his mother. The woman, who had concealed her pregnancy and said the baby was stillborn, admitted placing him in Weasenham St Peter’s Windmill Pit; police found no evidence of foul play after a second post-mortem and ruled out third-party involvement. Initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide, she had that charge dropped, and the CPS is considering charges of failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, originally buried without a name, was reburied on June 5, the 26th anniversary of his discovery, and named Peter after St Peter’s Church, with a new headstone funded by a stillbirth support group.

A High Court judge ruled that taxi driver Michael Young unlawfully imprisoned passenger Kristopher Hicks after wrongly suspecting he would evade the fare and driving him back to the rank, during which Hicks jumped from the moving car at over 20 mph, sustaining severe brain injuries, epilepsy, and requiring 24-hour care. The judge found Young intended only to return Hicks to the rank but held his conduct created significant risk; damages will be reduced by 50%, with an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment, and the total compensation is expected to be in the hundreds of thousands of pounds. Both parties have permission to appeal, and a further hearing will set the final amount.

Tornado sirens sounded across Kansas Wednesday night as multiple storms produced reported twisters, including one northwest of Goddard that moved northeast and spared Wichita but threatened other communities. CNN’s Chad Myers warned of the heightened danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna. The National Weather Service indicated a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof damage, and large hail, as documented by local affiliates and social media posts from nearby towns like Leadington and Farmington. More storms were forecast Thursday for the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and the southern Great Lakes region.

Ahead of their middleweight clash in New Jersey, Luke Rockhold aims for a fourth straight win and potential title shot by pressuring Lyoto Machida, vowing to “be the bull” against Machida’s elusive, matador-like style. Rockhold believes his well-rounded game—wrestling, kicks, and punches—gives him broader paths to victory, especially on the ground, and plans to cut off Machida, force exchanges, and dominate, while maintaining mutual respect for Machida’s long-standing elite status. Machida, coming off a win like Rockhold, counters that applying his own style and strategy can stop Rockhold, and asserts that the winner deserves a title shot; he reports a strong eight-week camp with notable training partners and confidence in executing on fight night.

A light Aerostar aircraft in Fort Pierce, Florida landed without deploying its landing gear, scraping its belly and striking its propellers on the runway before the pilot reapplied power and took off again. The bystander who filmed the incident described the unforgettable sound of propeller impacts and predicted a likely crash, yet the 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, regained control despite damaged propellers and flew about 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely with his dog onboard. The incident, often caused by human error or mechanical failure, is under FAA investigation.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted disappointment with Yaya Toure’s underperformance this season but vowed to back him until the end of the campaign, dismissing calls for a rest despite City’s faltering title defense and willingness to listen to summer offers for the midfielder. City, who have taken 18 of the last 39 points, face West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany, with a loss potentially allowing Liverpool to close the gap to one point. Joe Hart said players have let Pellegrini down but affirmed the squad’s support for him, while Pellegrini accepted ultimate responsibility for team selection. Meanwhile, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell—targeted by City and Chelsea—against following the path of English players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who moved to City and struggled for game time.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the “Godfather of Uxbridge,” will be allowed to remain in the UK after his Italian seven-year sentence for Mafia association, imposed in 1999 in absentia, was declared expired under Italian law, which extinguishes sentences after more than double the penalty time has passed. Although his conviction stands and must still be considered by Italy’s Supreme Court, his European Arrest Warrant is to be withdrawn, ending extradition proceedings. Rancadore, who fled Italy in 1995 and lived in Britain for over 20 years under an alias, had previously fought extradition amid human-rights concerns over prison conditions. Legal experts criticized the time and cost of the case and noted procedural delays, including a CPS error in 2014, may have contributed to the outcome. Once paperwork is completed, a UK court will formally discharge the case, and Rancadore is expected to remain in England with his family.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites for the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty’s injury. This will be McCoy’s final Grade One ride, with his full book of rides for his last professional day to be confirmed Friday. McCoy announced his retirement after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was raped and strangled in 1975 by Jerome Sidney Barrett, recently chose to view long-avoided crime scene photos, describing the images as horrific and saying they stirred feelings of revenge. Marcia’s body was found 33 days after her disappearance in a cluttered, windowless garage near her home, with signs of assault and a fractured neck bone; her cookie money was missing and cookies were scattered around her clothed body. The case was Nashville’s most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years: an initial charge against a 15-year-old neighbor in 1979 was dropped for lack of evidence. Barrett, who had spent most years from 1974 to 2002 in prison on sex charges and was arrested in 2006 after DNA on Marcia’s clothing matched his during an investigation into another 1975 murder, was convicted in 2009 of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years.

Rory McIlroy says it’s “unthinkable” he won’t eventually win the Masters to complete the career Grand Slam, aiming to join Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. Reflecting on his 2011 Augusta collapse from a four-shot lead to a final-round 80, he calls it the most important day of his career, crediting it with lessons that helped him win subsequent majors: the 2011 U.S. Open, 2012 PGA, and both The Open and PGA in 2014. Despite just one top-10 in six Masters starts, he believes Augusta suits him and hopes to win multiple green jackets, emphasizing focus on performance over hype. After personal and legal distractions last year, he says the golf course serves as his sanctuary and expects the same at Augusta amid intense buildup.

A roundup of the week’s trending stories includes a rare quadruple rainbow over New York captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis; China’s crackdown on the practice of hiring exotic dancers for funerals; Robert Downey Jr. growing agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview probing his private life; the #KylieJennerChallenge lip-plumping fad involving jar suction; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her dancing past with filmmakers’ help; a controversial bomb-referencing promposal that sparked accusations of racism after a school rejection; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; an unrecognizable Johnny Depp in the Black Mass trailer; a Fresh Prince of Bel-Air–themed pregnancy announcement; and a military dad’s creative photobomb—each drawing significant social media attention.

Official data show 272 children in England were hospitalized last year with disabilities from foetal alcohol syndrome, but experts warn the true number is much higher, with WHO research suggesting at least 1 in 100 UK babies—around 7,500 annually—may suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to prenatal alcohol exposure. A case example, 15-year-old Niamh Brown, illustrates lifelong impacts requiring support and preventing independent living. Additional risks include damage to the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. While UK guidance allows limited alcohol during pregnancy, advocates argue it should advise complete abstinence.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender from Coundon near Bishop Auckland known as “Boomerang Boy” for repeatedly returning home after crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 at 8 pm, waving an axe and demanding cash from assistant Andrea Brighty. Store owner Sab Dhillon rugby-tackled him to the floor, and his wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, helping disarm him and expose his face to cameras. Police arrived minutes later and arrested McKerry, who had a lengthy criminal history including starting shoplifting at 12, being arrested 80 times by 15, and prior convictions for vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary. He previously pleaded guilty at Durham Crown Court to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, 23; Craig Stoner, 24; Simon Radford, 31; and Darren Smalley, 35—have been charged in Nova Scotia with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, allegedly committed during an alcohol-fueled party at Canadian barracks on April 10 after a hockey game. Granted bail of over £2,000 each, they must surrender passports, remain in Nova Scotia, avoid contact with the victim and six witnesses, and live and continue working on Halifax’s Stadacona naval base under a UK-Canada agreement. They cannot resign from the Navy without court permission and were ordered back to court on May 27. The investigation is ongoing, forensic results may bring additional charges, and the offenses carry up to 14 years’ imprisonment. Authorities emphasized the allegations are serious but remain allegations.

Valerie Jackson from Las Vegas cares for her four-year-old son RJ, one of only about 70 people worldwide with Netherton’s syndrome, a rare congenital skin disorder that makes skin appear red, scaly, and sore, and can cause infection and allergy issues; managing it requires frequent moisturizing (e.g., Vaseline multiple times daily) and gentle bathing, with no cure though symptoms may improve over time. Misunderstanding of his appearance has led to severe public reactions, including denial of entry to play centers, taunts (often from adults), and a police intervention after a bystander reported suspected abuse while they applied creams in a store. RJ’s condition was evident at birth with a spreading rash; after initial uncertainty from doctors, Valerie found a Facebook group that matched his symptoms and guided home care. Despite stigma and exhaustion from constant care, his family supports him, and Valerie hopes awareness will reduce ignorance and bullying.

Transport for London is removing Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” ads from the London Underground at the end of their paid three-week run amid widespread backlash over body image, including a 50,000-signature petition, over 200 ASA complaints, defaced posters, and a planned Hyde Park protest. While TfL says it received one formal complaint and will follow CAP/ASA guidance on similar future ads, Protein World has defended the unphotoshopped campaign on social media with combative replies, and its marketing head said on TV the goal is promoting fitness, revealing the company has received threats, including a bomb threat under police investigation. The ASA is assessing 216 complaints, and the controversy has sparked polarized reactions online, with some public figures condemning the ad as anxiety-inducing and sexist and others defending it, as the UK protein market continues rapid growth.

Rail firms plan significant fare increases shortly after the general election despite pledges by major parties to freeze prices, prompting Prime Minister David Cameron to urge First Great Western (FGW) to review rises on the London–Cotswolds route through his Witney constituency. A key example is Charlbury–London off-peak returns: currently £33.30 with evening-peak return allowed, rising to £62.40 from May 17 (an 87% increase). Train companies can raise unregulated fares—about half their revenue—three times a year; these include off-peak and advance tickets. FGW says the change aligns the North Cotswolds route with others and notes cheaper advance singles could total £20 for a return if booked ahead. Other hikes include London Midland’s Crewe–Northampton off-peak first-class single (£30 to £37), Virgin’s Stafford–Liverpool anytime return (£26.50 to £33), and Manchester–Stoke anytime first-class day return (£29 to £35.30). Virgin says most increases affect its cheaper “Virgin Trains-only” fares and that its overall West Coast rise is 1.65%, below the industry average. Critics note surprise at the rises amid political freeze promises, with prior research showing many anytime and off-peak returns rose by 40% in January, especially on tickets bought on the day and rural routes.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left permanently blind in his left eye after vandals hurled bricks at his Oldham home; when he opened the front door to confront them, a brick struck his face, causing severe injuries despite emergency surgery. Young and his new wife Elaine, 54—married three weeks earlier—had been writing wedding thank-you cards when the attack occurred around 11–11:20 pm on April 18. Police say there appears to be no clear motive and suggest the culprits may have been “messing around,” but emphasize the seriousness of the reckless act. The couple, frightened and feeling unsafe, plan to move to Elaine’s flat in Southport. Authorities are investigating and urge anyone with information to contact them.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one-year contract extension through the end of the 2016 season after successfully returning from serious leg injuries sustained in a 2014 road accident that killed his father. Following an ankle operation and recovery, he made his comeback on Derbyshire’s pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the season start. Elite performance director Graeme Welch praised Poynton’s character, hard work, and form, expressing confidence the new deal will help him perform strongly this summer.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford, diagnosed a year ago with aggressive neuroblastoma that had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been declared cancer-free after intensive treatment including 80 days of chemotherapy, surgery to remove a kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at The Christie in Manchester. To stay brave during treatment, he decorated his radiotherapy mask as a Ninja Turtle and wore a superhero costume, a story that gained global attention and prompted Nickelodeon to send gifts. Harley has received Cancer Research UK’s Little Star Award and now fronts the charity’s Kids & Teens campaign. His parents, Oliver and Stacey, are overjoyed, though Harley will have regular check-ups. The passage also explains neuroblastoma: a rare childhood cancer of specialized nerve cells, usually arising in adrenal glands or along the spinal cord, affecting fewer than 100 UK children annually, mostly under five, with varied symptoms and treatments including surgery, chemotherapy, antibody therapy, and radiotherapy.

Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood urges 19-year-old Jack Grealish to focus on cementing his club place after impressing in the FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, rather than rushing a decision on his international future amid interest from both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood says the choice is Grealish’s alone and advises he follow his heart, citing past guidance to Nabil Bentaleb, while praising Grealish’s confidence and ball control. Grealish is expected to decide at season’s end and is currently split, with his father agreeing club performances should come first and noting he could feature in upcoming friendlies for either side.

Private jet travel is a growing, high-cost industry—2.5 million U.S. flights and 705,000 in Europe in 2013, with markets valued at $16.7 trillion (US) and $15.8 trillion (Europe)—where landing fees vary widely and can be surprisingly high at certain hubs. The Richest’s list of most expensive landing fees (based on a 767-400) is topped by Japan: Haneda £4,559 ($6,850), Narita £3,728 ($5,600), and Kansai £3,594 ($5,400); followed by Toronto Pearson £3,461 ($5,200), Darwin £3,059 ($4,600), Bristol £2,929 ($4,400), Chūbu Centrair £2,863 ($4,300), Dublin £2,729 ($4,100), LaGuardia £2,630 ($3,950), and Salzburg £2,530 ($3,800). Busy periods include major sports events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, with charter round trips estimated at $38,000–$54,000 NY–Glendale and about £8,835–£8,895 London–Cannes/Nice. Popular private routes include Los Angeles–Las Vegas (~£2,890/$4,340) and Milan–Rome (~$5,880 one-way).

A video by Katie Gallegos of Clackamas County, Oregon, shows her Labrador Cooper devouring a McDonald’s ice cream cone in one bite while his smaller companion Daisy takes polite licks; Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, says Cooper always eats quickly, so she lets Daisy have some first. The clip has amassed over seven million views, drawing both praise and criticism for feeding dogs ice cream. Gallegos defends the treats as safe, noting Cooper is healthy and her late dog lived to 19 with occasional ice cream; Daisy only gets a few licks due to her size. Another video shows the pair enjoying a Starbucks “pup-uccino,” which Gallegos clarifies is just whipped cream without coffee, with Cooper again finishing it enthusiastically.

Kilmarnock have appointed Gary Locke as permanent manager on a three-year deal after a successful interim spell, during which he lost just once in seven games. The 41-year-old former Hearts boss joined as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer and took over in February after Johnston resigned; he will address a press conference on Friday and was pictured shaking hands with chairman Jim Mann upon signing.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp of Eustis, says Seminole County Elementary threatened to remove her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, from class because the dōTERRA essential oils she applies to his head and neck—such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood—smell and distract other students. She claims he has used them all year to help him stay calm and focused, and that a teacher’s aide complaint prompted a school board letter citing a “problem” for staff and students. Kemp argues the oils are natural and beneficial and vows to continue their use. The Lake County School District later said Logan would not be suspended, calling it a health issue. The Daily Mail reached out to dōTERRA for comment.

A massive fire on Wednesday around 3 p.m. destroyed the Sandpiper beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, obliterating 90 condos and causing the building to collapse; smoke was visible from three miles away, and the heat melted paint on nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews used cranes but could not enter the summer homes; no cause is confirmed, though officials are investigating reports it began near a parked car. Residents, including apartment owner Janice Sklarek and building manager Rob Taber, who lived and worked there and says he lost everything, described flames pouring from every window. The complex operates seasonally from May to November, and the offshore wind aided firefighters’ visibility during the response.

Approaching 89, the Queen was seen riding in Windsor Great Park on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, accompanied by a groom, wearing her customary silk scarf instead of a helmet, which she has long declined due to her hair. A lifelong horse lover who began riding at four on a Shetland pony named Peggy, she has had many notable mounts, rode less recently due to a knee injury, and no longer presides over Trooping the Colour on horseback, yet remains active at her Windsor stables and involved with horses ridden by her grandchildren. She breeds Thoroughbreds, Fell ponies, and has a Highland pony stud at Balmoral. Fell ponies, an ancient, hardy breed from Cumbria dating to the Neolithic, grew in size through Roman influence, served as pack and trade animals through Vikings and Normans into the Industrial Revolution, later became favored family riding ponies in the 1950s, and remain popular today, including at the Queen’s Hampton Court stud.

A late-night noise dispute between Brisbane neighbors ended with 55-year-old Leon Yeaman dying from a single punch allegedly delivered by 28-year-old shift worker and father of three, Phillip Pama. Yeaman, reportedly a schizophrenic pensioner known for loud music and drinking, was making noise around 9 pm when Pama, who worked a 3 am shift and was sleeping, confronted him. According to Pama’s lawyer, the situation escalated; Pama grabbed Yeaman’s hand and swung “blindly” while being pushed, feeling the punch connect. Paramedics could not revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead around 11 pm. Pama, described as having no history of violence and deeply distressed, was charged with manslaughter and granted conditional bail, including surrendering his passport, a 6 pm–2 am curfew, and twice-weekly police reporting. The case returns to court on May 18.

In Shatura, near Moscow, 52-year-old music teacher Yulia Simonova was caught on hidden camera attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil, Damian Vanya, after he ended their year-long relationship for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400), detailing that she wanted his arms and legs broken, his kidneys damaged to make him bleed out, and to “finish him” herself. Police ran a sting with an undercover officer posing as the hitman; after she handed over expense money, armed officers arrested her in her car. Simonova has been charged with attempted murder and faces up to 15 years in prison. Vanya expressed relief and said he hoped authorities would “throw away the key.”

Chelsea manager José Mourinho, 52, says he prays and speaks to God daily but never about football, and he avoids discussing the game with his wife, aiming to keep professional and family life separate. He describes a strong faith, attending church when he feels the need, especially in Portugal, and emphasizes being a good family man and friend despite his combative professional persona. He notes his family’s awareness of poverty and his role as a World Food Programme ambassador against hunger. At the time, Chelsea were top of the league and set to play QPR; earlier in the season he was fined £25,000 for alleging a campaign against Chelsea after Cesc Fàbregas was booked for diving.

Bob Barker, the longtime host of The Price Is Right who stepped down in 2007 after 35 years, returned at age 91 for the first time in eight years to host the opening segment of the April 1 episode. He led the “Lucky Seven” game before handing the show back to current host Drew Carey, appearing energetic and unfazed despite his long absence.

Off-duty Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested around 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE in Washington, D.C., for alleged attempted burglary and destruction of property after officers returned to the scene; he faces a felony charge, had his security clearance revoked, and was placed on leave. Baldwin, assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch tied to the State Department, was scheduled for arraignment Friday, with no attorney listed. His arrest follows the recent suspension of a high-ranking supervisor over misconduct under police and DHS inspector general investigation, and comes amid broader probes, including a March 4 incident involving senior officials driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

A Pakistani freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, 38, risked his life in Lahore Safari Park by leaving his car and approaching a male lion to within about 10 feet to capture close-up photos. After taking a few shots while lying on the ground, the camera shutter alerted the hungry lion, which then charged. Saeed narrowly escaped by scrambling back into his car. He aimed to portray the lion’s character and status, later reflecting that while he laughed at the time, he wouldn’t attempt such a dangerous stunt again.

New York City police are seeking the public’s help to identify a woman, estimated to be 25–45 years old, who was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and later pronounced dead; she carried no identification but had a distinctive faded tattoo on her right leg showing a heart with a ribbon and rose, believed to read “Monique.” The NYPD released photos of the tattoo and an artist’s rendering, and is awaiting the medical examiner’s report on the cause of death. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

After returning to New Zealand from the UK in 2009 and unable to afford property, Hannah and Alex bought a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent about a year and a half turning it into a solar-powered, wood-and-steel two-bedroom home. Now parked on a lot they purchased in Nelson, the cozy, nearly self-sufficient house features a wood-fired stove, stained glass, cypress-lined interiors, and a loft spare room, with electricity mainly from solar panels (their first bill was $25), gas for stove and hot water, and spring water. The project cost about $25,000, they live there with their cat, and they hope to build another similar home in the future.

A study by Courtney Blackwell of Northwestern University found that kindergarteners who shared iPads in class throughout an academic year significantly outperformed peers on early literacy tests compared with both students without iPads and those with one-to-one devices, scoring about 30 points higher. Conducted with 352 students in a Midwestern suburban district, the research suggests benefits stem from collaborative learning around the technology rather than technology use alone, implying schools—especially in early grades—should reconsider tablet use to emphasize shared, collaborative activities. Blackwell planned to present the findings at the 65th International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan, has become an internet sensation after learning to walk by balancing on its two front trotters. Featured in a People’s Daily Online video, the pig—nicknamed “Super Pig”—is seen wobbling, foraging with its snout to the ground, and regaining balance despite near falls, while mingling with its four-legged siblings. Owned by farmer Ms. Duan, the unusual animal has attracted curious villagers, and its fame echoes a similar case in China where a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo learned to walk on its front paws, drawing tourists in Guangxi province.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Dayle Coyne Racing pit crew member Todd Phillips was struck in the leg by Francesco Dracone’s car as Dracone spun exiting his pit box on lap 25 after a stop for tires and fuel. Phillips received stitches at the infield care center and was released. Wet conditions from prolonged rain caused traction issues for many cars. Dracone did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

CCTV footage in Rio de Janeiro shows Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdering his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29 (stage name Amanda Bueno), by dragging her outside, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, then shooting her in the face five times; he later confessed he acted out of jealousy over men looking at her. The couple had been married four days, and a neighbor reported hearing him call her derogatory names before gunshots. Severiano fled in a stolen car, crashed, was arrested, and police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his vehicle. He faces life in prison.

Journalist and author Sarah Wilson, 41, known for I Quit Sugar, revealed in a candid interview that severe anxiety—compounded by stress, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated without a partner or children—left her unable to see a reason to continue living. She described reaching a point with no “light at the end of the tunnel,” but says she has recently found some peace and now accepts she is an anxious person. Wilson views depression and anxiety as intrinsically linked and believes acknowledging this connection is vital to address rising anxiety among Australian women. She notes anxiety is becoming the “new depression,” citing Beyond Blue’s statistic that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety, and provides helplines for support.

Prosecutors dropped second-degree assault charges against Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old Portland woman who was seven months pregnant when she struck her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014 after finding her shooting heroin on Curtin’s toilet and refusing to leave. Citing Oregon law permitting physical force against an intruder who won’t leave, prosecutors deemed Curtin “completely justified.” Curtin has since given birth; her boyfriend, the child’s father with a past heroin problem and a five-year-old with the ex, is not involved with the new child. Curtin now lives with her parents, and her attorney described a history of harassment by the ex. A conviction would have carried nearly six years in mandatory prison time.

A video from California shows Gemma, a pit bull living with two children, being fed treats when her owner slips in a broccoli spear; she reacts with visible disgust, chews it, then spits it out on the floor. The piece humorously notes she’s not setting a good example for the kids’ vegetable habits, and adds that other videos show Gemma enjoying sleep and time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website directed users to a pornographic page when the URL for its discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards (scrapped in 2011) was taken over after the domain registration lapsed. The bank removed the hyperlink from its community projects page, denied any association with the external site, and stated its website remains secure. A public statement dated April 20 confirmed the link’s removal and offered an apology for any inconvenience.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, calmly guided firefighters during an 11-minute 911 call after a fire broke out on the first floor of his Clinton home, leaving him and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah trapped in a second-floor bedroom. He reassured his sister, instructed her to stay low and breathe, and provided responders with precise directions. Prince George’s County firefighters entered the house, broke a window, and Lt. Kenny Ward handed Marcus out to another rescuer, then gave his gas mask to Aaliyah; officials praised his actions as heroic. Marcus and Aaliyah were taken to Children’s Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while their mother, stepfather, and older brother escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae, identified as Noctiluca scintillans, created a striking neon glow along Australia’s east coast, notably captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson at Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Described as a “beautiful supernatural scene,” the light is emitted by millions of plankton and is typically a natural phenomenon that blossoms in spring and autumn. Oceanographer Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales noted there is no cause for concern, explaining the carnivorous, single-celled phytoplankton preys on diatoms and produces the luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar display occurred at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014.

New genetic tests, particularly EndoPredict, analyze tumor markers after breast cancer surgery to gauge recurrence risk, allowing many women to safely avoid routine chemotherapy and its severe side effects. Results, available within days, can show risks as low as 5%, comparable to or better than outcomes with chemotherapy. Though currently costing about £2,500 privately, experts argue NHS adoption could be cost-effective by reducing unnecessary chemo. Clinicians say the tests support informed decision-making, as illustrated by a patient whose low score led her to forgo chemotherapy in favor of monitoring.

A Freedom of Information request revealed that more than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five emergency medevacs from HMS Ocean over nine years and at least one from HMS Illustrious; 18 other ships, such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. The Ministry of Defence stated there is a strict “no touching” rule at sea, implying most conceptions occurred before deployment or during leave. This follows the case of Commander Sarah West, removed from HMS Portland for “personal reasons” amid allegations of a relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, comprising about 9% of personnel in 2014, with three becoming the first female submariners in 2014. Separately, 99 pregnant British servicewomen were flown home from Afghanistan (2006–2013) and 102 from Iraq under rules barring pregnant personnel from war zones; most pregnancies began in the UK, though a few may have occurred on tour.

A drone containing traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s residence in Tokyo, prompting terrorism concerns, especially ahead of the Olympics and G7 summit. Discovered the same day a court approved restarting two Sendai nuclear reactors, the four-propeller, 50-centimeter drone carried a camera, smoke flares, and a bottle with cesium likely placed inside; the amount was not immediately harmful. Japan currently restricts drones near airports but not over most of Tokyo, including government buildings. Abe was abroad in Indonesia at the time, and officials said they will review regulations and countermeasures for drone-related threats.

A Chinese security guard, Lu Xincai from Zhejiang province, takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer’s to work daily on the back of his motorbike to prevent her from getting lost. After his father died and with his wife working in another city and his son still in school, he became her sole caregiver. Each morning he helps her up at 5 a.m., secures them together with a sash, and rides four kilometers slowly so she feels safe and they can talk, a trip that takes an hour. His employer, a bank, provides her a room, and he checks on her during work. Motivated by gratitude for her lifelong care, he says he now has a duty to care for her.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking in the U.S. rose 17.2% from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by increased alcohol use among women as social norms shift; binge drinking among women grew more than seven times the rate among men, with examples like Santa Clara County showing a 36% rise for women versus 23% for men. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers, with notable county-level variation (lowest binge drinking in Madison County, ID at 6%, highest in Menominee, WI at 36%; fewest heavy drinkers in Hancock County, TN at 2%, most in Esmeralda County, NV at 22%). Despite more heavy and binge drinking, overall alcohol use rates remained stable. Researchers cite factors including changing social norms, youth and affluence, cheaper real alcohol prices due to stagnant taxes, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened control policies. Alcohol was linked to about 88,600 U.S. deaths in 2010 and an annual economic cost over $220 billion, and treatment providers report rising demand though many delay care until severe consequences occur. The study analyzed data from 3.7 million adults via the CDC’s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System and is the first to assess adult drinking at the county level.

UN WHO officials warn that caesarean sections are being overused, putting mothers and babies at risk of short- and long-term health problems, complications, infections, disability, and even death, and diverting funds from other patients. They say C-section rates should ideally be 10–15%, contrasting with England’s rate of just over a quarter, more than double since the early 1990s, partly due to planned procedures for anxiety (tokophobia) and other factors. This stance conflicts with NHS/NICE guidance allowing elective C-sections without medical necessity. Costs are higher for C-sections (£2,369) than natural births (£1,665), and research indicates up to one in ten C-sections lead to infections.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 in Edgartown, Martha’s Vineyard, after allegedly breaking into an $800,000 summer home on Court Street, living there for about a week, and selling or giving away the owners’ belongings in a yard sale. Discovered by owner Mark Conklin sitting in his living room, she claimed she owned the house and fled in a gray Nissan pickup before returning and being arrested. Charges include breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, with a broken window found covered by a blanket. Missing items include deck chairs, a Weber grill, side tables, lamps, framed posters, cookware, linens, and a painting. Police ask anyone who received items to return them to Edgartown Police, noting buyers are also victims and can seek restitution; Filkins is due in court May 14.

After Bella Crooke lost her unlocked iPhone at a party in Melbourne, it was handed to Albury Police on the NSW-Victoria border. To locate her, officers used the phone to post humorous selfies and puns on her Facebook—showing the phone in a “cell,” promising it would be fully “charged,” and saying it awaited “bail.” The posts drew amused reactions from her friends. When Bella arrived, officers recognized her from Facebook, returned the phone, and she later added a password, praising the police for their good-humored approach.

A five-day-old hippo calf in South Africa’s iSimangaliso Wetland Park was killed after getting caught in a violent fight between two adult males. As the mother stayed with her herd, believing it safer, a sub-adult hippo seized the calf, dragged it through the water, and hurled it into the air, despite the mother’s attempts to intervene. Witness Stacey Farrell described how the mother had been guarding the calf from younger hippos for hours, but the calf was fatally injured and died hours later.

A three-bedroom, 1,990 sq ft unmodernised maisonette in Knightsbridge’s Egerton Place is on sale for £575,000—far below local prices—because it has only three years left on its lease, effectively costing about £191,000 per year (£15,000 per month), akin to local rents, and requiring renovation; a second, larger short-lease maisonette nearby is listed at £595,000. Agents say extending the lease (likely a 90-year extension costing £3.35–£4.5 million with the freeholder believed to be the Wellcome Trust) could raise values to £6–£7.5 million (£2,750–£3,000 per sq ft). Interest is strong from locals, developers, and end users, but experts warn the apparent bargain masks a hefty lease-extension premium, making it suitable either for short-term rental or a developer play; the rare offering also highlights the risks of letting leases run very short.

A computer glitch during a daily system refresh disrupted Starbucks’ point-of-sale registers at about 7,000 U.S. and 1,000 Canadian stores Friday evening, preventing credit card transactions and prompting many locations to give away free drinks and baked goods, while some stores closed early to avoid distributing free products; the outage, which also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana, began in the early evening across time zones, sparked widespread social media sharing of the giveaways, and was resolved by late Friday with stores set to open as usual Saturday, coming a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly revenues of $4.6 billion and a 4.4% stock gain to $51.50.

A Wales counterterrorism officer told Ceredigion council that rural areas of Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire are being used to radicalize and train extremists who blend into communities with ordinary activities but have ulterior motives. He cited past links including alleged 1998 training in the Brecon Beacons tied to Abu Hamza, the 2005 presence of two 7/7 bombers in North Wales, a 2010 Cardiff-based al-Qaeda-inspired plot with secret meetings in a Welsh country park, and Lee Rigby murderer Michael Adebowale’s Arabic studies at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder. Emphasizing that terrorism issues aren’t confined to big cities, DC Gareth Jones stressed the importance of community intelligence to authorities.

A juvenile female Omura’s whale, a species feared extinct and first described in 2003, washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. Initially difficult to identify, it was confirmed via DNA profiling by the Department of Parks and Wildlife. The find is highly significant for scientists due to limited knowledge of the species, typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. Omura’s whales have a sleek body and distinctive skeletal traits, including 53 vertebrae and four digits per pectoral fin. The carcass was buried, with plans to recover the skeleton in a few years for research and potential museum display.

The passage critiques claims that women’s hormones make them unfit for the presidency, sparked by Texas CEO Cheryl Rios’s assertion against Hillary Clinton, and counters that male leaders’ hormones have historically led to riskier, sometimes irrational decisions. Citing research that women take fewer unnecessary risks and extensive evidence of workplace gender bias—both overt (scarcity of women on boards) and subtle (students labeling male professors “geniuses” and women “nice”)—it argues that bias, not biology, limits women’s leadership prospects. It emphasizes that gender equality benefits everyone—improving corporate performance, child outcomes, marriages, and team results—and notes that dismissing women’s leadership is factually and historically wrong (e.g., Canada’s female prime minister, Kim Campbell). The piece concludes that Hillary Clinton’s path is steeper due to bias and calls for confronting stereotypes rather than debating hormones.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is auctioning more than 200 antiques and collectibles—238 lots in total—valued around £100,000 as he downsizes his home, with the sale held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire. A keen military historian and longbow expert who studied English under J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford, Hardy is selling items including a hand-painted limewood 3D diorama of the Battle of Agincourt (estimated £4,000–£6,000), a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle and a portrait of himself with the bow (up to £2,000), early Victorian Gillows cabinets, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, paintings, and books dating to the 17th century. Expressing sadness at parting with his treasured library and collection, he praised the auctioneers and wished future owners joy. Hardy is famed for roles as Siegfried Farnon in All Creatures Great and Small, frequent portrayals of Winston Churchill (and Franklin D. Roosevelt), and as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films; after a fall two years ago forced him to retire from stage acting, he plans to continue television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man on parole for battery on law enforcement and with a history of bipolar disorder and prior involuntary psychiatric commitment, is wanted as a suspect in the killing of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, found dead at their shared Winter Garden home after a well-being check. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son the same day, and neighbors and his estranged wife’s attorney cited ongoing divorce stress and recent adverse paperwork as possible triggers; neighbors said his mother may have prevented the visit. Police say foul play is confirmed, they possess the murder weapon but have not disclosed the cause of death. Shemansky was reportedly seen at the trailer park office asking for water shortly after the murder and was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. His estranged wife is preparing for her safety, and authorities urge tips to 407-656-3636.

The IAAF Council awarded Eugene, USA, the 2021 World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a “unique strategic opportunity” to stage the event in the U.S. for the first time. Eugene had previously lost the 2019 bid to Doha, Qatar, but a recent presentation convinced the IAAF of its capability. IAAF President Lamine Diack cited the alignment of public authorities, private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and public enthusiasm as reasons, emphasizing access to a key market and global sport development; a similar non-bid award occurred for Osaka 2007.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old care assistant and aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years after being found guilty of manslaughter for luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, into a deadly robbery. After meeting him at London casinos and posing as “Rachel,” she gained his trust, then left his flat door unlocked so her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and accomplice Nicholas Chandler, 29, could enter. The men tied up and brutally kicked Hassan to death while searching for his cash, later filming themselves tossing £50 notes. Granger was convicted of manslaughter by a 10–2 majority and, along with the others, of robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison; Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years, alongside additional convictions for plotting armed robberies of casino employees. Judge William Kennedy called the attack “pitiless and wicked,” rejecting mitigation that Granger was swayed by love, while Hassan’s family said his death will haunt them forever.

The passage discusses Cesc Fabregas’s notable post-Christmas dip in form despite a strong start to the season with Chelsea, highlighting a poor display in Spain’s 2-0 loss to the Netherlands where he was rated 4/10. After joining Chelsea for £30m and amassing 15 Premier League assists by mid-January, his output has tailed off to just one assist in his last five league games and four in 15 appearances in 2015, jeopardizing his bid to break Thierry Henry’s single-season assists record of 20. Barcelona had previously noted a recurring late-season decline in his contributions, and current fatigue from an intense campaign appears to be affecting his impact. Although Chelsea remain on course for the Premier League title—needing around six wins from nine matches—Jose Mourinho will demand a resurgence from his deep-lying playmaker, especially as upcoming opponents are teams Fabregas has previously unlocked, with a recent assist to Diego Costa offering hope of a timely recovery.

West Ham are in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two-week trial at their academy and is also attracting interest from Belgian clubs, with the highly rated Montego Bay United prospect linked to multiple European teams; additionally, West Ham announced season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, aiming to offer the Premier League’s cheapest pricing to help fill the 54,000-seat venue for the 2016–17 season.

Wiltshire police have halted their investigation into a January 24 assault on huntsman Mike Lane, 40, despite video evidence, a suspect photo, and a dossier including names and car registrations; Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was attacked by balaclava-clad protesters using ropes with iron bars, kicked in the head, hospitalized with concussion and broken teeth, and now suffers memory loss. The incident occurred during a drag hunt near Everleigh, where about 15 protesters also sprayed hounds with citronella. Police cited insufficient evidence and recorded the case as undetected but said it could be reopened if new information emerges. Lane, hunt members, and supporters criticized the decision as inadequate, highlighting difficulties identifying masked saboteurs, while the Countryside Alliance called for banning face coverings to aid prosecutions.

The White House announced that Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American who became al Qaeda’s chief English-language propagandist, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January, though he was not specifically targeted; another American al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, was killed in a likely separate strike in which hostages Warren Weinstein (U.S.) and Giovanni Lo Porto (Italian) also died. Born in 1978 in California to the Pearlman family (later Gadahn), Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995, moved to Pakistan in 1998, joined al Qaeda (known as Abu Suhayb), and rose after 9/11 as “Azzam the American,” appearing in videos threatening Western targets, urging lone-wolf attacks in the U.S., praising attacks like Fort Hood and Benghazi, and criticizing U.S. presidents. Indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda and placed on the FBI’s Most Wanted Terrorists list, he contributed to al Qaeda media strategy, including a 2011 letter found in bin Laden’s compound; his final video in 2014 called for overthrowing governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married to an Afghan woman and reportedly had at least one child.

A viral video in China showcases five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, who has been shooting hoops since two and a half, performing impressive basketball feats such as scoring multiple baskets and flawlessly dribbling two balls while maintaining rhythm and eye contact with the camera. His skills have captivated basketball-loving China, earning him widespread admiration and thousands of online comments ranging from disbelief and curiosity about his family to self-deprecating humor. The phenomenon highlights China’s enthusiasm for child prodigies and evokes comparisons within a culture that has celebrated stars like Yao Ming.

Tom O’Carroll, a former Open University information officer and leading member of the 1970s–80s Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which sought to legalize sex with children and allied with the NCCL, attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for statutory press regulation recommended by Leveson; the event, chaired by John Cleese, was open to the public. O’Carroll, previously jailed in 1981 for corrupting public morals, confirmed his attendance in a blog. His support is likely embarrassing for Hacked Off, which campaigns against the Independent Press Standards Organisation as biased and seeks a statutory regulator.

Bondi’s Icebergs Club pool was drained on a warm, sunny Thursday to host Ten Pieces’ Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia presentation, turning the empty pool and break wall into a striking catwalk with the ocean as a backdrop. While some lap swimmers were displaced, guests enjoyed snacks from Icebergs and drinks by Santa Vittoria as models showcased a monochrome, minimalist, and androgynous unisex capsule of ten pieces designed to be worn 20 ways, suitable from day to night. The label, led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, drew crowds of spectators from the club’s balcony, the road above, and the beach below.

Amir Khan, the Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Northern California with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa, posing with giraffes and sea lions and feeding a rare white tiger. Earlier in the week, he announced his next fight would be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri at welterweight on May 30, opting against a June bout with IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook despite pressure, and turning down links to Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

Israel’s National Insurance Institute will remove Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir’s name from the Mount Herzl memorial to fallen soldiers and terror victims after his family objected and a victims’ advocacy group, Almagor, argued his killing was a rogue attack rather than terrorism. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned to death by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His father said he did not consent to the inclusion and refused to have his son listed among Israeli soldiers. Following complaints, the institute has already taken his name off its website, and a panel of judges began hearing evidence in January against the three suspects.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son repeatedly trying to nap on the family cat’s belly in the garden. The boy follows the cat and lies on him multiple times, but each time the cat quickly gets up and moves to a new spot before finally heading indoors. A later video shows they reconciled, with the boy gently feeding the cat treats.

In a Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner, 32, lost his varsity basketball coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past marijuana dealing and alleging that undercover officers stole $81,000 and seven pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Although he passed a background check when hired in 2010, his 2007 charges were later expunged; he also had a 2008 DUI and a 2011 arrest that led to four years’ probation, which he disputes. Kushner, a seasonal employee who also coaches in a Narberth summer league, expressed remorse and said he never intended to deceive the school. Defense lawyers for the six former drug squad officers charged with racketeering and related crimes argue the case relies on testimony from lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a paraxylene (PX) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, triggered a large fire that injured six people—five hurt by broken glass—and led to the deployment of over 600 firefighters; the blaze was brought under control, and no toxic spill was reported. The plant, which produces a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in polyester, had a previous explosion in July 2013 without casualties or leaks. Originally planned for the densely populated city of Xiamen, the project faced strong pollution-related protests in 2007 and was relocated to a more remote site; PX plants have sparked occasionally violent demonstrations in several Chinese cities. Residents near the plant reported hearing a loud blast and feeling tremors, sharing images on social media.

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish says he will keep wearing his socks low and children’s shinpads due to lifelong superstition, despite referees telling him to pull his socks up. After making his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR, the Republic of Ireland U21 international expressed relief and pride, noting the manager’s faith in him and hoping for more starts, while acknowledging the tough relegation context and his dissatisfaction with the result.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22, is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive with global, irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston and a source familiar with her condition; she does not respond to voices or track movement and has a tracheostomy. While Bobby Brown publicly said she was “awake” and the family’s attorney noted her condition has improved and she is beginning a long rehabilitation, both acknowledged that the quality of her future life is uncertain, with doctors indicating she may live a long time despite her severe neurological state.

Russia took a 2-0 lead over Germany in their Fed Cup semifinal after Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets and Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova edged Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, saving a match point. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with 13 double faults and Lisicki’s power, while Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved decisive. With the result, Russia needs one more win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and pursue their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales faces the risk of another east coast low later this week, bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday, particularly to the state’s far north, Northern Rivers, and Mid North Coast, with possible impacts extending to southeast Queensland; while Sydney may see some showers, the heaviest rain is not expected there. The State Emergency Service, still handling 4,409 of 24,196 requests from last week’s storm and deploying over 1,000 personnel (including interstate support), warns that saturated ground could lead to renewed flooding and wind could topple already weakened trees, with special concern for the hard-hit Hunter region. Meteorologists note this system should be faster-moving than last week’s three-day event, and the Bureau of Meteorology says severity is still uncertain, urging communities to prepare homes and families.

Croatian-born model Nina Moric, known for appearing in Ricky Martin’s “Livin’ la Vida Loca” video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide, instead saying she collapsed at home due to low blood pressure, fell and hit her head, and was treated in hospital before recovering at home; she shared photos of bruising on Instagram, said her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso was in Naples at the time despite reports he confirmed a suicide attempt, and expressed shock at the claims. Media also referenced a 2009 alleged attempt. Moric was previously married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, jailed for blackmail-related offenses, with whom she has a son.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times found that as Kate and William await their second child, 12% of Britons favor the traditional name Diana if it’s a girl, with Alice and Charlotte next at 9% each; for a boy, James is preferred by 13% and Alexander is second. Among 2,200 respondents, a quarter hope for a girl and only 3% for a boy, and social media users voiced strong support for honoring William’s late mother with the name Diana. Additionally, 68% back William’s decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber struck a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, around 10 a.m. local time Thursday, killing 17 and wounding 64, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon, according to provincial police chief Faizullah Ghairat and eyewitness accounts. The protesters were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group claimed the attack. CNN reporters contributed from Kabul and Hong Kong.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club’s final contract offer, according to his agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana. Despite seven successful years at the club—winning four La Liga titles and two Champions League trophies—the 31-year-old right-back could not agree a new deal. The proposed three-year extension required him to play in 60% of matches, which Santana called unacceptable, stating negotiations are over and criticizing Barcelona for delaying renewal talks until April.

Pablo Osvaldo, on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton and scoring three goals in six games, urged his former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentine club. He told Corriere dello Sport that Pirlo and Totti’s South American–style qualities would suit Boca, and that La Bombonera’s fans would “go crazy” for them, praising Pirlo as a top midfielder and noting Totti’s legendary status at Roma.

Teenage amateur jockey Lee Lewis Ferguson, working at Paul Nicholls’s yard, returned to routine stable duties with only a cut on his nose after a widely viewed, spectacular double-somersault fall from favourite Merrion Square in the 4:20 pm at Wincanton. He rode out the next morning, saying the incident was a blur until he saw the replay in the weighing room, where fellow jockeys reacted in horror. Grateful to have escaped serious injury, he took some teasing, gained a few hundred Twitter followers, and joked that the somersaults might point to a future in gymnastics after racing.

James Haskell, the England flanker and London Wasps captain, marked the UK release of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man, captioned with hashtags celebrating the film and Under Armour. The movie premiered at Westfield London with stars including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell began his career at Wasps in 2002, earned his first England cap in 2007, then moved to Stade Francais in 2009, Ricoh Black Rams in Japan after the 2011 World Cup, and the Highlanders in New Zealand before returning to Wasps in 2012. Since his return he has passed 100 appearances for the club and amassed 57 England caps.

The passage highlights the resurgence of wide-leg trousers as a key SS15 trend, offering an effortless alternative to long-dominant skinny jeans. Suitable in denim, cropped, printed, or striped styles, the look echoes 1970s fashion and appeared on runways from Gucci, Céline, and Stella McCartney, with high-street options like Topshop’s Miller and affordable picks from Finery London. Styling advice centers on proportion: pair with simple knits, shirts, or tees; choose high heels that expose the top of the foot to elongate legs; opt for high-waisted, very long lengths for added height; and avoid being overwhelmed by fabric. Denim is the easiest entry point, and the trend works even in cooler weather. Celebrities like Louise Redknapp and Poppy Delevingne exemplify the look, and more inspiration is available at astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan will proceed with screening “American Sniper” at a UMix student event after initially canceling it due to a petition by over 200 students who said the film negatively depicted the Middle East; the reversal followed backlash and a counter-petition. Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper called the cancellation a mistake, citing the university’s commitment to freedom of expression and student choice. As an alternative, UMix will also show the family-friendly film “Paddington.” The decision received praise from Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh.
