Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24 and living in Cockburn Central, allegedly used a lighter to ignite an aerosol and directed the flame at a quokka on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3, singeing but not killing the animal. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, and evicted them from the island. Both were charged with animal cruelty and are scheduled to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas, about the size of a domestic cat, are found on small islands off Western Australia, notably Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

CNN reports that 102-year-old Alice Barker, a former chorus line dancer at New York venues like the Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar in the 1930s–40s who performed alongside stars such as Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen her own filmed performances because her movies, photos, and memorabilia were lost; with help from filmmaker Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers, “Soundies” (early music videos) of her dancing were compiled and shown to her at her nursing home, and she reacted with delight, calling it “just fabulous.”

A survey of 1,100 UK adults by vehicle leasing firm OSV found a sharp decline in DIY car washing: 31% of men and 75% of women have never washed their own car, and only 12% of men who do wash their cars do so regularly; just 5% have asked children to do it for pocket money. Reasons include Sunday shopping, live football, larger vehicles, and the growth of hand and automated car washes. Holiday periods see a spike, with an estimated 15 million cars cleaned by owners over Easter, though a quarter did it to get out of the house. Owners wash most often in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, least in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh; Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most likely to be owner-washed, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least. OSV’s Andrew Kirkley notes the fading Sunday tradition amid less free time and convenient, cheap alternatives.

Martin Skrtel praised Steven Gerrard’s influence on him since joining Liverpool in 2008, calling Gerrard still one of the world’s best and synonymous with the club, while acknowledging Liverpool will be different without him. With Gerrard set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and potentially end his Liverpool career in a May 30 final before moving to LA Galaxy, Skrtel said Gerrard helped him settle at the club and deserves thanks. Despite Gerrard’s impending departure, Skrtel believes Liverpool have players who can replace him if supported and emphasizes teamwork. Both players could return from three-match bans for the Villa match.

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus thrilled the Augusta National crowd by making his first-ever hole-in-one there during the Par-3 Contest, acing the 130-yard fourth hole while playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. His feat was part of a record-tying day with five aces, highlighted further by Camilo Villegas making two holes-in-one (on the fourth and eighth) before losing a playoff to Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters champion who first won the green jacket in 1963 and last in 1986, is among five golfers to have completed the career Grand Slam—a milestone Rory McIlroy could achieve with a Masters win.

Multiple storms triggered tornado warnings across Kansas Wednesday night, with a spotted twister northwest of Goddard moving northeast and additional reports from southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Experts warned that nighttime tornadoes are especially dangerous. Beyond Kansas, the National Weather Service indicated a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri, where wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof damage, and street flooding were reported; nearby towns saw ominous clouds and baseball-size hail. More storms were forecast Thursday for the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Oklahoma reserve deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, saying he intended to use a Taser during an April 2 weapons sting; a judge allowed Bates to travel to the Bahamas, prompting Harris’ family to criticize the trip as apathetic. Bates’ preliminary hearing is set for July 2, and his attorneys say they look forward to addressing facts in court. The Harris family’s lawyer alleges Bates was unqualified and benefited from favoritism tied to donations and friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz; the sheriff’s office denies claims that supervisors were told to forge Bates’ records. Bates’ lawyers released training documents asserting he had proper training. Two deputies involved in Harris’ arrest were reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor, preparing to challenge José Aldo for the featherweight title in Las Vegas on July 11, unveiled a new tiger face tattoo on his stomach, adding to his chest tattoo of a gorilla eating a heart, and captioned it on Instagram with a predatory message. McGregor asserts he is more motivated than Aldo, claiming Aldo doesn’t want the belt “in his presence.” Their rivalry intensified during a promotional tour in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo’s belt before 5,000 home supporters, underscoring their fractious relationship ahead of Aldo’s eighth title defense.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a schooner of beer in about six seconds at an Australian rules event, drawing cheers from players but criticism from anti-drinking advocates. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert called it problematic, arguing it glorified binge drinking, linked masculinity to alcohol, and encouraged speed and quantity over socializing; she also faulted media and political reactions that reinforced heavy-drinking stereotypes. Opposition leader Bill Shorten joked about Abbott’s beer habits, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended him, citing his fitness and saying there was nothing wrong with the act. Witnesses described Abbott proudly downing the beer, though Robert noted shifting public concern about binge drinking compared to past leaders like Bob Hawke.

Indiana health officials report a significant rise in HIV cases linked to Scott County—now 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary—more than two weeks into a 30‑day emergency needle exchange approved by Gov. Mike Pence, amid an outbreak among IV drug users primarily using Opana. While testing expansion was expected to increase case counts, the surge pressures Pence to decide next week on extending the program beyond April 25. The exchange has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used ones, aided by a mobile unit building trust. Policy uncertainty persists: Pence opposes exchanges long-term; Senate leaders are unsure about broader authorization, and a bill allowing high–hepatitis C–rate counties to run exchanges faces debate before the April 29 adjournment. Advocates argue exchanges are proven harm reduction, but funding is a challenge due to a federal ban on public funding and the lack of state funds in Pence’s order.

An Arsenal-obsessed boyfriend made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a mock “Arsenal exam” with multiple-choice, tables, and written answers, complete with strict instructions and red-pen marking. She scored 43.5/50 (87%) and received an A, with joking feedback that he wouldn’t dump her, though he noted she could improve on player positions and specific questions (e.g., missing Koscielny, misplacing Özil and Welbeck). Creative answers—like praising Alexis Sánchez over Eden Hazard—earned extra marks, while wrong answers drew angry-face doodles. Saskia shared the test on Twitter, sparking reactions that ranged from calling the boyfriend a legend and dubbing Saskia “proper gf material” to criticism that he’d gone too far; most took it as lighthearted fun.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former Medellín cartel member who became a DEA informant for 27 years, says he was promised U.S. citizenship for his unpaid work but is now facing deportation after retiring due to declining health. His information helped prosecute figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, and he assisted global undercover stings, earning praise from his former DEA handler, who called the government’s inaction “bureaucracy at its worst” and even gave Toro $5,000 for medical needs when the DEA declined to help. After going public, the DEA refused to assist with his citizenship; his last temporary visa expired January 1, leaving him in the U.S. illegally, unable to collect Social Security, and fearing he would be killed if returned to Colombia. Toro seeks a green card or passport, saying he has atoned and only wants what was promised.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Mathura district, Uttar Pradesh, allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village while relieving herself, set herself on fire with kerosene on Tuesday after her family reportedly urged silence; her brother extinguished the flames and she is in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns, while the accused have been arrested. The case unfolds amid heightened sensitivity to sexual violence in India following the government’s ban on the documentary India’s Daughter about the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh, which sparked nationwide and global protests and led to death sentences for four perpetrators. Recent vigilante incidents, including mob killings of accused rapists in Nagaland, underscore public outrage and concern over women’s safety.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal, ahead of his first Old Trafford derby against Manchester City, said he dreams of victory to boost United’s push for a top-three finish but ruled out Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw as not match-fit despite general squad fitness. He emphasized controlling aggression after a 1-0 loss in the reverse fixture, downplayed revenge motives, and noted that a win could make third place attainable and virtually secure top four, while praising the strong support of United’s fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a coordinated protest over high ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates, where the cheapest tickets for the 12:45pm kickoff were £64. The action, featuring banners inside and outside the 60,000-capacity stadium reading messages like “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “Football without fans is nothing,” followed the announcement of the Premier League’s £5.14bn TV deal. Organized by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement with Liverpool groups Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, supporters condemned “extortionate” prices, late fixture changes, and unreasonable kickoff times, warning that without price reductions aligned with working-class incomes, clubs risk losing a generation of fans. Further protests were planned after full-time.

A newborn named Star from Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed within days of birth with biliary atresia, a life-threatening condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent, signaled by persistent jaundice. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock the ducts and learning neither parent was a suitable donor, her mother’s twin sister, Shanell Reader, was found to be an ideal match and donated part of her liver. Star underwent a transplant in November, spent six weeks in hospital, and has since made a good recovery, though she requires weekly blood and liver function tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Her family expressed shock at the diagnosis, immense gratitude to Shanell, and relief that Star now has the chance to live a normal life.

Chelsea stars Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake faced teammates Loic Remy and Willian in Audi’s football challenge, competing in three rounds involving precision shots into car boots, a makeshift tennis game over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus, and long-range attempts to sink balls into convertible Audis. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds (5-3 and then extending the lead to 6-0), but Remy and Willian rallied to win the final long-range challenge. A humorous mishap occurred when Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror with a long-range shot, drawing a stunned reaction from Remy, though no real consequences were implied.

Former Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, who drove his pickup across a New Hampshire highway median at over 100 mph in December 2013, killing Vermont couple Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé Jason Timmons, 29, told the court at his sentencing that he was not suicidal, despite earlier statements to investigators. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide for the couple’s deaths and assault for the fetus’s death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison, and is also being sued in a wrongful death case. Prosecutors said he argued with his wife about medications and chose to drive into the median while “depressed and loopy,” while his defense cited Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug effects, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis, and his wife described him as ethical and suffering serious health issues. Dellinger, with past senior roles at PPG Industries, Sprint, Delphi, and GE, previously took a severance package worth over $1 million and his family trust holds Sunapee properties valued at about $3 million.

Lacey Spears of Kentucky was sentenced to 20 years to life for second-degree murder after poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul, with salt via his feeding tube while maintaining an online presence about his illnesses; prosecutors argued she induced and exaggerated his medical issues for attention, calling the crime unfathomably cruel, while her defense claimed she was a loving mother and blamed hospital negligence, with plans to appeal. The boy’s father, Chris Hill, reacted on Facebook expressing a desire for her to be placed in general population so she would be harmed, criticizing her lack of emotion at sentencing. Prosecutors presented her social media posts, including images of Garnett’s final hours, and noted repeated unnecessary medical interventions throughout his short life; Spears did not testify.

Australia’s flu vaccine supply is arriving a month late because scientists updated it to include protection against two strains that drove higher deaths in Europe and the US—influenza A (H3N2) and influenza B (B/Phuket)—in addition to H1N1. The northern hemisphere’s vaccine was a poor match, prompting global authorities to modify the formula for Australia’s winter; the same formulation will be used next northern winter. Free, government-funded shots for high‑risk groups (very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians) start April 20. Experts, including Dr Alan Hampson, urge everyone to book vaccinations now to protect themselves and those around high‑risk individuals, saying the updated vaccine is worth the wait and should better prevent deaths.

Amid the 150th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln’s assassination, Illinois faces criticism and budget pressures over Lincoln’s Tomb in Springfield. A National Geographic piece by historian Adam Goodheart called the tomb’s interior a disappointment with “office lobby” character and “incongruous art deco” reconstruction, a view disputed by site caretakers and visitors. Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed folding the state historic preservation agency, which manages the site, into another department amid a fiscal crisis, following prior funding cuts that reduced hours and staffing. Despite concerns from supporters about further cuts, officials note over $2.5 million in recent repairs and renovations—including interior plaster, paint, bronze and marble work, upgraded lighting, and vault waterproofing—leaving the site in excellent condition. Designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, the tomb—rebuilt in 1899 and 1930—features marble and bronze interiors leading to the family burial chamber marked “now he belongs to the ages.”

The passage critiques the resurgence of 1990s and early-2000s fashion trends, noting that while items like chokers, berry lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein tees are popular again, the return of JNCO wide-leg jeans alarms many. It highlights nine “worst offenders” that should stay in the past: bucket hats reappearing via celebrities like Rihanna; camouflage prints worn by stars from Destiny’s Child to Jourdan Dunn; maximalist looks such as double denim revived by Kylie Jenner; Ugg boots favored for comfort by Paris Hilton and Kristen Bell; ultra-short “Daisy Dukes” popularized by Jessica Simpson and embraced by Miley Cyrus; Juicy Couture velour tracksuits kept alive by Nicki Minaj; brightly colored/mirrored sunglasses worn by Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner; corsets as outerwear from Victoria Beckham to Selena Gomez; and harem trousers once worn by Kim Kardashian and now by Elle Macpherson.

A roundup of trending stories includes a rare quadruple rainbow over New York captured by Amanda Curtis; China cracking down on the practice of hiring strippers for rural funeral wakes; Robert Downey Jr. cutting short a tense UK interview over personal questions; the viral #KylieJennerChallenge promoting jar-suction lip plumping; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her past with filmmakers; a school rejecting a bomb-referencing prom-posal amid racism claims; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp’s dramatic transformation in the Black Mass trailer; and creative announcements like a Fresh Prince–themed pregnancy reveal and a military dad photobombing his son.

At the Miami Open, Serena Williams earned her 700th career victory with a 7-6, 1-6, 6-3 quarter-final win over Sabine Lisicki, avenging her 2013 Wimbledon loss and advancing to the semifinals, where she will face Simona Halep after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens 6-1, 7-5. Celebrations echoed Andy Murray’s earlier 500th-win cake as Williams was also presented with a giant cake. Serena’s potential matchup with sister Venus ended when Venus lost to Carla Suárez Navarro.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani human rights and free speech advocate who ran the Karachi café and cultural space T2F, was shot dead by two gunmen after hosting a discussion on enforced disappearances in Baluchistan, a topic often silenced in Pakistan; her mother was also shot but is expected to recover. Known for promoting technology, women’s entrepreneurship, secular discourse, and the arts, Mahmud had previously received death threats yet persisted in creating space for open debate. No group has claimed responsibility, and police have not identified a motive. Her killing sparked nationwide grief and tributes, highlighting her role as a symbol of humanism, love, and tolerance in a country where free expression is dangerous.

The passage profiles 82-year-old Mangu Ram and roughly 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), mostly Hindus who fled to Jammu and Kashmir during the 1947 partition, who have been denied state citizenship rights for nearly seven decades due to pre-independence laws and political fears of upsetting the Muslim-majority state’s demographic balance. Lacking rights to own property, vote in state elections, access state-run training colleges, or hold state government jobs, three generations remain in poverty in slum settlements around Jammu, despite Kashmir being relatively prosperous. With the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) newly sharing power in the state, WPRs hope for normalization of their status, while activists like Labha Ram Gandhi warn of escalating protests if promises fail. The broader context includes ongoing militant violence and long-standing conflict over Kashmir.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is weighing a summer move to Chelsea after the Premier League leaders made a reported £4m offer, with a plan to loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem. The 22-year-old, who prioritizes regular playing time and development, says he will take his time deciding. His former coach Ranko Popovic praised Muto’s intelligence, speed, strength, confidence, and prolific chance creation, predicting he could thrive at Chelsea. Jose Mourinho acknowledged awareness of Muto and noted that while commercial factors—amid Chelsea’s £200m Yokohama Rubber sponsorship—affect transfers within Financial Fair Play rules, the club only pursues players who are good or strong prospects.

The passage argues that England should scrap its policy of not selecting overseas-based players for the national rugby team, praising Australia for reversing a similar stance and citing examples like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell at Toulon. It contends that World Cups require picking the absolute best, regardless of club location, and highlights Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon as players who improved abroad, alongside Jonny Wilkinson’s success in France. The author insists that restricting selection undermines England’s chances, creates doubt among players, and is misguided compared with nations like South Africa and Wales that select stars such as Bryan Habana and Leigh Halfpenny from foreign clubs.

Open Garden’s FireChat app enables off-the-grid messaging by creating wireless mesh networks using Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework and Android Bluetooth, allowing messages and photos to pass between nearby devices (about 30 feet per hop) without internet or mobile signal; while individual message propagation typically tops out around 200 feet, Open Garden’s new egg-shaped Greenstone device acts as a beacon/booster to strengthen and extend these networks by storing and relaying messages when FireChat users come within roughly 20 feet, holding up to 1,000 recent messages with a one-year battery life. FireChat, downloaded over five million times, supports chatrooms for nearby and broader “everyone” communication, offers secure and anonymous messaging, and is useful in places like planes, subways, festivals, protests, stadiums, or connectivity outages; Greenstone is still in development, currently only works with FireChat, and Open Garden is seeking manufacturing partners to bring it to market.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle uses the word “fat” as a neutral, body-positive self-description alongside “short” and “wife,” arguing it needn’t mean “ugly.” In a recent TED Talk, she highlighted rising size discrimination—up 66% in 30 years—and the early pressure on girls whose top “magic wish” is to be thinner. Citing research that exposure to diverse bodies increases acceptance and even preference, she performs burlesque to present a glamorous, positive image of a fat body, echoing fellow performer Beelzebabe’s view that burlesque challenges narrow standards of desirability. Weighing 240 lbs, Bustle began performing in 2012; overcoming initial insecurities became a “courage reference” that boosts her confidence, a strategy she recommends to others. Her 2014 TED Talk, posted to YouTube recently, has drawn about 38,000 views and largely positive feedback, including messages from viewers who reconsidered their body image, leading her to believe the body-positivity movement is gaining ground.

Arsenal winger Theo Walcott, often benched this season (17 of 33 Premier League games), appeared in a Lanvin photoshoot alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Ozil, and model Olga Sherer; Arsenal’s first team will wear similar attire en route to Wembley for the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30. Walcott, who came on for the last six minutes of the 0-0 draw with Chelsea, hopes to make his first start since the 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14 when Arsenal face Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

An auction of 417 original props, puppets, and make-up creations from legendary effects artist Rick Baker’s Cinovation Studio will take place May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at propstore.com, with the collection valued at about $746,100 and individual items expected to exceed $40,000. Highlights span more than 50 productions, including Men in Black (Alien Edgar Bug estimated $40,000, Mikey costume $30,000, Hammerhead alien $8,000, Worm Guy from MIB II $10,000), Batman Forever (Two-Face mask $1,500, bat puppet $6,000), How the Grinch Stole Christmas (Grinch costume $8,000), Gremlins 2 (Bat Gremlin $8,000, Mohawk Mogwai $8,000, Daffy Gremlin $6,000), Harry and the Hendersons (Harry suit $6,000), Mighty Joe Young (hero Joe head $6,000), Michael Jackson projects (Moonwalker robotic transformation face $3,000; Thriller video items), Batman & Robin (Frozen thug statue “Frosty” $4,000), and Planet of the Apes. Prop Store’s Brandon Alinger called it a no-reserve sale offering fans a rare chance to own pieces from Baker’s 30-plus-year career.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell from Talybont-on-Usk, Wales, died after becoming separated from his family while skiing in Flaine, France, and falling 164 feet in woodland he entered after leaving the piste, apparently heading toward the resort he saw below. Police traced his footprints and sliding marks to locate his body, and said it is ready for repatriation while the family remains in the Alps. Described by loved ones as daring, outgoing, caring, and a competent skier who started at three and admired Bear Grylls, Carwyn’s death has left his family devastated, with tributes from his school, community, and friends noting he will be greatly missed.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed severe anorexia after becoming obsessed with being “size zero,” surviving on about 100 calories a day and hiding food, which led to her collapse and a week on a heart monitor as her body began to shut down. Her disorder began two years earlier after bullying and a desire to lose weight quickly, escalating from a “sensible diet” to near-starvation. With support from eating disorder services (EDICT and CAMHS), she began recovery and now advocates against pressures on girls to be ultra-thin. Her improved body image and confidence have taken her to the Miss Teen GB semi-final, a pageant that promotes positive, non–size-zero ideals. The passage also outlines NHS information on anorexia, its symptoms, prevalence, and guidance to seek help through charities like Beat.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015/16 home kit at Anfield, the first from New Balance under a record-breaking £300m four-year deal replacing Warrior, featuring a new gingham design, all-white branding, an updated collar, and a Hillsborough tribute. Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, Simon Mignolet, and others modeled the strip, with fans loudly urging Sterling—who recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and admitted being flattered by Arsenal links—to stay; the club remains adamant he will not leave this summer. Players praised the supporters, highlighted the “Hold Nothing Back” message, and looked ahead to the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Sturridge targeting a trophy as a platform for future success and hopes alive for Steven Gerrard’s farewell FA Cup final.

Researchers from the University of Manchester, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, have produced the largest high-definition map to date of dark matter, covering about 0.4% of the sky using gravitational lensing measurements from the Dark Energy Camera on the 4 m Blanco Telescope in Chile, as part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey. Built from analyses of 130 million galaxy images and immense supercomputing power, the map reveals clumps and filaments of dark matter aligning with galaxy distributions and cosmic voids, supporting theories that galaxies form in regions of higher dark matter density. This initial release—about 3% of the eventual survey area—previews a planned 3D map spanning 12.5% of the sky by 2018, aimed at probing how dark matter “clumpiness” evolves over time to shed light on dark energy, which is thought to drive the universe’s accelerating expansion.

PSV Eindhoven confirmed Manchester United have made an official approach for 21-year-old winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal—who coached him at the 2014 World Cup—keen to sign him amid competition from PSG and another major European club. PSV’s technical director Marcel Brands said the fee will exceed last summer’s rebuffed £15m bid from Tottenham. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years and their 22nd overall. A PSV academy product with pace, dribbling, and a powerful right foot, he typically plays from the left cutting inside, though he can hold the ball too long at times. He has been compared to Arjen Robben and, by scout Ed van Steijn, favorably to a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Internationally, Depay debuted under Van Gaal, scored twice at the 2014 World Cup, and was nominated for Best Young Player.

Chelsea’s youth team beat Manchester City’s youngsters 3-1 in Manchester to take a strong first-leg lead back to West London, with Tammy Abraham scoring two first-half volleys (his 35th and 36th of the season) and Dominic Solanke adding a late third after Isaac Buckley-Ricketts had briefly leveled for City. Chelsea’s defense, led by Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori, largely contained City, while Ola Aina and Jay Dasilva posed threats from full-back and Ruben Sammut and Charlie Colkett controlled midfield. For City, captain Tosin Adarabioyo was solid at the back, Brandon Barker was lively but erratic, and opportunities were missed by Aaron Nemane, Manu Garcia, and Kean Bryan, with goalkeeper Kjetil Haug unable to prevent the goals. Abraham left injured on 67 minutes, with Kasey Palmer showing pace off the bench but wasting a chance.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, told CBS’s Face the Nation that while he believes most people are born with their sexual preference and would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cares about, he opposes recognizing same-sex marriage as a constitutional right and maintains marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman. He argued that states, not courts, should decide marriage laws through legislative debate. Rubio, a Catholic who also views divorce as wrong but continues to love those who divorce, recently launched his presidential campaign and has reportedly secured significant donor commitments exceeding $51 million for a crowded Republican primary.

A couple, Spaniard Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian Ilze Zebolde (31), quit restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue an open-ended, low-cost bicycle journey to “discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time.” In 356 days they’ve cycled nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, starting in London and traveling across Western and Southern Europe, the Balkans, Greece, Turkey’s northern coast, Georgia, and Armenia, aiming next for Asia and eventually the Americas. Living on less than three euros each per day—about 10 euro cents per kilometer—they minimize costs by camping most nights, using Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, accepting hospitality from strangers, and spending almost all expenses on simple food (pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce), supplemented by foraged, gifted, or dumpster-dived items. They carry about 130 kg of gear, shower irregularly, and embrace slow travel without a fixed plan, relishing symbolic milestones like crossing from Greece into Turkey as they commit to years on the road.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 are suing James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, alleging a photo booth at their wedding printed a racist slur (“poor n ***** party”) on snapshots. The bride’s sister informed them months later to avoid spoiling the day. According to their attorney, Cathy Hale, the groom called Evans, who allegedly refused to apologize and said “sue me,” prompting the couple to file under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies all allegations, argues there’s no evidence tying his company to the caption among 103 attendees, and claims the couple showed no mental anguish. The couple primarily seeks an apology. Mediation is scheduled for tomorrow; if unresolved, trial is set for July.

England and Harlequins full-back Mike Brown is taking a cautious, stage-by-stage approach to recovering from a recent concussion, unsure of his return date after withdrawing from the Saracens match. Knocked out against Italy in February and experiencing headaches after the France game, he credits World Rugby’s online concussion modules for raising awareness of symptoms and influencing his decision to pull out before the Ireland game. Citing the risks highlighted by cases like George North, Johnny Sexton, and Geoff Parling, Brown refuses to rush back, emphasizes honesty about symptoms, and says he would encourage teammates to do the same. He spoke as a Land Rover ambassador at the launch of its “We Deal In Real” Rugby World Cup 2032 campaign.

A leading statistician, Professor David Spiegelhalter of Cambridge, suggests that increased smartphone and internet use may be contributing to a decline in sexual frequency among Britons, with typical heterosexual couples now having sex three times a month, down from four in 2000 and five in 1990. He argues that technology blurs boundaries between work and home, keeps people constantly connected and checking emails, and reduces “quiet” time, thereby squeezing time with partners. While more people living alone may play a role, he deems the busier, always-connected lifestyle the more realistic explanation, echoing researcher Catherine Mercer’s view that competing demands push sex down the priority list and late-night work emails hinder focus on partners at bedtime.

Once-status-symbol Tibetan mastiffs in China, once fetching up to £1.2 million, have rapidly fallen out of favor due to an anti-corruption crackdown that ended gift-giving to officials, urban bans on dogs over 50 kg, and recognition that the large, loyal breed is unsuited to city life; alongside profit-driven cross-breeding that degraded quality, this collapse has created a glut of unsellable dogs, leading to widespread slaughter for hotpot meat and leather, thefts by gangs, and cruel transport conditions, with animal welfare groups reporting rescues of malnourished, injured dogs and fearing hundreds face similar fates nationwide.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every female user of public transport reported experiencing gender-based harassment or sexual assault, with half first encountering it before age 18. Harassment ranged from insults, persistent flirting, whistling, and comments on appearance to sexual assault and rape. The pervasive, often unreported abuse leaves six in ten women fearing attacks on public transport (versus three in ten men) and forces many to alter routes, schedules, transport modes, behavior, and clothing, effectively limiting their freedom and participation in public life. The report, delivered to France’s women’s rights ministry, prompted calls for a campaign to curb sexist and threatening behavior, with officials stressing that such acts are crimes—e.g., groping is punishable by up to five years in prison and a €75,000 fine—and urging education for women, aggressors, and witnesses.

Direct Line’s #everydayfix competition asked people to identify top “everyday emergencies” in a 2,000-person survey (leading issue: not being able to sleep), then commissioned Makerversity teams to prototype solutions. Three finalists were chosen: Snooze, an alarm clock that syncs with your phone to silence notifications for better sleep; Forget Me Lock, a key-mounted indicator that shows green for open and red for locked so you can confirm door status remotely; and Nipper, a tiny phone charger using any household battery via two terminals for on-the-go power. Twitter votes via retweets with #everydayfix determine the winner by 46 April, which will proceed to Kickstarter and development. Other shortlisted concepts that didn’t make the final three included a bone-conduction navigation helmet, a parking pin to alert when a space frees up, and a relay app to forward messages when your phone dies.

Northumbria Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird is under Ministry of Justice investigation after allocating over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a victims’ charity she directs alongside Northumbria Chief Constable Sue Sim. Critics, including Keith Vaz, call the funding a conflict of interest and “totally inappropriate,” arguing PCCs should not fund organizations in which they have any interest. Baird defends the decision, saying MoJ procedures were followed and funding devolved to PCCs permits such commissioning, while the MoJ says it will probe for conflicts and can halt funding if found. The charity was created after a decline in contacts to its predecessor, Victim Support, but concerns persist about public trust given Sim’s prior misconduct allegations and her impending retirement.

In late March 2014 in Mayfair, Northeast Philadelphia, 53-year-old Greg Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and forcibly tattooed over roughly 42 hours by a group led by 21-year-old Corry “Corey” Campbell, who believed Valecce had injured his cat and stolen money and marijuana; the assault, filmed by the perpetrators, left Valecce with broken ribs, wrists, facial fractures, and offensive tattoos later removed for free. Campbell and Carl Halin, 18, each received 20-year state prison sentences; Sandra Ng, 19, got 23 months; David Thomas, 28, is awaiting sentencing; and Jennifer Pratt, 40, is awaiting trial. Police recovered a tattoo gun, related paraphernalia, drugs, and Valecce’s debit card from the scene. All charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment, the three sentenced defendants pleaded guilty. Valecce reported lasting trauma, including fear, nightmares, and insomnia.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven winger Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal—who coached him at the 2014 World Cup—keen to secure him this summer. PSV’s technical director confirmed contact from United, PSG, and a third major European club, noting the fee will exceed last summer’s rebuffed £15m bid from Tottenham. Depay is having a prolific season with 20 goals in 26 league games, helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years and their 22nd overall. A PSV academy product with pace, dribbling, long-range shooting, and a preference for cutting in from the left, he’s lauded by figures such as Phillip Cocu and scout Ed van Steijn, though still developing decision-making. Internationally, Depay broke through under Van Gaal, scored twice at the 2014 World Cup, and was nominated for Best Young Player.

Chelsea’s youth team beat Manchester City’s youngsters 3-1 in Manchester to take a strong first-leg lead back to West London. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half for his 35th and 36th goals of the season, with Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly leveling for City. Dominic Solanke added a late third to seal the advantage. For City, captain Tosin Adarabioyo and Brandon Barker impressed, though chances were missed by Aaron Nemane, Kean Bryan, and Manu Garcia, while keeper Kjetil Haug looked shaky but blameless on the goals. For Chelsea, defenders Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori were commanding, Ola Aina was influential down the right, Ruben Sammut protected the back four well, and captain Charlie Colkett controlled midfield; Charly Musonda was quiet and Isaiah Brown was lively despite an early miss. Abraham left injured on 67 minutes, replaced by Kasey Palmer.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, told CBS’s Face the Nation that while he believes people are born with their sexual preference, he does not view same-sex marriage as a constitutional right and says marriage definitions should be set by state legislatures, not courts. He maintains marriage should be between one man and one woman but stated he would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cares about out of love and respect, similar to how he treats divorce despite his Catholic belief that it is wrong. Rubio recently launched his presidential campaign, with donors indicating he has significant financial commitments for the primary race.

Pablo Mandado, 27, from Spain, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, from Latvia, quit restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue an open-ended, low-budget cycling journey to “discover different parts of this planet a pedal at a time.” In their first 356 days they covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, starting in London and riding through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, North Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue across Asia and eventually the Americas. They live on less than €3 each per day—about €0.10 per kilometer—by camping most nights, using Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, accepting hospitality from strangers, and keeping food costs to about €2.74 daily with simple staples, foraged or gifted produce, and occasional dumpster diving in Western countries. Carrying about 130 kg of gear, they prioritize scenic, unhurried travel, marking the Greek–Turkish border crossing as a symbolic step into the unknown, and intend to remain on the road for years.

England and Harlequins full-back Mike Brown, recovering from concussion, says he will take a cautious, stage-by-stage return with no set timeline after withdrawing from the Saracens match, citing headaches following the France game and heightened awareness from World Rugby’s online concussion modules. Having been knocked out against Italy and missing the Ireland Test, he stresses the importance of recognizing symptoms, honesty, and not risking long-term health—referencing cases like George North, Johnny Sexton, and Geoff Parling—and notes he would advise teammates similarly. Brown spoke as a Land Rover ambassador at the launch of its “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2028 campaign supporting grassroots clubs.

A Cambridge statistician, Professor David Spiegelhalter, reports that the average heterosexual couple in Britain now has sex three times a month, down from four in 2000 and five in 1990, a decline he links to the rise of the internet and smartphone-driven connectivity. He suggests that constant email checking and blurred boundaries between work and home have eroded “quiet” time, squeezing out moments with partners. While more people living alone may contribute, he argues the more realistic cause is busier, technology-connected lives. Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that competing demands and late-evening work emails leave people too connected and distracted at bedtime to focus on their partners.

Tibetan mastiffs, once status symbols in China fetching up to £1.2 million as recently as a year ago, have plummeted in popularity due to an anti-corruption crackdown that curbed gifting to officials, urban bans on dogs over 50 kg in major cities, recognition that the breed is ill-suited to city life, and widespread cross-breeding that degraded quality and temperament. As a result, many dogs are being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather, with reports of thefts, unscrupulous breeders offloading “imperfect” animals, and cruel transport conditions where rescued dogs were found dead, starving, dehydrated, and injured. The market collapse has left a glut of poor-quality mastiffs, a stark contrast to their 2005–2014 boom when they were prized for loyalty and used traditionally in Tibet for herding.

Direct Line’s #everydayfix competition asked the public to identify top “everyday emergencies” in a 2,000-person survey (with not being able to sleep ranked highest), then commissioned Makerversity design teams to prototype solutions. Three finalists are open to a Twitter vote (most retweets with #everydayfix by 40 April goes to Kickstarter and development): Snooze, an alarm clock by Instruments that links to your phone to silence notifications for better sleep; Forget Me Lock by ONN Studio, a key-mounted indicator that shows green for open and red for locked and can confirm lock status while away; and Nipper by Impulse, a tiny phone charger that uses any household battery via two terminals to give a power boost. Other shortlisted-but-rejected ideas included Hat Nav (a bone-conduction navigation helmet), Parking Pin (a space-reservation alert device), and Relay (an app to route messages to nominees when your phone dies).

The 2009 convention hosted over 512 guests and musical performers, including notable figures such as Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.

The 2009 convention hosted over 6,000 attendees and musical performers, including notable figures such as Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.
